questions.text: During a psychiatric assessment, patient was asked to explain the sentence, “A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush”. To which he replied, “It’s better to have a bird in the hand than to have two birds in the bush”. This is known as ______________
questions.solution:
Type of thinking was being tested in the above patient. The patient was asked meaning of the proverb, and he could only answer in the literal sense, and not what the proverb actually meant metaphorically. Hence the patient has concrete thinking.

In the given example, if the patient had explained the proverb as, “Things we already have are more valuable than what we hope to get”, then it would be abstract thinking.

Types of thinking:

  • Concrete thinking: It is literal thinking that is focused on the physical world. People engaged in concrete thinking are focused on facts in the here and now, physical objects, and literal definitions.
  • Abstract thinking is the ability to think beyond a single aspect of a situation, showing that they can think of various meanings of a situation, simultaneously. 

Type of thinking is tested by asking the patient:

  1. The meaning of a proverb
  2. The similarities between objects like a table and a chair or between a dog and a lion.

Note: Abstract thinking maybe impaired in schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient comes to the OPD with a history significant for a mood disorder. Her moods can be charted as done in the image given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing 3 episodes of mania and 2 episodes of depression within 1 year, points towards a diagnosis of rapid cycling bipolar disorder. 

It is diagnosed when the patient has a combination of 4 or more alternating episodes of depression and mania/hypomania within one year. There must be less than 2 weeks of normalcy between the episodes or an immediate shift between the symptoms with no intervening normal mood.

Risk factors:

  • Female patients
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Alcoholism or substance abuse
  • Antidepressants (if used without mood stabilizers)
  • Cyclothymia
  • Bipolar II disorder

Note: If the phases of mania and depression alternate very rapidly in a matter of hours or days then the condition is known as ultra-rapid cycling disorder.

World Bipolar Day (WBD) is celebrated each year on March 30th to bring world awareness about bipolar disorders and to eliminate the social stigma. The theme for the year 2023 is "BipolarTogether"

questions.text: A 70-year-old female patient presents with one week history of fever, joint pain and myalgia. The examination findings are shown below. The patient has been on procainamide for arrhythmia. Which of the following is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the image showing malar rash are suggestive of features of lupus in a patient who is on procainamide, suggestive of a diagnosis of drug-induced lupus. Drug-induced lupus is commonly associated with anti-histone antibodies.

Drug-induced lupus (DIL) is associated with symptoms such as fever, arthralgia and myalgia, serositis and rash during therapy with certain medications and biological agents. It differs from SLE in that it has lesser female predilection, rarely involves the kidney or the brain, and is not associated with anti-dsDNA antibodies (option B). DIL is commonly associated with anti-histone antibodies. The most frequent drugs which can cause drug-induced lupus are:

  • Antiarrhythmics like procainamide, disopyramide, and propafenone
  • Hydralazine
  • Propylthiouracil
  • Antipsychotics like chlorpromazine and lithium
  • Antiepileptics like carbamazepine and phenytoin 
  • Isoniazid
  • Biologics which block IFNs and TNF

In DIL, ANA becomes positive before the appearance of symptoms. However, even patients who have positive ANA after being on therapy with one of these drugs might never develop clinical features of DIL. DIL resolves over several weeks once the offending agent is stopped.

Anti-centromere antibodies (option A) are seen in CREST syndrome while anti-U1 RNP (option D) are seen in mixed connective tissue disease.

questions.text:
A couple presented to the infertility clinic as they had been unable to conceive. The lady is 25 years old and has normal reports, however, her 27-year-old husband presents with a semen analysis report that is as follows. What is the next best step in the management of this condition?
  • Appearance: Opalescent
  • Volume: 2ml
  • pH: 7.5
  • Sperm count: absent
questions.solution:
As the semen analysis of the patient indicates an absence of sperm in the semen, the next step is to repeat the semen analysis after a month.

During this time, the patient should be advised to take a good nutritional diet and restrict smoking and consumption of alcohol. He should take a cold or tepid bath and discard tight underwear. Only after two negative or below-average counts, he can be diagnosed as azoospermic or oligospermic.

Azoospermia is characterized by the total absence of sperm in semen. This may result from male reproductive tract obstruction or from nonobstructive causes. Obstructive azoospermia may result from a prior vasectomy or ejaculatory duct obstruction. However, congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens (CBAVD) can cause of azoospermia.

Nonobstructive azoospermia may be caused by a karyotypic abnormality such as Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY) or balanced translocation; deletion of a small portion of the Y chromosome; testicular failure; or unexplained causes. Serum FSH is used to differentiate between obstructive and nonobstructive azoospermia(option A). It is elevated in a case of nonobstructive azoospermia. Chromosomal studies are done in cases of nonobstructive azoospermia (option D).

Management of Azoospermia

Obstructive azoospermia requires a vasogram to study the site and nature of the blockage. Vaso-vassal anastomosis has been successful in a few cases. The advantage of surgery over ICSI is that it is a one-time treatment and cost-effective, if successful with permanent effect. In a case of non-obstructive azoospermia, especially in hormonal deficiencies, GnRH and pituitary hormones have been used to induce spermatogenesis.

Other methods of treatment for male infertility are as follows:

• IVF
• Gamete intra-fallopian transfer (GIFT) technique
• Microassisted fertilization (MAF) technique
• Microsurgical epididymal sperm aspiration (MESA) or percutaneous epididymal sperm aspiration (PESA).

questions.text: The axons of the ganglion cells from the nasal retina of the right eye project to the _________

choices.text: Layers 2,3, and 5 of the right lateral geniculate body
Layers 1,4, and 6 of the left lateral geniculate body
Layers 2,3, and 5 of the left lateral geniculate body
Layers 1,4, and 6 of the right lateral geniculate body

questions.solution:
The axons of the ganglion cells from the nasal retina of the right eye project to the layers 1,4, and 6 of the left lateral geniculate body.

The axons of the retinal ganglion cells project a detailed spatial representation of the retina on the lateral geniculate body. Each lateral geniculate body has six well-defined layers numbered from 1 to 6. Of these layers,

  • Layers 1,4, and 6 receive the projections of the axons from the nasal retina of the contralateral eye (crossed fibres)
  • Layers 2,3, and 5 receive the projections of the axons from the temporal retina of the ipsilateral eye (uncrossed fibres)

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is being evaluated for intellectual disability. On examination, the child had large ears, a long, prominent square jaw, and enlarged testes. Genetic analysis reveals trinucleotide repeats. Which of the following is not true about this particular syndrome?

choices.text: It is caused due to mutations in the FMR1 gene
The nucleotide repeats involve the CGG sequence
The larger the triplet repeat expansion, the lesser the intellectual disability
Females can also be affected by this syndrome.

questions.solution:
The patient’s clinical features are strongly suggestive of Fragile X syndrome. The larger the triplet repeat expansion in fragile X syndrome, the more significant the intellectual disability.

It is caused due to trinucleotide repeat expansion (CGG) of DNA in the long arm of chromosome X involving the FMR1 gene. The main clinical features in affected males include intellectual disability, autistic features,post-pubertal macroorchidism, and characteristic facial features including large ears, a long face, and a  square jaw. Affected females also show varying degrees of intellectual disability. 

Diagnosis is made by DNA testing which shows more than 200 trinucleotide (CGG) repeats. Premutation repeats(55-200 repeats) are associated with fragile X–associated tremor/ataxia syndrome, and premature ovarian failure. Unaffected individuals show fewer than 50 trinucleotide repeats.

The image shown below is of a boy who was diagnosed with Fragile X syndrome. Note the large ears, long face, and prominent square jaw.

questions.text:
Which of the following are components of the P-SPIKES protocol for communicating bad news to the patient?
  1. Assess the family's perception of her current medical status and her cancer diagnosis.
  2. Empathize with the family's feelings and provide them emotional support.
  3. Prepare yourself mentally to discuss and break the news.
  4. Schedule a follow-up meeting in a day to re-assess their needs and to provide them with additional information on the developments in the case.
  5. Prepare an appropriate setting for discussion.
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 2, 3, 4, 5.

P -SPIKES protocol is for breaking bad news.

Each letter represents a phase in the six-step sequence.

  • P - Preparation - mentally preparing yourself for the interaction
  • S - setting
  • P - perception
  • I - invitation or information
  • K - knowledge
  • E - empathy
  • S - summarizing or strategize (includes scheduling follow-up visits when needed)

Key components of the SPIKES strategy include demonstrating empathy, acknowledging and validating the patient's feelings, exploring the patient's understanding and acceptance of the bad news, and providing information about possible interventions.

questions.text: A young woman with 10 weeks of amenorrhea, presents with complaints of heavy vaginal bleeding. On examination, an open cervical os with tissue protruding is seen. Ultrasonography reveals echogenic material in the uterine cavity, no adnexal masses, no free fluid, and no viable pregnancy. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The patient has an incomplete abortion and the most appropriate management would be to evacuate the contents of the uterus with dilatation and curettage.

The patient can present with complaints of the expulsion of fleshy mass per vagina, continuous vaginal bleeding, and abdominal cramps. Internal examination reveals open cervical os, and products of conception protruding out of the cervix. Ultrasonography reveals echogenic material (retained products of conception) within the cavity and no viable pregnancy. There are no adnexal masses, and no free fluid found on ultrasonography, ruling out ectopic pregnancy. All this confirms the diagnosis of incomplete abortion. 

Incomplete abortion can be managed surgically, or medically. The surgical method is by dilatation and curettage, it has the least failure rate and gives a quick resolution. For medical management of incomplete abortion at <13 weeks gestation, use of 600 μg misoprostol administered orally or use of 400 μg misoprostol administered sublingually, is recommended.

Note- For medical management of incomplete miscarriage, the use of 400–800 μg vaginal misoprostol has been removed in the updated recommendation from the WHO 2012 Safe abortion guidance (6).

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text: The image shown below represents which type of mechanical asphyxia?
questions.solution:
The type of strangulation shown in the image is Burking. 

Burking is a type of homicidal asphyxial death comprising of smothering and traumatic asphyxia. In burking, the assaulter throws the victim to the ground and kneels or sits on the chest of the victim preventing chest movements. He/she then covers the nose and mouth of the victim with his/her hands. 

Other options:

Option A: Mugging is a type of strangulation caused by holding the neck of the victim in the crook of the elbow.  Pressure is then exerted either on the front of the larynx or at one or both sides by the forearm and upper arm. In mugging, the attack is usually made from behind.

The below image show strangulation by mugging.

Option B: Garrotting involves attacking the victim from behind using a ligature. The ligature is thrown around the unaware victim’s neck and then tightened by twisting it with a lever such as a rod or stick within the ligature. Earlier in Spain, garroting was an official method of judicial execution.

 

Option D: In bansdola, one strong bamboo or stick is placed across the back of the neck and another across the front. The victim is squeezed to death by tieing both ends of the stick with rope.

On examination, a bruise can be seen in the centre of the neck across the windpipe corresponding to the width of the stick or the substance used. A similar mark can be seen on the back of the neck if two sticks are used. 

Sometimes two sticks are used across the back and front of the upper part of the chest and squeezed forcibly. This causes laceration of the muscles, rib fractures and interferes with respiration.

questions.text: While in OBG posting, your professor teaches about positive Stallworthy sign in a patient. Which of the following statement is false about the condition in this patient?

choices.text: It is a painful vaginal bleeding condition
The patient has low lying placenta
Per-vaginal examination should not be done
The uterus is relaxed and soft with no tenderness

questions.solution:
The Stallworthy sign is seen in placenta previa, a painless vaginal bleeding condition not a painful condition.

Clinical features of placenta previa:

  • Sudden-onset recurrent painless vaginal bleeding: First bleeding usually appears after the end of the second trimester or later and is usually mild and not fatal. This is called ‘Sentinel bleed’. 
  • The size of the uterus corresponds to gestational age. 
  • The uterus is relaxed, soft, no tenderness 
  • Floating head 
  • Fetal heart sound is present unless there is major separation and the patient is exsanguinated.
  • Slowing of fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis which recovers promptly as pressure is relieved is suggestive of a low-lying placenta especially of posterior type: Stallworthy sign.

Per-Vaginal Examination should not be done in suspected Placenta Previa, whereas it can be only done in the operation theatre with all the arrangements for CS.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with severe Alzheimer's disease has been prescribed a medication that acts against the NMDA receptors in the brain. Which of the following drug belongs to this category?
questions.solution:
Memantine is an NMDA receptor antagonist that is used in the treatment of Alzheimer’s disease.

It is used as an adjunct or an alternative to first-line therapy. Memantine delays clinical deterioration in patients with moderate to severe Alzheimer’s disease. Adverse effects are mild headache or dizziness. It is excreted by the kidneys and the dosage should be reduced in patients with severe renal impairment.

Other options:

Option A: Galantamine is a natural alkaloid that selectively inhibits cerebral acetylcholinesterase and has some direct agonistic action on nicotinic receptors as well. It has produced cognitive and behavioral benefits in patients with Alzheimer’s disease.

Option B: Piracetam is a cyclic GABA derivative used in Alzheimer's disease. It improves the efficiency of higher telencephalic integrative activities.

Option C: Donepezil is a reversible anti-AChE that produces measurable improvement in several cognitive as well as non-cognitive (activities of daily living) scores in AD.

 

 

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with right wrist pain. She says that the pain aggravates while working and improves with rest. On examination, there is local tenderness in the area of the dorsal radial styloid. There is no limitation of motion, but the ulnar deviation is very painful. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of De Quervain's disease.

De Quervain's disease is a stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons of the first dorsal compartment, namely extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL). It involves noninflammatory thickening of both the tendons and the tunnel or sheath through which they pass. This condition is prominent among females, especially women of childbearing age.

Key diagnostic factors:

  • History of joint overuse at home or at work.
  • Pain and tenderness at the tip of radial styloid.
  • Positive Finkelstein test

Finkelstein's test - The examiner grasps the thumb of the patient and abducts the hand towards the ulnar side. This causes severe pain over the tip of the styloid process. It is positive in the following conditions:

  • De Quervain's disease (tenosynovitis)
  • Arthritis in the intercarpal and radiocarpal joints
  • Superficial radial nerve entrapment 
  • Intersection syndrome i.e. tenosynovitis occurs due to friction between the obliquely placed extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis tendons and the longitudinally placed extensor tendons.

Treatment of De Quervain's disease includes conservative management in the majority of the patients with steroid injection. Only a few require surgical release of the 1st dorsal compartment (housing the APL and EPB tendons).

Other options:

The site of pain and tenderness can be diagnostic

Condition Site of pain
Kienböck’s disease Over the lunate
Scaphoid fracture Anatomical snuffbox
Carpometacarpal osteoarthritis The base of the first metacarpal


Note: Kienböck’s disease is the traumatic softening of the lunate bone. This condition is characterized by ischemic necrosis which may be due to chronic stress or injury.

questions.text: Identify the uterine anomaly in the HSG given below and the class it belongs to according to AFS classification.
questions.solution:
The given HSG shows Didelphys Uterus which belongs to class 3 according to AFS classification.

Uterus didelphys is an anomaly that arises due to non-fusion of the Mullerian ducts, resulting in two entirely separate hemiuteri, two cervices, and a longitudinal vaginal septum running between the two cervices in most cases. The HSG is confirmatory, showing two different endocervical canals opening into separate noncommunicating fusiform endometrial cavities.

  • Class 2- Unicornuate Uterus
  • Class 3 – Didelphys Uterus
  • Class 4- Bicornuate Uterus(Option B)
  • Class 5- Septate Uterus(Option A)
  • Class 6- Arcuate Uterus(Option C)

questions.text: A young man was started on the drug which is an irreversible P2Y12 inhibitor of platelet after percutaneous coronary intervention. Identify this drug?
questions.solution:
Prasugrel is an irreversible P2Y12 inhibitor of the platelet.

Prasugrel is a prodrug that is used in patients with acute coronary syndrome who have undergone percutaneous coronary intervention. It reduces the rate of thrombotic cardiovascular events in such patients. 

Side effects include bleeding and thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura in rare cases. Administration of prasugrel with an anticoagulant or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug is avoided as it may increase the risk of bleeding. Contraindicated in patients above 75 years of age and those with a history of cerebrovascular disease.

Other options:

Option A: Vorapaxar primarily inhibits platelet aggregation caused by thrombin. PAR-1 activation by thrombin contributes to platelet aggregation. Vorapaxar is a competitive antagonist of protease-activated receptor-1 (PAR-1). Vorapaxar is indicated in combination with aspirin and/or clopidogrel to reduce thromboembolic events in patients with MI or peripheral vascular disease.

Option B: Tirofiban acts by blocking Gp IIb/IIIa receptors. It has a short duration of action and is used for the management of patients with non–ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome.

Option C: Eptifibatide acts by blocking Gp IIb/IIIa receptors. They are mainly used during percutaneous coronary intervention for acute coronary syndrome. They carry a high risk of bleeding and can cause thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to you with the complaints of frequent painful urination with a history of weight loss. On rectal examination, a hard, irregular nodule was palpated within his prostate. Lab reports show PSA levels as 7.0 ng/ml. You suspect prostatic carcinoma in this patient and plan for TRUS-guided biopsy. The standard biopsy template usually includes ________
questions.solution:
The standard biopsy template usually includes 12 core-biopsies.

Patients who have either an elevated total PSA level (i.e in excess of 2.5 - 4.0 ng/ml) or abnormal findings on digital rectal examination (DRE) or both are advised to undergo TRUS-guided biopsy of the prostate.

The standard biopsy template involves 12 core biopsies with a spring-loaded biopsy instrument.

Site of biopsy: The tissue is usually obtained from the base, mid, and apex regions, medially and laterally from the left and right sides.

Patients are asked to stop anticoagulants to prevent bleeding complications.

Common adverse effects that follow TRUS biopsy include rectal bleeding, gross hematuria, and hematospermia, all of which are usually self-limited. Fever, urinary infection and retention occur in less than 5% of patients.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs given for diabetes reversibly inhibits the α-glucosidase enzyme?
questions.solution:
Voglibose reversibly inhibits the α-glucosidase enzyme and is used in the treatment of diabetes mellitus. 

Voglibose is an α glucosidase inhibitor with similar properties to acarbose. α-glucosidase is the final enzyme for the digestion of carbohydrates in the brush border of the small intestine mucosa. α glucosidase inhibitors slow down and decrease digestion and absorption of polysaccharides and sucrose. It also promotes the release of GLP-l which adds to its hypoglycemic effect. It is usually preferred in obese patients as a mild antihyperglycemic agent that can be used adjuvant to diet with or without metformin. 

Other options:

Option B: Pioglitazone belongs to the thiazolidinediones class of hypoglycemic drugs that stimulate the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPAR-γ) in muscle, fat, and liver, and reduce insulin resistance. The most common adverse effect include weight gain and edema due to an increase in adiposity and fluid retention. They can increase the incidence of heart failure and the risk of fractures.

Option C: Teneligliptin is a new dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. It exerts a long-lasting effect (>24 hours) on DPP-4 inhibition and antihyperglycemic effects. 

Option D: Repaglinide is a D-phenylalanine/meglitinide analog that blocks ATP-sensitized potassium channels and in turn helps in the release of insulin. It is primarily metabolized by the liver (CYP3A4) into inactive products. It is mainly indicated only in selected type 2 diabetics who suffer pronounced post­ prandial hyperglycemia, or to supplement metformin/long­acting insulin. It is contraindicated in liver disease.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with the following finding. Which of the following is not true about her condition?

choices.text: Occurs due to excess collagen deposition
It grows beyond primary wound margin

questions.solution:
The above image shows a keloid. It is not a precancerous condition.

Keloid scars are associated with elevated levels of growth factors. A keloid scar is defined as excessive scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original incision or wound. Its etiology is unknown but is associated with elevated levels of growth factor, deeply pigmented skin, and inherited tendencies and certain areas of the body (triangle whose points are the xiphisternum and each shoulder tip).

Keloid scars do not improve spontaneously with time and excision of the keloid scar has a high rate of recurrence.

Treatment:

  • Pressure- local moulds or elastic garments
  • Silicone gel sheeting
  • Intralesional triamcinolone injection
  • Excision and steroid injections
  • Excision and postoperative radiation (external beam or brachytherapy)
  • Intralesional excision
  • Laser to reduce redness
  • Vitamin E and palm oil massage

Difference between keloid and hypertrophic scar:

Race No predilection African American, Asian, Hispanic
Site Anywhere (more common on flexor surfaces) Neck, chest, ear lobes, shoulders, upper back
Timings 4–6 weeks postinjury Symptom-free interval; may appear years after injury
Symptoms Raised, some pruritus respects wound confines Pain, pruritus, hyperesthesia, growth beyond wound margins
Regression Frequent spontaneous No
Contracture Frequent Rare
Histology Parallel orientation of collagen fibers Hypocellular, thick, wavy collagen fibers in random orientation

questions.text: A 55-year-old female has come for her annual well-woman checkup. During the breast examination, the following finding is noted. Which of the following is true regarding this finding?

choices.text: It is usually seen in benign inflammatory breast conditions
It is due to blockage of subcuticular lymphatics
It is due to Thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast

questions.solution:
The image shows the Peau d'Orange appearance, a classical sign of breast carcinoma. It is due to the blockage of subcuticular lymphatics. The resultant edema deepens the mouth of the sweat glands and hair follicles giving rise to the typical orange peel appearance. 

Other options:-

  • It is not necessarily always associated with nipple retraction, as seen in the image above where there is peau de orange, but no nipple retraction.
  • Peau d'Orange appearance is a classical sign of breast carcinoma not a finding of benign inflammatory breast condition.
  • Thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast is called Mondor’s disease. The pathognomic feature of Mondor's Disease is a thrombosed subcutaneous cord, attached to the skin.

questions.text: Which of the following statement about testicular tumour is true?

choices.text: A testicular lump felt separately from the testes is suggestive of malignancy.
Lymphatic spread is to the para aortic lymph nodes.
Microscopic residual disease in the scrotum are Stage III testicular tumours.
Ultrasound is not mandatory in all suspected cases of testicular tumours.

questions.solution:
The lymphatic spread of testicular tumors is to the para-aortic lymph nodes. Inguinal lymph nodes are involved only if the scrotal skin is involved.

A solid testicular lump that cannot be felt separately from the testes is suggestive of malignancy (Option A). The diagnosis of a testicular tumor is confirmed by ultrasound. It can also assess the contralateral testis. Ultrasound is a mandatory investigation in all suspected cases of testicular tumors. (Option D)

Stages of testicular tumors (according to the older staging system of Stages I-IV) are valuable in determining treatment options.

  • Stage I: Tumor is limited to testis
  • Stage II: Microscopic residual disease is present in the scrotum or high in the spermatic cord (Option C)
  • Stage III: Retroperitoneal lymph node involvement
  • Stage IV: Distant metastatic deposits

Note: According to TNM Staging of Testicular Tumor: American Joint Committee on Cancer and Union Internationale Contre le Cancer, depending on the Primary tumor (T), regional lymph node (N), distant metastasis (M), and serum tumor markers (hCG, LDH, AFP) it is staged into stages I, II, III.

Related Pearl: TNM staging of testicular tumour: American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) and Union Internationale Contre le Cancer (UICC)

Primary tumor (T)

The extent of the primary tumor is usually classified after radical orchiectomy (except for pTis and pT4) and, for this reason, a pathologic (p) stage is assigned.

pTx - Primary tumor cannot be assessed

pT0 - No evidence of primary tumor (e.g., a histologic scar in testis)

pTis -  Germ-cell neoplasia in situ

pT1 - Tumor limited to the testis and epididymis without vascular/lymphatic invasion; tumor may invade into tunica albuginea but not tunica vaginalis

pT2 - Tumor limited to testis and epididymis with vascular/lymphatic invasion or tumor extending through the tunica albuginea, with the involvement of tunica vaginalis

pT3 - Tumor invades spermatic cord with or without vascular/lymphatic invasion

pT4 - Tumor invades the scrotum with or without vascular/lymphatic invasion

Regional lymph nodes (N)

NX - Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

N0 - No regional lymph node metastasis

N1 - Metastasis with lymph node mass ≤2 cm in greatest dimension; or multiple lymph nodes, none more than 2 cm in greatest dimension

N2 - Metastasis with lymph node mass, 2–5 cm in greatest dimension; or multiple lymph nodes, anyone mass >2 cm but not more than 5 cm in greatest dimension

N3 - Metastasis with lymph node mass >5 cm in greatest dimension

Distant metastasis (M)

MX - Distant metastasis cannot be assessed

M0 - No distant metastasis

M1 - Distant metastasis

M1a - Nonregional nodal or pulmonary metastasis

M1b - Distant metastasis at site other than nonregional lymph nodes or lung

S0 - Marker study levels within normal limits

questions.text: A mother brings her 2-week-old neonate with lesions over the body and arms. On examination, thin-walled superficial vesicles are noted as shown in the image below. A disorder of the eccrine sweat gland is suspected. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows clear, thin‐walled, superficial vesicles 1–2 mm in diameter resembling drops of water, without any associated erythema. It is suggestive of miliaria, a disorder of eccrine sweat glands. 

Miliaria is a common acute or subacute skin condition that arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat ducts in hot humid conditions, resulting in a leakage of sweat into the epidermis (miliaria crystallina and miliaria rubra) or dermis (miliaria profunda).

Other options: 

Option A: Fox-Fordyce disease or apocrine miliaria is the obliteration of the apocrine duct at the infundibulum.

Option B: Bromhidrosis is characterized by foul-smelling sweat usually due to infection of apocrine glands.

Option C: Milia, also known as “milk spots” are pearly opalescent white epidermal inclusion cysts, located over the face usually. They resolve spontaneously without scarring and require no treatment.

Milia and miliaria may sound similar but are actually different from one another. Milia are epidermal inclusion cysts usually located on the face whereas miliaria is a disorder of the eccrine sweat gland and is usually located on the body and arms. The clue given in the question is that the condition is a disorder of the eccrine sweat gland. Hence, the answer is miliaria.

Related Pearl: Different types of miliaria

Miliaria is a common acute or subacute skin condition that arises due to the occlusion or disruption of eccrine sweat ducts in hot humid conditions.

Based on the level of blockade it is differentiated into

  • Miliaria Crystallina- Stratum corneum
  • Miliaria Rubra - Malpighian Layer
  • Miliaria profunda - Dermoepidermal junction

Pathophysiology:

  • The first event may be an increase in the skin flora, perhaps with Staphylococcus epidermidis being responsible for producing an extracellular polysaccharide substance or slime that blocks the lumen of the sweat duct.
  • The parakeratotic plugs, a notable feature of the later stages of the disease, are not the primary cause of the obstruction but arise in the repair process, and further aggravate the obstruction.
  • Leakage of sweat into the epidermis is responsible for the final production of the lesions, and for their further aggravation.
  • Miliaria crystallina occurs commonly in infants due to a delay in the development of patency in the sweat ducts.

Clinical features:

  • Miliaria crystallina: Clear, thin‐walled vesicles, 1–2 mm in diameter without an inflammatory areola, are usually symptomless and develop in crops, mainly on the trunk. In persistent febrile illnesses, recurrent crops may occur. The vesicles soon rupture and are followed by superficial, branny desquamation.

 

  • Miliaria rubra: Typical lesions develop on the body, especially in areas of friction with clothing, and in flexures. The lesions are uniformly minute erythematous papules, which may be present in very large numbers. Characteristically, the lesions produce intense discomfort in the form of an unbearable pricking sensation. Relief is often instantaneous when the stimulus to sweating is abolished by a cool shower. In infants, lesions commonly appear on the occluded skin of the neck, groins and axillae, but also occur elsewhere.

 

 

  • Miliaria profunda: This nearly always follows repeated attacks of miliaria rubra, and is common only in the tropics. The lesions are easily missed. The affected skin is covered with pale, firm papules 1–3 mm across, especially on the body, but sometimes also on the limbs. There is no itching or discomfort from the lesions.

 

Treatment:

  • First line
    • Control local environment (remove excess bedding, fans, air
    conditioning)
    • Cool the skin (damp compresses, cool showers)
    • Avoid tight or excessive clothing
  • Second line
    • Menthol (e.g. 0.5% menthol in aqueous cream)
    • Topical antibiotics if there is secondary infection
    • Mild topical steroids
  • Third line
    • Removal to cooler climate
    • Prophylactic oral vitamin C

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient presents with complaints of pruritus, easy fatiguability, and right upper quadrant discomfort. Laboratory investigations show elevation of GGT & ALP and the presence of anti-mitochondrial antibodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A perimenopausal age group female presenting with fatigue, pruritus, elevated GGT & ALP, and antimitochondrial antibody positivity points to a diagnosis of primary biliary cholangitis (PBC). 

Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) is characterized by chronic, non-suppurative inflammatory destruction of small- and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts. It shows strong female preponderance. Most of the patients are asymptomatic; symptomatic patients present with fatigue out of proportion to the extent of liver disease or the age of the patient. Pruritus is another common complaint. On examination, jaundice and other complications of chronic liver disease such as hepatosplenomegaly and ascites may be seen, but may not be common. 

Laboratory findings show a cholestatic pattern of liver enzyme elevation, with increased levels of GGT and ALP. Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are present in 95% of the patients with PBC. A liver biopsy is relevant in the setting of AMA-negative disease and would demonstrate florid duct lesions/ granulomas. Ursodeoxycholic acid is the first-line treatment early in the disease course. It has been shown to slow the progress of the disease. Liver transplantation is the treatment of choice for patients with decompensated liver disease due to PBC.

Other Options:

Option B: Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by the presence of p-ANCA, not A anti-mitochondrial antibody.

Option C: Autoimmune Hepatitis may present with fatigue, pruritus, ⬆️ AST, ⬆️ ALT. It is often positive for anti-smooth muscle antibodies.

Option D: Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis involves the fatty infiltration of the liver in non-alcoholics and usually presents with elevated liver enzymes (⬆️ AST, ⬆️ ALT) in obese individuals.

questions.text: A patient involved in a road traffic accident had difficulty in breathing and multiple bone fractures. Chest X-Ray revealed a pneumothorax and an emergency needle thoracostomy is performed. The patient was shifted to the operation theatre for management of the fractures. Which of the following inhalational agents would you avoid in this patient?
questions.solution:
The inhalational agent to be avoided in a patient with pneumothorax undergoing surgery is nitrous oxide.

Nitrous oxide has greater diffusibility across tissue than nitrogen. It has the potential to expand air-containing cavities, specifically nitrogen-containing spaces, and replace nitrogen. Hence, it should be avoided in patients with pneumothorax. 

Due to its greater diffusibility, nitrous oxide is avoided in 

  • arterial air embolism
  • pneumothorax
  • acute intestinal obstruction with bowel distension
  • intracranial air
  • pulmonary air cysts
  • intraocular air bubbles
  • tympanic membrane grafting
  • middle ear surgeries

Nitrous oxide can even diffuse into tracheal tube cuffs, increasing its pressure and hampering mucosal blood circulation. 

The other options are not specifically contraindicated in pneumothorax as they do not worsen the condition. Their effects on the respiratory system are given below:

Option A: Desflurane causes a decrease in tidal volume and an increase in respiratory rate. Due to its pungent nature, it causes airway irritation leading to increased salivation, coughing, and laryngospasm.

Option B: Halothane causes rapid and shallow breathing as it stimulates ventilatory efforts. It is a potent bronchodilator but depresses the clearance of mucus from the respiratory tract. 

Option C: Sevoflurane depresses respiration and reverses bronchospasm similar to isoflurane. 

Related Pearl: Unique features of Nitrous oxide

Concentration-effect

  • The blood gas partition coefficient of N2O is 35 times higher than O2 and N2, hence its rapid uptake diminishes its volume and concentrates the remaining anesthetics in the alveolus.

Second-gas effect

  • Concentration-effect of one gas over another is known as the second gas effect
  • Increase in the partial pressure of the 2nd gas (Oxygen and volatile agents) due to the rapid uptake of N2O during induction.

Diffusion hypoxia (Finks effect)

  • Rapid elimination of N2O during recovery causes a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen leading to hypoxia
  • Avoided by using 100% oxygen for 10 minutes during recovery from anesthesia.

Nitrous oxide in gas-filled spaces

  • It diffuses into air-containing cavities more rapidly than air (principally nitrogen) can be absorbed by the bloodstream
  • If the walls surrounding the cavity are rigid, pressure rises instead of volume.

Hence N2O is contraindicated in:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Acute intestinal obstruction
  • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to your clinic with complaints of fever and abdominal pain for the past couple of weeks. On inquiry he recalls experiencing bloody stools with colicky abdominal pains and tenesmus several weeks ago. Examination reveals tenderness in the right upper quadrant. A CT scan was requested and the findings are attached below. Which among the following is the infective form of the suspected causative organism?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features and upper abdominal CT scan revealing an abscess in the right liver lobe are suggestive of amoebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica. The infective form of Entamoeba histolytica is the quadrinucleate cyst. 

Entamoeba histolytica are intestinal amoebae that exist in three forms. 

  • Trophozoite:
    • It is the only form found in tissues. 
    • It is also found in freshly-passed dysenteric stools. However, they are not the infective form. 
    • It is irregularly shaped with cytoplasm (contains an outer ectoplasm and an inner endoplasm), and a nucleus has a central karyosome with radiating fibrils called linin network giving a cartwheel appearance, and pseudopodia that exhibit gliding motility.
    • They often contain phagocytosed erythrocytes
    • They divide by binary fission.
  • Precystic stage:
    • It is formed through the encystment of the trophozoite
    • They are round or oval
    • It has a large glycogen vacuole and 2 chromatid bars
  • Cystic stage:
    • It is formed through the formation of a refractile cyst wall around the pre-cyst
    • They are spherical
    • The early cyst has one nucleus
    • Glycogen and chromatid bodies disappear and the early cyst undergoes mitotic divisions to form the mature cyst
    • Mature cyst is a quadrinucleate cyst which is the infective form
    • It is passed in feces and remains viable under moist conditions for about 10 days.

Clinically, infection with entamoeba histolytica may present as- 

  • Amoebic Colitis- Patients with amoebic colitis typically present with colicky abdominal pains and diarrhea. There is associated tenesmus and heme-positive stool. In amoebiasis, the organisms attach to the colonic epithelium, invade the crypts and burrow laterally to create a flask-shaped ulcer. Tissue damage results in inflammation. 
  • Amebic Liver Abscess- Patients usually present with fever, abdominal pain, abdominal distention, and enlargement and tenderness of the liver. A characteristic "anchovy sauce-like" pus may be seen.

Diagnosis can be established using ultrasonography, CT or MRI. The most useful laboratory evaluation is the measurement of cir­culating antiamebic antibodies, by enzyme immunoassay; these antibodies are present in 90% to 95% of patients. The antibody can be present because of prior infection, and hence, detection of Entamoeba histolytica lectin antigen in the serum and liver abscess pus is more useful for acute infections than chronic infection. Nuclear medicine studies, such as gallium scanning or technetium (99mTc)  liver scans, can be helpful in differentiating pyogenic from amebic abscesses because amebic abscesses typically do not contain leukocytes and therefore do not light up on these scans.

Treatment for amebic abscesses includes tinidazole or metronidazole along with a luminal amoebicide like paromomycin or diloxanide furoate.

questions.text: An 11-month-old child is brought to the emergency room with a history of 12-14 episodes of loose, watery stools which is not blood-stained for the last two days. On examination, the temperature is 98.8 deg F, pulse rate is 130/min, and respiratory rate is 45/min. The child appears lethargic with sunken eyes and skin turgor is reduced with recoil in 3 secs. Which of the following is incorrect about the management protocol in this patient as per the WHO IMNCI plans?

choices.text: The fluid replacement should be done over 6 hours
Both Ringer's lactate and normal saline can be used for resuscitation
The total fluid requirement in this patient is 75ml/kg
ORS can be given as a bridge to definitive management

questions.solution:
The child presenting with watery diarrhea, lethargy, sunken eyes, and skin pinch going back very slowly(longer than 2 seconds) is classified as severe dehydration. 100 ml/kg of ringer’s lactate solution or if not available, normal saline is given over 6 hours.

According to the IMNCI classification, the child should be treated according to plan C. The child is transferred urgently to the hospital and the mother is advised to give frequent sips of ORS along the way.

This child should be started on IV fluids immediately. 100 ml/kg of ringer’s lactate solution or if not available, normal saline can be given over 6 hours as the child is less than 12 months of age. If the child can drink ORS(Oral rehydration solution) should be given by mouth while the drip is set up. 

As soon as the child can drink, ORS is given at about 5 ml/kg/hour, which is usually after 3-4 hours (infants) or 1-2 hours (children).

Necrotizing enterocolitis is the most common life-threatening gastrointestinal disorder in the newborn period. It is characterized by various degrees of mucosal or transmural inflammation and necrosis of the intestinal tract. It most commonly affects the distal ileum and proximal colon. 

Three major risk factors are:

  • Prematurity is the greatest risk factor
  • Formula feeding
  • Bacterial colonization of the intestine

Incidence and mortality increase with decreasing birth weight and gestational age. It usually presents within the 2nd or 3rd week of life with abdominal distension and tenderness, feed intolerance, and occult/gross blood in the stool. Systemic features include hypotension, bradycardia, lethargy, and temperature instability.

Diagnosis can be made with a plain abdominal X-ray. The important signs are :

  • Pneumatosis intestinalis- air in the bowel wall is diagnostic, and corresponds to stage IIA.
  • Portal vein gas is a sign of severe disease and corresponds to stage IIB.
  • Pneumoperitoneum indicates perforation and corresponds to stage IIIB.

Management of NEC includes supportive measures, nil per oral, nasogastric decompression, intravenous fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and inotropic support if indicated. Perforation is an absolute indication of surgery. The most effective preventive strategy is the use of human milk. questions.text: A statistician is working on a study about the hemoglobin status of children in an area. He plotted the frequency distribution as shown below.  Which of the following is most likely to be the mean, median, and mode, respectively of the same?
questions.solution:
The image given shows a negatively skewed distribution where mean < median < mode. Hence, the mean, median, and mode, in this case, must be 7, 9, and 11 respectively.

Skewed distributions are the ones that have asymmetric frequency distributions. They can be identified as positive (right) or negative (left) according to the location of the tail of the curve. In the image, the tail is located on the negative side of the graph (left side) and so it is a negatively or left-skewed distribution.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

Related Pearl: Measures in Statistics

Measures used in statistics

Definition

Examples

Measures of Location or Central Tendency

These measures summarize the data by defining the centre or the middle.

An entire distribution can be characterized by these measures which represent all the observations.

Mean, median, mode

Measures of Dispersion or Variability or Spread

These measures help in determining the extent to which data is stretched or squeezed.

Range, interquartile range, variance, standard deviation

Measures of Position

These measures give the position of specific data in relation to other data in the set.

Percentiles, quartiles, centiles,  z scores

questions.text: An intern is asked to examine the thyroid gland by Crile's method. Which of the following correctly describes this method?

choices.text: Palpate the gland with the thumb while patient swallows
The lobes are pushed to one side for palpation
Demonstrates the pressure effect of the thyroid gland on the trachea or larynx
Patient places his hands behind the occiput of his/her head.

questions.solution:
The patient is asked to swallow while palpating the gland with the thumb in Crile's method. This helps to identify mild enlargements and for detecting the presence of nodules. The below video shows Crile's method of thyroid palpation.

Other options:

Option B: In Lahey's Method, the lobes are pushed to one side for palpation. For palpating the left lobe, the examiner should push the lobe laterally with the left hand, and the lobe is palpated with the right hand as shown below.

Option C: Kocher's method is done to demonstrate the pressure effect of the thyroid gland on the trachea or larynx. Lateral compression will result in stridor.

Option D: Pizillo's method is used in short-necked and obese individuals. The thyroid is better inspected by asking the patient to place his hands behind the occiput of his/her head.

questions.text: A 78-year-old male patient presented with meningoencephalitis. Laboratory workup for Herpes Simplex is negative. An increased rate of deaths in crows in the neighborhood has been reported. You suspect an arbovirus whose life cycle is shown below. It can be classified under which of the following family?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is suggestive of West Nile encephalitis caused by the West Nile Virus belonging to the family Flaviviridae. Other important species under the genus flavivirus include:

  • Dengue virus
  • Japanese encephalitis virus
  • Yellow fever virus

West Nile Virus is a common viral febrile illness and is the most common cause of arboviral encephalitis in the United States. It is also seen in The Middle East, Europe, Africa, and Asia. In India, it is found in regions of Rajasthan to Karnataka.

The virus has a predominantly enzootic lifecycle involving birds and mosquitos, mostly belonging to the Culex species such as C. pipiens (although Aedes and Anopheles might also be rarely involved). Humans and other mammals such as horses are incidentally involved in the cycle. Very rarely, the virus may be transmitted through organ transplantation and blood transfusion. 

Clinically, the majority of the West Nile Virus infections are asymptomatic. Symptomatic patients present with fever, maculopapular rash, lymphadenopathy, myalgia, arthralgia, headache, and fatigue. The elderly, ill, and immunocompromised individuals may be affected more severely than the general population. They may develop neurological manifestations such as tremors, acute flaccid paralysis resembling polio, aseptic meningitis, and diffuse encephalitis. Very rarely, patients may develop features of transient parkinsonism. 

Note:

Arbovirus is a term used to refer to any viruses that are transmitted by arthropod vectors. There is no family or order by the name arbovirus. The word arbovirus is an acronym (Arthropod-Borne virus).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about ferroptosis?

choices.text: Triggered by low levels of reduced glutathione

questions.solution:
Ferroptosis is triggered when there are low levels of reduced glutathione. Reduced glutathione is an anti-oxidant. During oxidative stress, it gets used up and there is unchecked lipid peroxidation of the membrane. This causes ferroptosis. 

Ferroptosis is a form of cell death that is triggered because of excessive levels of intracellular iron deposition (option B), or when oxidative stress overwhelms the glutathione antioxidant system. Reactive oxygen species thus formed cause lipid peroxidation of the cell membrane. The cell membrane loses its selective permeability, and therefore cell death resembles necrosis (option D). Caspases are not involved in ferroptosis (option A). The most prominent ultrastructural feature is the loss of mitochondrial cristae and the rupture of the outer mitochondrial membrane.

questions.text: A patient presented with a non-pruritic lesion in the palm as shown in the image below. KOH mount of the epidermal scrapings showed brown, branched, closely septate hyphae and elongated budding cells. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and image are suggestive of tinea nigra, an infection caused by Exophiala werneckii. 

The infection occurs by direct inoculation through the skin. It causes deeply pigmented, macular, non-scaly patches commonly on palms. The image below shows a microscopic image of the tinea nigra, with pigmented filaments with conidia. 

First-line treatment is topical azole creams such as econazole and ketoconazole.

Option B: Malassezia furfur causes tinea versicolor.

Option C: Piedraia hortae causes black piedra.

questions.text: While observing the capnographic waveform of a patient undergoing surgery, you are surprised to notice the EtCO2 suddenly becoming zero. Which of the following is most likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
EtCO2 suddenly becoming zero is most likely to be due to a kinked ET tube, among the given options.

Capnography refers to the method of CO2 measurement as a function of time or volume. Normal capnography is shown in the image below.

Accidental extubation, circuit disconnection, and a defective CO2 analyzer would also show a sudden fall of EtCO2 to zero.

Other options:

Option A: Malignant hyperthermia would show a progressive rise in the end-tidal CO2 due to the increased metabolic rate.

Option C: Rebreathing will show the failure of CO2 to return to the baseline at the end of the expiration. The inspiratory CO2 remains above 0.

Option D: Capnographic changes in bronchospasm include:

  • Loss of verticality of phase II
  • the opening of the angle between phases 2 and 3 (α angle)
  • Increased upslope of phase III
  • No plateau before the next inspiration
  • Shark fin appearance - in severe cases

A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor

The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted.

questions.text:
Match the following chemotherapeutic agents with their adverse effects.
Drugs Adverse effects
1. Bleomycin a. Peripheral neuropathy
2. Doxorubicin b. Hand foot syndrome.
3. Vincristine c. Pulmonary fibrosis
4. Capecitabine d. Cardiotoxicity
questions.solution:
The correct match is;

Drugs Adverse effects
1. Bleomycin

c. Pulmonary fibrosis
2. Doxorubicin

d. Cardiotoxicity
3. Vincristine

a. Peripheral neuropathy
4. Capecitabine

b. Hand-foot syndrome.

Bleomycin is an anticancer antibiotic used for the treatment of squamous cell cancer and Hodgkin lymphoma. It chelates copper or iron and produces superoxide ions that damage DNA. Side effects are mucocutaneous toxicity and pulmonary fibrosis.

Doxorubicin is an anthracycline that is widely used in clinical practice as a chemotherapeutic agent. It is most commonly used as a part of regimens with other agents like cyclophosphamide, cisplatin, and 5-FU in several malignancies including: 

  • Breast cancer
  • Endometrial cancer
  • Ovarian cancer
  • Soft-tissue sarcoma
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Ewing's sarcoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • ALL
  • Multiple myeloma
  • Hodgkin's and Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma

Cardiotoxicity is a known side-effect of doxorubicin. Therefore, careful monitoring is required for doxorubicin. Specifically, doxorubicin requires dose adjustment during or after radiotherapy in order to prevent radiation toxicity.

Vincristine is a vinca alkaloid that acts during the M phase of the cell cycle. It causes microtubule disruptions, thereby preventing cellular replication. Side effects are neuropathy and SIADH.

Capecitabine is a pyrimidine analog that is classified as an antimetabolite agent. Side effects are diarrhea, hand-foot syndrome, and myelosuppression.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male was brought to the Emergency department following a road traffic accident. His radiological investigations revealed complete transection of the spinal cord below the level of medulla with intact vagus, what is the expected breathing pattern in this case?

choices.text: Regular breathing continues but depth of inspiration increases

questions.solution:
Complete transection below medulla causes cessation of spontaneous respiration irrespective of vagi status.

  • Complete transection above the pons with vagi intact would result in the continuation of regular breathing.
  • A section at the mid pontine level with vagi intact would result in the continuation of regular breathing and apneusis would result only when the vagi are cut.
  • Transection midway between pons and medulla with intact vagi causes irregular but rhythmic respiration.
  • Transection midway between pons and medulla with cut vagi causes irregular but rhythmic respiration.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents with increasing fatigue, bone pain and is found to be anemic. Physical examination reveals a hard 1-cm nodule in the prostate and the PSA level is elevated. Peripheral blood smear findings include occasional myelocytes, a few tear-drop red blood cells (RBCs)  and two nucleated RBCs per 100 white cells. Erythrocytes are normochromic and normocytic. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a patient suspected to have metastatic prostate cancer now presenting with normocytic normochromic anemia with a leukoerythroblastic picture and tear-drop-shaped RBCs on the peripheral smear, a diagnosis of myelophthisic anemia is most likely.

Myelophthisic anemia is a form of marrow failure in which space-occupying lesions replace normal bone marrow elements. The most common cause is metastatic cancer, most often carcinomas arising from the breast, lung, and prostate. Myelophthisic anemia can also be seen in the spent phase of myeloproliferative neoplasms.

Infiltration of the bone marrow leads to fibrosis and structural distortion. This disturbs the normal mechanisms by which RBCs and WBCs come out from the bone marrow into the blood. This leads to the premature release of nucleated erythroid precursors and immature granulocytic forms. This is referred to as a leukoerythroblastic picture. Moreover, dacrocytes (tear-shaped RBCs) are also seen; they are formed due to their deformation during release from the bone marrow.

Due to fibrosis and structural distortion of bone marrow, extramedullary hematopoiesis occurs in the liver and spleen, leading to hepatomegaly and splenomegaly.

The image given below shows a leukoerythroblastic blood picture with nucleated RBCs, tear-drop cells, and immature myeloid cells:

Other options:

Option A: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA) is caused due to trauma to RBCs inside the blood vessels. The hemolysis is a result of the shear forces which act on the RBCs. This occurs in prosthetic heart valves, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP), and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). These disorders lead to luminal narrowing and thrombus formation and thus cause mechanical damage to the RBCs. MAHA shows schistocytes or helmet cells on peripheral smear.

Option C: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia is caused by antibody and complement-mediated RBC destruction. The diagnosis of autoimmune hemolytic anemia requires direct and indirect Coombs test.

Option D: Aplastic anemia refers to primary bone marrow failure and consequent pancytopenia. Although aplastic anemia also presents with normocytic normochromic anemia, it will not show a leukoerythroblastic picture in the peripheral smear. Hepatomegaly and Splenomegaly are not seen in aplastic anemia.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl was admitted with a large wound on her thigh for the past 3 months. Cultures from the wound margin revealed an MRSA infection. She was given an antibiotic that binds to the subunit of the ribosome marked by the red cross and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. Identify the drug given to this patient.

MRSA- Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus
questions.solution:
The drug given in this case is Linezolid which binds to the P site of the 50s ribosomal subunit and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. It is an oxazolidinone that is active against various resistant organisms including methicillin-resistant staphylococci, vancomycin-resistant staphylococci. Linezolid is well absorbed orally and the bioavailability approaches 100%.

Linezolid and tedizolid are FDA approved for the treatment of skin and soft tissue infections caused by streptococci and staphylococcus aureus (MSSA and MRSA). Linezolid is also approved for the treatment of community-acquired pneumonia due to S. pneumoniae and nosocomial pneumonia due to S. aureus.

Adverse efffects of linezolid:

  • Myelosuppression (anemia, leukopenia, pancytopenia)
  • Thrombocytopenia (most common side effect) 
  • Serotonin syndrome if given along with serotonergic drugs due to monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibition
  • Mitochondrial toxicities like peripheral neuropathy, optic neuropathy, lactic acidosis

Clinical correlate- Intravenous and oral doses for linezolid are the same because of 100% bioavailability.

Other options:

Option A - Chloramphenicol primarily binds reversibly to the 50S ribosomal subunit. It blocks the amino acid–containing end of the aminoacyl tRNA from binding to the acceptor site on the 50S ribosomal subunit. This prevents the peptide bond formation by breaking the interaction between peptidyl transferase and its amino acid substrate. One of the most important adverse effects of chloramphenicol is grey baby syndrome.

Option C - Vancomycin is a glycopeptide. It inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding with D-alanyl-D-alanine. It is used in the treatment of MRSA, clostridium difficile, and enterococci. Redman syndrome, ototoxicity, and nephrotoxicity are the most important adverse effects.

Option D - Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside. Aminoglycoside antibiotics act by binding to the 30s ribosome and interfere with the initiation of protein synthesis. Their ability to cause misreading of DNA template and the formation of aberrant proteins that get incorporated into bacterial cell membrane makes them bactericidal agents. Their antimicrobial activity reduces in an anaerobic environment. Ototoxicity, nephrotoxicity, and neuromuscular blockade are the most important adverse effects.

questions.text: You are a pediatrician evaluating a baby in the NICU. The mother had a history of fever and painful swellings in her neck at 9 weeks gestation. At that time, she had a maculopapular rash that spread from her face to her body and resolved in 3 days. Investigation had revealed Rubella IgM was positive in the mother.  Which of the following features is the baby most likely to have?
questions.solution:
The history of maternal fever, painful neck swellings, and a rash that subsided in 3 days, coupled with the IgM rubella is indicative of rubella infection of the mother. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common congenital heart disease associated with rubella, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis (PS). PDA presents with a continuous machinery murmur. 

Heart disease in congenital rubella: PDA > PS > VSD > ASD.

Note:

  • ASD: Ejection systolic murmur
  • VSD: Pansystolic murmur
  • Mitral stenosis: Mid diastolic murmur. 

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic male patient came for a regular ophthalmic examination. He has no ocular complaints. A slit-lamp examination revealed the following finding in his right eye. It is also noted that these opacities do not settle down when the eye is immobile and moves with the vitreous during eye movements. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a diabetic, elderly male with unilateral numerous yellowish-white vitreous opacities that don’t sediment when the eye is immobile is suggestive of asteroid hyalosis.

Asteroid hyalosis is a common degenerative process in which calcium pyrophosphate particles collect within the vitreous gel. It is seen clinically as numerous tiny round yellow-white opacities of varying size and density. These move with the vitreous during eye movements but do not sediment inferiorly when the eye is immobile.

It occurs unilaterally (75%); patients are mostly asymptomatic. It is more common in elderly men. Associated with diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia.

Other options-

Option A:  Synchysis scintillans are vitreous opacities that occur as a consequence of chronic vitreous hemorrhage, often in a blind eye. They are composed of cholesterol derived from plasma cells or degraded products of erythrocytes. These vitreal opacities sediment in the lower part of the vitreous cavity due to gravity.

The below image shows Synchysis scintillans.

Option B: Muscae volitantes commonly referred to as ‘floaters’, is an ubiquitous entoptic phenomenon of fly-, cobweb- or thread-like condensations that are best seen against a pale background. It represents tiny embryological remnants in the vitreous gel. 

Image given below show floaters.

Option C: The vitreous opacities in amyloidosis are linear with footplate attachments to the retina and posterior surface of the lens and has a characteristic sheet-like (‘glass wool’) appearance.

questions.text: A patient is suspected to have had an iatrogenic injury to the pharyngeal plexus during surgery. All of the soft palate muscles would be affected by the injury except?
questions.solution:
Except for Tensor veli palatini, all the other muscles can be affected in the given scenario. All the soft palate muscles are supplied by the pharyngeal plexus, except tensor veli palatini, which is supplied by the nerve to the medial pterygoid, a branch of the mandibular nerve.

All soft palate muscles are derived from the 4th pharyngeal arch and are supplied by the vagal plexus/pharyngeal plexus, except tensor veli palatini, which is derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch and supplied by the mandibular nerve.

The pharyngeal plexus is formed by the pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and the vagus nerve with contributions from the superior cervical sympathetic ganglion. It supplies:

  • All muscles of the soft palate, except tensor veli palatini which is supplied by the mandibular nerve
  • All the muscles of the pharynx, except the stylopharyngeus which is supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Note:

  • All tongue muscles are supplied by the hypoglossal nerve except the palatoglossus (supplied by the vagus nerve through the pharyngeal plexus).
  • All the muscles of the pharynx are supplied by the pharyngeal plexus, except the stylopharyngeus (supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve) 
  • All larynx muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, except the cricothyroid (supplied by the external laryngeal nerve).

questions.text: The patient whose hands are shown in the image below is developmentally delayed with a short, stocky build. Which of the following laboratory values is consistent with this condition?
questions.solution:
Considering the given options, based on the history and the image showing a short 4th metacarpal, the most likely diagnosis is pseudohypoparathyroidism. It is characterized by hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and high PTH. 

Pseudohypoparathyroidism occurs due to mutations in GNAS gene, leading to the formation of defective Gsα protein. This means that end-organ effects of PTH are hampered in patients suffering from pseudohypoparathyroidism. Even though PTH levels are high, it is not able to perform its normal function. Hypocalcemia is seen in these patients due to insufficient calcitriol production in the proximal renal tubules and consequent impaired intestinal calcium absorption. Urinary phosphate excretion is also impaired, causing hyperphosphatemia. 

Most patients with pseudohypoparathyroidism have characteristic skeletal features. These include short stature, early-onset obesity, round face, short metacarpals, and short metatarsals. This complex of skeletal abnormalities are referred to as Albright's hereditary osteodystrophy (AHO). Treatment of pseudohypoparathyroidism consists of a high dose of calcium and activated vitamin D (calcitriol).

questions.text: A soldier underwent a left above-knee amputation after a  terrorist attack with explosives. He was brought to your department for fixing a leg prosthesis. Which level of prevention does this fall under?
questions.solution:
Strategies to reduce impairment with prostheses fall under the tertiary level of prevention. 

Tertiary prevention includes all rehabilitation measures available to reduce or limit impairments and disabilities and minimize suffering caused by any stage of the disease. This also promotes the patient's adjustment to irremediable conditions. Tertiary prevention extends the concepts of prevention by rehabilitation.

Examples include occupational and physical therapy in burn patients, and cardiac rehabilitation in post-myocardial infarction patients.

Other options:

Option B- Secondary prevention includes early disease detection, and its target is healthy-appearing individuals with subclinical forms of the disease. This is defined as the action which halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications. Screening tests and early diagnosis are the specific intervention used in the secondary level of prevention and they help to arrest the disease process.

Option C- Primary prevention is defined as an action taken prior to the onset of disease, which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur. Primary prevention is obtained by specific protective measures, as well as measures promoting general health, well-being, and the quality of life of people.

Option D- Primordial prevention consists of risk factor reduction targeted towards an entire population through a focus on social and environmental conditions. Measures taken in this level of prevention are typically promoted through laws and national policies. The main intervention in primordial prevention is by individual and mass education. Examples include discouraging harmful modes of lifestyle like smoking from early childhood, as it can lead to adult health problems.
