questions.text: A cardiologist wants to study the effect of an anti-hypertensive drug. He notes down the initial systolic blood pressure of 50 patients and then administers the drug to them. After a week of treatment, he measures the blood pressure again. What is the most appropriate statistical test to be chosen to compare the change in blood pressure?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, a paired t-test (before and after) would be used. As the effect of a drug to change the blood pressure is measured on the same sample, making it a dependent sample.

T tests are performed when experimental subjects are divided into two different groups. One group is treated with one intervention and the other group with a different intervention. 

Other options:

Option B: Unpaired t-test or a student t-test or independent t-test is used when the two groups under comparison are independent of each other.

Option C: ANOVA or analysis of variance is a test used to compare and analyse the difference between the means of more than two groups.

Option D: Chi-square Test is a method of testing the significance of the difference between two proportions. 

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Which of the following structures and their location in the middle ear is incorrectly paired?

choices.text: Canal for facial nerve - medial wall

questions.solution:
The canal for tensor tympani is located on the anterior wall, not on the roof.

The tegmen tympani forms the roof of the middle ear. It separates the tympanic cavity from the middle cranial fossa. It also extends posteriorly to form the roof of the aditus and antrum as tegmen mastoideum.

The image below shows the tegmen tympani.

The middle ear has a roof, floor, and four walls: anterior, posterior, medial & lateral.

  • Roof: Formed by tegmen tympani bone
  • Floor: Formed by a thin plate of bone
  • Anterior wall: Structures related are
    • Eustachian tube
    • Canal of tensor tympani
    • Internal carotid artery
  • Posterior wall: It has a bony projection called a pyramid. The aditus connecting the middle ear to the attic is present above the pyramid. The posterior sinus, also known as the facial recess, is a depression in the posterior wall lateral to the pyramid. It is bounded medially by the vertical part of the VII nerve, laterally by the chorda tympani, and above by the fossa incudis. Intact canal wall techniques use this for middle ear access.
  • Medial wall: It is formed by the labyrinth and it presents as a bulge called promontory. The medial wall is related to:
    • Oval window
    • round window
    • Processus cochleoriformis
    • Horizontal semicircular canal
    • Canal of the facial nerve
  • Lateral wall: It is mainly formed by the tympanic membrane and also by the bony outer attic wall called the scutum.

questions.text: Which of the following tests can be used to identify the contamination of mustard oil with argemone oil?
questions.solution:
Detection of contamination of mustard oil with argemone oil can be done by Nitric acid test.

Epidemic dropsy is caused by the toxic compound sanguinarine, which is present in argemone oil extracted from argemone seeds. It is commonly used as an adulterant in mustard oil. Epidemic dropsy results in sudden onset of swelling of lower limbs, diarrhea, and breathlessness. Some patients may develop hypersecretory glaucoma. It can lead to death due to cardiac failure. Adulteration with argemone oil can be detected by the following tests:

  • Paper chromatography (most sensitive test)
  • Nitric acid test 

Phosphatase test (Option A), standard plate count (Option B), and coliform count are used to check whether milk has been pasteurized. A positive test after pasteurization of milk shows contamination after pasteurization.

Methylene blue reduction test (Option D) is an indirect method for the detection of microorganisms in milk. The test is carried out on the milk accepted for pasteurization to check for gross contamination. It is used for grading raw milk quality prior to pasteurization.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy with asthma is having frequent exacerbations despite being on high-dose ICS and LABA. His absolute eosinophil count is found to be elevated. Which of the following is the most appropriate add-on drug?

ICS: inhaled corticosteroids

LABA: long-acting β-receptor agonists
questions.solution:
In patients on high-dose ICS and LABA with frequent acute exacerbations of asthma and elevated eosinophil count, IL-5-blocking drugs have been shown to be beneficial. In this group, mepolizumab and reslizumab are monoclonal antibodies which bind to IL-5 and benralizumab binds to IL-5 receptor.

Most patients with asthma have type 2 inflammation. TH2 type of helper T-cells are activated and they release IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13. IL-4 induces B-cell isotype switching to cause the production of IgE. IgE binds to mast cells and causes sensitivity to environmental antigens. When an antigen comes in contact with the IgE antibody, the antigen-antibody reaction causes mast cell degranulation, resulting in bronchoconstriction and edema. IL-5 is predominantly involved in recruitment of eosinophils. IL-13 causes airway hyperresponsiveness and mucus hypersecretion. 

It has now been recognized that eosinophils play a major role in the pathophysiology of asthma. They induce airway hyperresponsiveness by releasing free radicals and major basic protein, both of which can disrupt the airway epithelium. Mucus plugs, which contain significant amounts of eosinophil aggregates, accumulate in the airways and also contribute to the severity of asthma. By blocking IL-5, drugs like mepolizumab block the recruitment and functioning of eosinophils and bring about major symptomatic improvement in patients with asthma.

Other options:

Azithromycin (option A) is a macrolide antibiotic. It is used as an add-on drug in COPD because bacterial infections are one of the most important causes of acute exacerbations in COPD. Azithromycin is most effective in older patients and milder GOLD stages, and is not beneficial in patients who continue to smoke.

Roflumilast (option C) is a phosphodiesterase 4 inhibitor that is used in COPD as an add-on drug for reducing exacerbations. 

Omalizumab (option D) is a monoclonal antibody against the Fc portion of the IgE antibody. It is used in patients not adequately responding to high-dose ICS and LABA and with elevated circulating IgE and a positive skin test or radioallergosorbent test (RAST) to a perennial allergen.

questions.text:
You are an intern posted in the labor room. Which of the following parameters would you consider while calculating the APGAR score in a newborn?
  1. Respiratory rate 
  2. Pulse rate 
  3. Muscle tone
  4. Oxygen saturation
  5. Appearance
questions.solution:
The parameters to consider while calculating APGAR score in newborn babies are:

  1. Appearance
  2. Pulse rate (Heart rate)
  3. Grimace
  4. Activity(muscle tone)
  5. Respiratory effort.

The Apgar score is a systematic way of assessing the infant after birth at 1 and 5 minutes of life. It gives a maximum score of 10 which indicates the newborn is in the best possible condition.

Scores between 0-3 require immediate resuscitation. Changes in the Apgar scores denote the response of the infant to resuscitation. If the score at 5 minutes remains less than 7, the infant should be assessed again every 5 minutes for the next 20 minutes.

Causes for false positive APGAR score are:

  • Prematurity
  • Drugs like analgesics, narcotics, sedatives, magnesium sulfate
  • Acute cerebral trauma
  • Precipitous delivery
  • Airway obstruction (choanal atresia)  
  • Congenital pneumonia or sepsis
  • Hemorrhage- hypovolemia

False-negative Apgar score is seen in maternal acidosis and high fetal catecholamine levels.

questions.text: Calculate hepatic clearance of a drug given that the hepatic blood flow is 2500 mL/min and hepatic extraction ratio is 0.4.
questions.solution:
The hepatic clearance of the drug is 1000 mL/min.

Clearance of a drug by an organ is the difference between the rate of presentation of the drug to the organ and the rate of exit of the drug from the organ. It is calculated by the equation:

CLorgan = Q x (CA-CV/CA)

where,

CLorgan =Clearance of the drug by the organ

Q = Blood flow to the organ

CA = Arterial drug concentration

CV = Venous drug concentration.

The extraction ratio (E) is the fraction of the drug that is removed from the blood by the eliminating organ. CA is the concentration of the drug presented to the organ and CA-CV is the drug removed by the organ, hence,

Extraction ratio (E) = CA-CV/CA

Therefore, the clearance of the drug by the organ can be simply written as,

CLorgan = Q x E

In the question, it is given that the hepatic blood flow is 2500 mL/min and the hepatic extraction ratio is 0.4.

Substituting the values in the above equation, 

CLorgan = 2500 X 0.4

= 1000 mL/min

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, who has completed her family asks for long term contraception, as she usually forgets taking pills as per schedule. She prefers to avoid frequent visits to the hospital and is not willing for surgery. Her previous ultrasound records reveal that she has large fibroids distorting her uterine cavity. What would be the most appropriate contraception amongst the following in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
The appropriate contraception for her is Norplant.

As the patient has large fibriods distorting the uterine cavity, IUCDs are not appropriate. The patient is also non-complaint with oral pills, therefore progesterone-only pills are not suitable in her case. Since she needs long term contraception, and prefers to avoid frequent visits to the hospital, depot injections are not feasible as these injections are to be taken every 3 months, whereas implants like norplant are long term and work for 3-5 years.

Norplant I  contains six silastic capsules - has been withdrawn and replaced.

Norplant II (Jadelle) consists of two rods each containing 70 mg LNG. The daily release of hormone is 50 mcg and provides contraception for 3–5 years. Implants mainly suppress the endometrium, but it can also suppress ovulation in about 50%.

Insertion: The implants need to be generally inserted on the first day of the menstrual cycle, within 5 days of abortion, or 3 weeks after the delivery. They will need to use other forms of contraception like barrier methods until 7 days of insertion of implants. It is inserted under local anesthesia and needs removal at the end of its use.

Advantages of implants:

  • They are long-acting with good effect, therefore compliance is also good.
  • Coital-independent with no need to remember taking pills or getting regular injections.
  • Pregnancy rate—varies between 0.2 and 1.3 per 100 woman years

Disadvantages of implants:

  • Breakthrough bleeding, irregular cycles, amenorrhoea 
  • Ectopic pregnancy is seen in 1.3%
  • Local infection
  • Requires insertion and removal with minor surgical procedures
  • The implants are expensive

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient presents with jaundice, confusion, and aphasia. Peripheral smear shows the presence of schistocytes. Coagulation studies were found to be normal but platelet count is decreased. Serum haptoglobin levels are low. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this case is thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP).

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is thrombotic microangiopathy that can be inherited or spontaneously acquired. It results from a deficiency of the metalloprotease ADAMTS13, which normally cleaves multimers of vWF. Failure to cleave these multimers results in excessive platelet adhesion and aggregation. This causes platelet thrombi and fibrin deposits to form at various sites in the circulation. These thrombi result in the classic pentad of clinical features: 

  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA)
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Renal failure
  • Neurologic findings
  • Fever

The platelet thrombi narrow the vessel lumen, causing shearing stress on the red blood cells that are passing through. This results in microangiopathic hemolytic anemia. The same platelet thrombi cause microvascular occlusion and result in features like renal failure and neurological manifestations. On peripheral smear, these fragmented red cells appear as schistocytes or helmet cells, as shown in the image below:

 

MAHA is an example of intravascular hemolysis. It causes an increase in free hemoglobin in the blood, which is taken up by haptoglobin. This reduces free haptoglobin in the blood. Moreover, the activation of the coagulation cascade is not of primary importance in TTP and HUS, and hence the coagulation studies are usually normal. The mainstay of treatment of TTP is therapeutic plasma exchange.

Other causes of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia include:

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) (Most common)
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)
  • Malignant hypertension
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Disseminated cancer 

Other options:

Option A: Immune thrombocytopenic purpura occurs as a chronic disease in adults with several episodes over time, usually following infections. It presents as mucocutaneous bleeding and very low platelet counts. These patients have abnormally large platelets (megathrobocytes) in the peripheral smear, which is a sign of accelerated thrombopoiesis. Coagulation studies are normal. 

Option B: Disseminated intravascular coagulation refers to the widespread intravascular clot formation, commonly due to sepsis, trauma, and obstetric complications. These patients present with petechiae, ecchymoses, and oozing from venipuncture sites. They do not display the classic pentad seen in TTP. Schistocytes may be present on peripheral smears. Deranged clotting parameters are seen and fibrin degradation products such as D-dimers are elevated.

Option C: Hemolytic uremic syndrome is a disorder seen predominantly in children, following an episode of bloody diarrhea. Escherichia coli O157:H7 is most commonly the cause of this diarrhea. It can also present with acute renal failure, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia, but neurological manifestations are less common.

questions.text: A G2P1L1 woman with a previous history of preterm delivery presents at 32 weeks with intermittent uterine contractions. To allow for fetal lung maturity, what is the dose of betamethasone to be given?
questions.solution:
To allow for fetal lung maturity, the dose of betamethasone to be given is 12mg IM 24 hourly 2 doses.

Antenatal corticosteroids are recommended in a pregnancy less than 34 weeks to allow fetal lung maturation and to reduce the incidence of respiratory distress syndrome(RDS), intraventricular hemorrhage(IVH), and necrotizing enterocolitis(NEC). 

Betamethasone is the steroid of choice and it becomes useful if the delivery is delayed beyond 48 hours of the first dose with the effect lasting for about 18 days. Dexamethasone is another steroid that can be given in a dose of 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses IM.  

Short-term therapy with tocolytics is given in conjunction with steroids for 1-3 days to delay labour for at least 48 hours or to transfer the patient to a tertiary centre (with NICU). The drugs include terbutaline, indomethacin, nifedipine, and atosiban. Contraindications to tocolysis include chorioamnionitis, preeclampsia/eclampsia, fetal distress, pregnancy >34 weeks, active labor, and placental abruption.

Preterm labour is the onset of labour before 37 completed weeks of pregnancy (less than 259 days of gestation). It can occur in patients with a history of prior preterm birth, multiple pregnancies and genital tract infection. Evaluation of cervical anatomy is the most important step in women with a history of preterm labour to look for cervical incompetence. 

Features of preterm labour include regular uterine contractions at least once every 10 minutes, with/without pain, cervical dilatation >2 cm and effacement >80% and length of cervix <2.5 cm and funnelling of the internal os >1 cm.

The best predictors of preterm labor in a woman with a previous history of preterm birth are fetal fibronectin >50ng/ml and cervical length <2.5cm on transvaginal ultrasound.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presented with recurrent epistaxis. There is no history of trauma associated with it. He also complained of nasal obstruction and rhinorrhea. On examination, there is a firm purplish mass on the posterior nasopharynx. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

Adolescent male presenting with recurrent epistaxis, nasal obstruction, and purplish mass on the posterior nasopharynx points towards angiofibroma. The consistency of the tumor is firm but the digital palpation should never be done until at the time of operation, because of the risk of profuse bleeding.

Computed tomography (CT) scan of the head with contrast enhancement is now the investigation of choice. Anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus often called antral sign or Holman-Miller sign, is pathognomonic of angiofibroma.

Surgical excision is the treatment of choice though radiotherapy and chemotherapy monotherapy or in combination have also been used.

questions.text: A 46-year old lady is being evaluated for abnormal uterine bleeding by a dilatation and curettage procedure. The following instruments are placed on a table in the minor operating theatre. Which of the following instruments will be used in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Among the given instruments 1, 2, and 3 - Sim's uterine curette, Hegar's dilators, and Simpson's uterine sound are used for dilatation and curettage (D&C).

Instruments used in D&C:

  • Sim’s speculum: It retracts the posterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix
  • Anterior vaginal wall retractor: Retracts the anterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix.
  • Vulsellum or Allis forceps: To hold the anterior lip of the cervix
  • Uterine sound: Simpson's uterine sound is a 30 cm long angulated instrument with a handle at one end and a rounded blunt tip at the other.
    It is used to measure the length of the uterus. It can be identified by the markings used for measurement
  • Cervical dilators: 
    • Hegar's dilator is a double-ended dilator used to dilate the cervix.
    • Hawkins’ single-ended dilator 
    • Fenton’s dilator
  • Curette:
    • Sim's curette is a single-ended curette
    • Blake's curette is a double-ended curette

Other options: 

Karman's cannula: It is used for menstrual regulation. 

Leech Wilkinson's cannula and Rubin's cannula are used in hysterosalpingography.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is used for considering liver transplantation in patients with cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The Milan criteria are used to assess the suitability of patients with cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma for liver transplantation. In order to be suitable for liver transplantation, the patient should have

  • a single tumor with a diameter of ≤5 cm
  • up to 3 tumors, each with a diameter ≤3 cm
  • no extra-hepatic involvement
  • no macrovascular invasion

Other options:

Option A: The Miami criteria were developed to ensure the adequacy of resection in parathyroid surgery. It is based on the principle that the half-life of the PTH is 3-5 minutes. In a single-gland disease, once the gland is removed the PTH levels should drop to the normal range and to less than half the maximum preoperative PTH at 10 minutes.

Option B: King’s College selection criteria is used for liver transplantation in acute liver failure (paracetamol (acetaminophen) and non-paracetamol induced)

Option D: NEXUS criteria: There are five criteria included under NEXUS. If a trauma patient meets all five criteria, then no radiography is required and the cervical c-spine collar may be removed. However, if any one of the criteria is met then radiography is done to evaluate further.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus is brought with complaints of cognitive decline. His family gives a history suggestive of stepwise deterioration in his condition. On examination, the Babinski sign is found to be positive. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given patient, who is a known case of hypertension and diabetes mellitus, now presenting with stepwise deteriorating cognitive function and Babinski sign positive (suggestive of a UMN lesion, like stroke), the most likely diagnosis is vascular dementia.

Vascular dementia is the second most prevalent form of dementia, after Alzheimer disease. It includes any dementia which is primarily caused by a cerebrovascular disease or impaired cerebral blood flow. Any cause of ischemic stroke (like atheroembolism), intracerebral hemorrhage, or subarachnoid hemorrhage can cause vascular dementia if the underlying injury to the brain is severe enough. Aside from a clinical stroke, cerebral small vessel diseases such as arteriosclerosis and cerebral amyloid angiopathy can also lead to vascular dementia.

The patient will likely have a vascular risk factor (hypertension, diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia, tobacco use or atrial fibrillation), a history of prior stroke, or transient ischemic attack. There will usually be a stepwise decline in the mental state of the patient due to a series of unrecognized strokes. Executive functions (such as planning and organization) are likely to be affected more and early in the disease course.

Diagnosis is usually clinical based on the history but lesions in the brain can be visualised by an MRI. 

Treatment is mainly aimed at preventing further strokes via pharmacotherapy and supportive therapy.

This condition is in contrast to Alzheimer's disease (option B), where there's a slow progression and recent episodic memory is affected first.

Frontotemporal dementia (option A) presents with apathy, loss of social inhibition, and impulsivity. Memory is relatively preserved. It is associated with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

Dementia with Lewy bodies (option C) presents with prominent psychiatric dysfunction in the form of visual hallucinations, delusions (Capgras syndrome), and delirium. This is accompanied by Parkinsonian motor features.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to ophthalmology OPD with the complaints of diminished vision along with floaters and photopsia. The consultant on duty uses the following instrument to assess the retinal lesions. All of the following are the advantages of this instrument except  ______

choices.text: Visualization through hazy media is possible
Produces real image with 15 times higher magnification
Field of view is much larger
Depth perception of the lesion is possible

questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is an indirect ophthalmoscope, and it produces an inverted real image of 2 to 5 times magnification.

Advantages of the binocular indirect ophthalmoscope are:

The image shows the post mortem phenomenon of marbling.


Adipocere: also called corpse wax, grave wax or mortuary wax, is a wax-like organic substance formed by the anaerobic hydrolysis of fat in tissue by bacteria.

questions.text: Which of the following determines the pH of a buffer solution?
questions.solution:
Henderson–Hasselbalch equation is used for the calculation of pH of a buffer solution.

pH = pKa + log[A−]/[HA]

where, pKa is the acid dissociation constant, A- is the free acid concentration, HA is the bound acid concentration.

Other options:

Option A: Gibbs Donnan equation: In the presence of a nondiffusible­ ion, the diffusible ions distribute themselves so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal.

 

Option B: Nernst Equation determines the magnitude of equilibrium potential.

Equilibrium potential is the membrane potential at which an ion exists in equilibrium across the membrane.

The Nernst equation for Chloride ions is,

 

 

Where ,

Clo – Chloride outside the cell

Option D: The Goldman equation is used to calculate the diffusion potential when the membrane is permeable to several different ions.

Goldman-Hodgkin-Katz equation

Here,

  • P= permeability of the membrane to each ion, and
  • C= concentrations of the respective ions on the inside (i) and outside (o) of the membrane.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a fibroid uterus develops acute pain abdomen at 28 weeks of gestation. The pain is restricted to the site of the fibroid. This was associated with nausea and vomiting. She also developed a fever and her WBC count was 18000/μL. Which of the following is the appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of red degeneration of the fibroid. Red degeneration in pregnancy is managed with bed rest and analgesics.

Red degeneration is a complication of fibroids that often develops during pregnancy. It is due to the breakdown of fibroid resulting in ischemia and pain. It is an aseptic condition. Clinical features acute pain abdomen restricted to the site of the fibroid, fever, and vomiting. Investigations reveal an elevated WBC count and a raised ESR. Diagnosis can be made by ultrasound. It is usually self-limiting and can be managed with bed rest and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

Related Pearl: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

  • Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.
  • Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size
  • A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion
  • A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.
  • Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy
  • When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

questions.text: After recent floods in a region, the water bodies get grossly contaminated. How much free residual chlorine level in water sources would you recommend after such a disaster?
questions.solution:
The recommended level of free residual chlorine in water sources after floods/natural disasters is >0.5 mg/L.

After a disaster such as a flood, the water bodies are grossly contaminated with sewage and drainage. The mixing of feces in drinking water sources increases the risk of numerous microbial infections. The advisable level of residual chlorine in water bodies after a disaster is more than 0.5 mg/L, and can be as high as 1 mg/L. If the free residual chlorine level is lower than 0.5 mg/liter, the water should be disinfected again. 

Note: Under routine circumstances, the minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/L for one hour.

Related Pearl: Chlorination of Water

  • Chlorination is widely used for the large-scale purification of drinking water.
  • It is bactericidal and moderately virucidal but not sporicidal, except in high doses.
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese, and hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys some taste and odour producing components. It controls algae and slime organisms and aids in coagulation.
  • The action of chlorine:
    • Hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid are formed when chlorine is added to water. Hypochlorous acid ionizes to form hydrogen and hypochlorite ions.
    • H2O + Cl2 → HCl + HOCl
      HOCl → H + OCl
    • The disinfecting action of chlorine is predominantly due to hypochlorous acid. Hypochlorous acid is the most effective form of chlorine and it is almost 70 – 80 times more effective than hypochlorite ions.
    • Chlorine acts best in water that has a pH of around 7.
  • Principles of chlorination:
    • The water to be disinfected must be clear of turbidity as turbidity impedes efficient chlorination.
    • The chlorine demand of water is the difference between the amount of chlorine added to the water and the amount of residual chlorine remaining at the end of a specific period of contact (usually 60 minutes) at a given temperature and pH of the water. This has to be estimated before chlorination is done.
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint. It is beyond this that residual free chlorine begins to appear.
    • Contact period of free chlorine for at least one hour is required to kill bacteria and viruses.
    •  Minimum recommended concentration of free chlorine is 0.5 mg/litre for one hour. Free residual chlorine provides a margin of safety against microbial contamination that occurs in storage or transport.
    • The sum of the chlorine demand of the specific water plus free residual chlorine of 0.5 mg/litre constitutes the correct dose of chlorine to be applied.
  • Methods of chlorination:
    • Chlorine gas: It is the first choice as it is cheap, quick and efficient in action, and easy to apply. Special chlorinating equipments like Paterson’s chloronome are used for the application of chlorine gas.
    • Chloramines: These loose compounds of chlorine and ammonia give more persistent forms of residual chlorine. They have slow action and thus are not widely used.
    • Perchloron or high test hypochlorite (H.T.H.): It is a calcium compound that has 60 – 70% of available chlorine.
  • Break point chlorination:
    • The point at which the chlorine demand of water is met is called the breakpoint.
    • Free chlorine (HOCl and OCl) appears when chlorine is added beyond the breakpoint.
    • In other words, at the breakpoint, if chlorine is added, then all the combined chlorines would have been completely destroyed and free residual chlorines begin to appear.
    • This corresponding dosage to achieve the appearance of free residual chlorine is called breakpoint dosage and this method is called breakpoint chlorination.
    • It is also called controlled superchlorination
    • Superchlorination followed by dechlorination is used to disinfect highly polluted waters whose quality fluctuates greatly.
  • Orthotolidine (OT) test:
    • It is a test for chlorination and determines free and combined chlorine in water, rapidly and accurately.
    • The reagent used is analytical grade Orthotolidine dissolved in a 10% solution of hydrochloric acid.
    • When added to water that contains chlorine, it turns yellow with varying intensity. This is faster in the presence of free chlorine and slower in the presence of combined chlorine.
  • Orthotolidine - arsenite (OTA) test:
    • This is a modification of the OT test which nullifies the errors due to interfering substances like iron, nitrites, manganese, etc.
    • It determines free and combined chlorine separately.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the surgery department. Your consultant asks you to prescribe a drug for a patient complaining of heartburn. What will you prescribe?
questions.solution:
Omeprazole 20mg OD 30 mins before breakfast can be prescribed inthis patient. Heartburns are most effectively treated with proton-pump inhibitors (PPI) like pantoprazole, omeprazole, and rabeprazole. PPIs should be ideally given 30 minutes before breakfast.

PPIs are prodrugs, when ingested, get absorbed into the systemic circulation. It then diffuses into the parietal cells of the stomach and accumulates in the acidic secretory canaliculi. Acidic pH in the parietal cell canaliculi causes activation of the PPIs. The maximum proton pump (H+ K+ ATPase) activation corresponds to the peak concentration of PPI resulting in maximum efficacy.

Proton pumps are higher in number after a period of fasting. So, PPIs are usually given in the mornings before breakfast. Food hinders the absorption of PPIs and decreases their bioavailability. Therefore, PPIs are given on an empty stomach, 30 mins before taking food.

PPIs are administered orally in enteric-coated or delayed-release capsules/ granules/ pellets/ oral suspension packets to prevent its degradation by the gastric acid.

Common dosage of PPIs:

  • Pantoprazole 40 mg OD
  • Omeprazole 20-40 mg OD
  • Rabeprazole 20 mg OD 

Note: 

Vonoprazan, a potassium-competitive acid blocker, has been recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of peptic acid-related disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about this posture?

choices.text: Due to damage in the upper pons

questions.solution:
The image shows decerebrate rigidity, in which there is reticulospinal excitation resulting in hyperactivity of extensor muscles. It occurs due to damage in the upper pons and lower midbrain.

Decerebrate posturing occurs when there is complete transection of the brain stem between the superior and inferior colliculus. The inputs from the corticospinal tract, corticobulbar tract, rubrospinal tract are interrupted, and only the reticulospinal pathway remains intact. Excitatory inputs from the reticulospinal tract stimulate gamma motor neurons which in turn stimulates alpha motor neurons. This results in the contraction of the extensor muscles in the extremities. It can also be seen following uncal herniation.

Injury to the cerebral cortex and upper mid brain produces decorticate rigidity. Here the rubrospinal and the reticulospinal tracts are intact. The excitation of the rubrospinal tract causes flexion of the upper limbs while the excitation of the reticulospinal tract causes extension of the lower extremities.

questions.text: A female patient underwent trucut biopsy of a breast lump. The following test was done on the specimen to confirm HER2 neu mutation. Identify the technique used.
questions.solution:
The technique shown in the image is fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH).

FISH is a technique where cells are stained with fluorescent stains. It uses DNA probes that recognize sequences specific to particular chromosomal regions. FISH can be performed on prenatal samples, peripheral blood cells, touch preparations from cancer biopsies, and even fixed archival tissue sections. Uses include :

  • Numerical abnormalities of chromosomes e.g., aneuploidy.
  • Subtle microdeletions and rearrangements.
  • Complex translocations that are not demonstrable by routine karyotyping.
  • Gene amplification of HER2 in breast cancer or NMYC amplification in neuroblastomas.

Other options:

Option B: Karyotyping is the process by which chromosomes are isolated, stained, and examined to find chromosomal anomalies. It is used in prenatal diagnosis, investigation of repeat pregnancy loss, investigation of children and adults suspected of having a chromosomal disorder, and subtyping of lymphomas and leukemias for the purpose of exact diagnosis, giving a prognosis, and treatment.

The karyotyping of a normal human male is given below.

Option C: Immunohistochemistry (IHC) is a technique that uses the specific binding between an antibody and antigen to detect and localize specific antigens in cells and tissue. It is commonly used to assist in the classification of neoplasms, determination of a metastatic tumor’s site of origin, and detection of tiny foci of tumor cells. It is increasingly used to provide predictive and prognostic information in testing for HER2 amplification in breast cancer.

 

Option D : Microarray technique is used to detect multiple (thousands) genetic abnormalities on a single slide.

Microarray slide is given below. 

Related Pearl: Fluorescent In Situ Hybridisation (FISH)

It is a simple technique for the detection of specific genetic information on a morphologically intact tissue using fluorescent probes.

The fluorescent probes are added to cells usually arrested in the metaphase stage of cell division (when every chromosome is separately).

Types of FISH:

1) Chromosomal painting: Each chromosome is identified by using a different colour of the fluorescent probe, however, each chromosome does not have a unique colour. Since the fluorescent dyes are limited.

2) Multicolour FISH: 23 distinct fluorescent colours made by mixing 5 fluorophores. Thus each chromosome is identified by a unique colour. It is also known as spectral karyotyping (SKY). It offers various advantages such as

  • Detects structural and numeric abnormalities in chromosomes.
  • Detects gene amplification and subtle microdeletions
  • Maps a newly isolated gene to its correct chromosomal loci

However, this process requires prior knowledge of the genes and chromosomes.

3) Interphase FISH: It is a rapid procedure of FISH, wherein growing cells are not needed. It is used in prenatal diagnosis and in tumour diagnosis.

The image shown is of a Multicolor FISH also known as Spectral karyotyping with a unique colour to each chromosome pair.

questions.text: A patient was admitted for acute diarrhea and vomiting 2 days ago. The doctor on duty assessed that he has recovered from dehydration and ordered discontinuation of the IV fluids. The ward nurse by mistake administered 0.45% NaCl to this patient. Which of the following Darrow-Yannet diagrams represents the fluid shift in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient did not need IV fluids but was administered hypotonic saline (0.45% NaCl). The Darrow Yannet diagram in image 3 represents the fluid shift in case of hypotonic fluid administration as seen in this patient. 

Darrow Yannet diagrams depict the change in plasma osmolarity and plasma volume in various conditions. The dotted line in the diagram is the change after either the addition or removal of fluid.

Hypotonic saline leads to the decreased osmolarity of the ECF. This causes a shift of fluid from the ECF to the ICF until the osmolarity of both compartments becomes equal. The fluid influx leads to a decrease in the osmolarity of the ICF as well. The net result is the decreased osmolarity and increased volume of both the compartments.

Other options:

Image 1- Normal ECF and ICF balance.

Image 2- The addition of isotonic saline to ECF does not cause any fluid shift from the ICF. Hence, it only leads to an increase in ECF volume without causing any change in osmolarity.

Image 4- The addition of hypertonic saline to the ECF pulls the fluid from the ICF into the ECF. This results in a decreased volume of ICF, increased volume of ECF, and increased osmolarity in both ECF and ICF.

questions.text: All of the following statements about pleomorphic adenoma are true except

choices.text: Parotid gland is the most commonly affected gland
It is also known as mixed tumor

questions.solution:
Malignant change occurs in 3-5% of cases of pleomorphic adenoma and is referred to as carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma.

Symptoms suggestive of malignant transformation:

  • Rapid growth
  • Pain
  • Paraesthesias
  • Enlarged cervical lymph nodes
  • Restriction of jaw movements
  • Facial weakness
  • Skin invasion
  • Fixation of mastoid tip.

Pleomorphic adenoma:

  • Most common benign salivary gland tumor.
  • Most commonly affected gland is parotid gland. Superficial lobe is most commonly affected.
  • Also called mixed tumor since it has both epithelial and mesenchymal components.

Clinical features:

  • Most commonly affects females around 40 years of age.
  • Most common presenting feature – painless swelling below, in front and behind the ear.
  • Involvement of deep lobe leads to dumbbell tumor – swelling in both neck and oral cavity.

Diagnosis:

  • FNAC – investigation of choice. 
  • Open biopsy contraindicated due to chances of injury to facial nerve.

Treatment:

  • Surgery is the mainstay of treatment - Superficial parotidectomy (Patey's operation).

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme is common for both gluconeogenesis and glycolysis?
questions.solution:
Enolase is common for both gluconeogenesis and glycolysis. Enolase catalyzes the conversion of 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate, which is a reversible step.

Enzymes catalyzing irreversible steps in gluconeogenesis and glycolysis cannot be the common enzyme for both.

The irreversible steps of glycolysis are catalyzed by the following enzymes:

  • Hexokinase
  • Phosphofructokinase
  • Pyruvate kinase

The irreversible steps of gluconeogenesis are catalyzed by the following enzymes:

  • Pyruvate carboxylase
  • Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase
  • Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase
  • Glucose-6-phosphatase

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden-onset loose stools, vomiting, and muscular cramps. Stools were colorless with a rice water appearance and had an inoffensive sweetish odor.  Stool microscopy showed characteristic fish in stream appearance of the organism with darting motility. What is the likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with rice water stools is suggestive of cholera, caused by Vibrio cholerae.

Vibrio cholerae is a comma-shaped, gram-negative bacillus with darting motility. It has a single polar flagellum. It causes cholera, an acute diarrheal disease. It is marked by painless, profuse, watery diarrhea with flecks of mucus (rice water stools) associated with effortless vomiting. Pulmonary edema and arrhythmias are some of the complications. 

Infection is acquired by ingestion of contaminated food and water. The organisms produce an enterotoxin known as cholera toxin (CT). It has 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B subunit (binding units) fixes to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on jejunal epithelial cells. The A subunit dissociates into the A2 fragment, which attaches the A1 fragment to the B subunit. This results in prolonged accumulation of cAMP, which causes an outpouring of large amounts of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen. Ultimately, it results in profuse watery diarrhea. 

The characteristic darting mobility and its hindrance by antiserum can be used for rapid microscopic diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following are secreted by the beta cells of the pancreas along with insulin?
questions.solution:
Amylin is secreted by the beta cells of the pancreas along with insulin. Amylin slows the rate of glucose entering the bloodstream, making it a short-term regulator of blood glucose levels.

Cells of the endocrine pancreas are divided into: 

Cell type

Secretion

A (alpha)

Glucagon

B (beta)

Insulin and amylin

D (delta)

Somatostatin

The close interrelations among these cells allow direct control of the secretion of some of the hormones by the other hormones. For example:

  • Insulin inhibits glucagon secretion,
  • Amylin inhibits glucagon secretion, and
  • Somatostatin inhibits the secretion of insulin and glucagon.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida with a history of gestational diabetes mellitus is in active labor. After delivery of the head, a positive turtle sign was noticed. Which of the following maneuvres cannot be used for the management of this case?
questions.solution:
The case of gestational diabetes with a positive turtle sign is suggestive of shoulder dystocia. Pinard's maneuver is not used in the management of shoulder dystocia.

Pinard's maneuver is done for frank breech extraction. The middle and the index fingers are placed in the popliteal fossa to abduct and flex the fetal leg. The fetal ankle is then grasped and breech extraction is accomplished as shown below.

Mc Robert's maneuver, Gaskin's maneuver, Rubin's maneuver are all used in the management of shoulder dystocia. 

Shoulder dystocia occurs when either the anterior or rarely the posterior fetal shoulder gets impacted on the maternal symphysis or on the sacral promontory respectively, following the delivery of the head. A positive turtle sign may be seen which refers to a definite recoil of the head back against the perineum. The incidence of shoulder dystocia increases with increasing birth weight, which can be due to maternal obesity, gestational diabetes, post-term pregnancy, and multiparity. Management of labor in case of shoulder dystocia:

  • Gentle downward traction of the fetal head with suprapubic pressure 
  • Mc.Roberts maneuver: Flexing the legs on the abdomen with concurrent suprapubic pressure. This causes straightening of the sacrum relative to the lumbar vertebrae, rotation of the symphysis pubis toward the maternal head, and a decrease in the angle of pelvic inclination. This tends to free the impacted anterior shoulder. It is shown in the image below.

Woods corkscrew maneuver: Pro­gressive rotation of the posterior shoulder 180 degrees in a cork­ screw fashion releases the impacted anterior shoulder. It is shown in the image below.

  • Rubin's maneuver: The fetal shoulders are rocked from side to side by applying force to the maternal abdomen. If this is not successful, the pelvic hand pushes the most easily accessible fetal shoulder toward the anterior surface of the chest, producing a smaller bisacromial diameter. This permits displacement of the anterior shoulder from behind the symphysis.
  • Gaskin maneuver: (All fours maneuver): The parturient rolls onto her knees and hands and downward traction against the head and neck is applied, with the attempt to free the posterior shoulder.
  • Zavanelli maneuver: It involves the replacement of the fetal head into the pelvis followed by cesarean delivery.
  • Symphysiotomy: The intervening symphyseal carti­lage and ligamentous supports are cut to widen the symphysis pubis.
  • Cleidotomy: Fracture of the clavicle using an instrument to free the anterior shoulder. Usually done for a dead fetus. (shown below)

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: Identify the structure marked by the red arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the musculocutaneous nerve. 

The structure can be identified as the musculocutaneous nerve as it pierces the coracobrachialis muscle in its course and also supplies the biceps brachii. The root value of the musculocutaneous nerve is C5, C6, C7.

The musculocutaneous nerve supplies all the muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm, which include coracobrachialis, brachialis, and biceps brachii muscles.

Related Pearl: Brachial Plexus

Brachial Plexus

  • C5 to T1
  • Roots (from spinal cord) > Trunks (in the neck)> Divisions (passing behind clavicle) > Cords and Branches (in the axilla).
  • Covered by prevertebral fascia extension called "axillary sheath"

Trunks:

  • Upper trunk: C5 and C6
  • Middle trunk: C7.
  • Lower trunk: C8 and T1

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented with fatigue, growth retardation, obstructive uropathy, and neurologic abnormalities. A peripheral blood smear revealed megaloblastic anemia. The condition did not improve with the administration of vitamin B12 and folate but responded to treatment with uridine. Which of the following is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is orotic aciduria and the enzyme responsible for the condition is uridine-5'-monophosphate synthase deficiency.

Orotic aciduria is a rare inborn error of metabolism in children. A defect in the enzyme uridine-5′-monophosphate (UMP) synthase in the pyrimidine synthesis pathway results in the failure of conversion of orotic acid to uridine. As a result, there is increased excretion of orotic acid in urine.

The condition is characterized by hypochromic megaloblastic anemia that is unresponsive to vitamin B12 and folic acid, growth retardation, and neurologic abnormalities.

Treatment includes, the administration of uridine (100–200 mg/kg per day), which corrects anemia, reduces orotic acid excretion, and improves the other sequelae of the disorder.

Other options:

Option A: Dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase is responsible for the degradation of uracil and thymine. Deficiency of the enzyme causes excessive urinary excretion of uracil and thymine. Clinical features are nonspecific cerebral dysfunction with convulsive disorders, motor retardation, and mental retardation. There is no specific treatment available.

Option B: Pyrimidine 5′- nucleotidase catalyzes the removal of the phosphate group from pyrimidine ribonucleoside monophosphates (cytidine-5′-monophosphate or UMP). Deficiency of this enzyme causes hemolytic anemia with prominent basophilic stippling of erythrocytes. The accumulation of pyrimidines or cytidine diphosphate choline induces hemolysis. Acquired pyrimidine 5′-nucleotidase deficiency is seen in lead poisoning and in thalassemia.

Option C: Deficiency of xanthine oxidase causes hereditary xanthinuria. This results in all purine in the urine occurring in the form of hypoxanthine and xanthine. Patients may have kidney stones composed of xanthine.
