questions.text: A 62-year-old female with history of ovarian carcinoma in the mother achieved menopause with smooth transition. And she is on hormone replacement therapy. She developed abdominal pain and on examination the right adnexal mass was palpable, non tender. On USG examination she has a 3 X 3 cm smooth cyst in her ovary. Which is the next step

choices.text: Reassure and advice regular follow up once in 6 months
Confirm USG findings by ordering CT scan
Do an exploratory laparoscopy to visualise the nature of cyst
Do CA-125 levels, if normal advise regular check up

questions.solution:
Doing a CA-125 level measurement is the next best step according to the latest RCOG guidelines for Post-menopausal Ovarian cyst.

Initial steps in management include the following:

  • Estimate CA – 125 level
  • USG
  • Calculating Risk of Malignancy index
    • RMI = U x  M  x  Ca-125
    • U – Ultrasound score
    • M – Menopausal status
    • Ca 125 – Serum levels

Option B : CT scan is not recommended in initial evaluation.

Option C : Laparotomy/laparoscopy only indicated if size > 5 cm or RMI > 200.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient complains of fatigue and difficulty in climbing the stairs for the past 2 years. Her symptoms are absent in the morning but worsen as the day progresses. On examination, the following finding is noted. Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Incremental response on repetitive nerve stimulation
Anterior mediastinal mass on CT chest

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of proximal muscle weakness (weakness while climbing the stairs) which worsens as the day progresses, and the image showing bilateral ptosis, are suggestive of myasthenia gravis (MG). MG shows a decremental response on repetitive nerve stimulation. 

MG is an autoimmune disorder most commonly caused by antibodies against the acetylcholine receptor (AChR). These antibodies cause damage to the postsynaptic muscle membrane and increased endocytosis of the AChR. This autoimmune response against the AChR seems to be mediated by the thymus. The myoid (muscle-like) cells present in the thymus express AChRs on their surface and are postulated to provide the autoantigen which triggers this autoimmune reaction. There is some thymic abnormality in most patients with MG. Thymic hyperplasia is seen in 65% of the patients, and thymomas are seen in 10% of the patients. Thymoma is seen as an enlargement of the thymus in the anterior mediastinum on CT chest (option D).

MG usually occurs in females in their 20s and 30s.  Patients usually present with weakness and fatiguability of the muscles, which increases on repeated use or late in the day and improves on rest. The cranial muscles, particularly the eyelids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course of MG. Diplopia and ptosis are common initial complaints. When MG becomes generalized, the proximal muscles of the limbs are affected first. Despite the muscle weakness, the deep tendon reflexes remain normal. 

The tests which are used to confirm the diagnosis of MG include:

  • Anti-AChR antibody immunoassay (option A)
  • Recurrent nerve stimulation test: MG shows a decremental response, while Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) shows an incremental response (option B)
  • Block and jitter response on single-fiber EMG
  • Positive edrophonium test: improvement of ptosis on the administration of anticholinesterase such as edrophonium
  • Positive ice-pack test (option D): improvement of ptosis on the application of ice-pack on the affected eye

Patients with generalized MG are started on anticholinesterase drugs such as pyridostigmine. They are evaluated for associated thymic abnormalities using a CT chest. Indications for thymectomy in a patient diagnosed with MG include: 

  • Presence of thymoma
  • Generalized MG with anti-AChR antibodies, even if no thymoma is seen on CT chest

Following thymectomy, immunosuppressive drugs are started based on the clinical status of the patient. 

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the triad of ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm?
questions.solution:
Hematuria is not included in the triad of ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysms.

A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm is a surgical emergency. The rupture can be anterior or posterior. In the anterior rupture, there may be bleeding into the peritoneal cavity whereas, in the posterior rupture, a retroperitoneal hematoma may be present. 

The features include severe abdominal or back pain, hypotension, and pulsatile abdominal mass.

Management is as follows

  • Oxygen, IV replacement, and central line
  • Maintenance of systolic blood pressure but not beyond 100.
  • Catheterization
  • Cross-matching blood
  • Shifting the patient rapidly to the operating room.

questions.text: A chronic smoker was on nicotine replacement therapy and clonidine tablets for smoking de-addiction. He stopped taking clonidine tablets and now presents with a headache. Which of the following drugs is best suited for the treatment of his condition?
questions.solution:
The mechanism that causes headaches in this patient, who stopped taking clonidine, is rebound hypertension. Amongst the given drugs, phentolamine is best suited for the control of hypertension due to clonidine withdrawal.

Phentolamine is a non-selective alpha antagonist that opposes the alpha receptor-mediated vasoconstriction of sympathomimetics. It is also used in:

  • Clonidine withdrawal
  • Short-term control of hypertension in pheochromocytoma
  • Limiting the duration of soft tissue anesthesia.

Clonidine is an alpha-2 receptor agonist and a centrally-acting antihypertensive agent. It treats high blood pressure by stimulating presynaptic α2 receptors in the vasomotor center in the brainstem. This binding has a sympatholytic effect, by suppressing the release of norepinephrine and other sympathomimetics.

Abrupt withdrawal after long-term therapy can result in rebound hypertension, restlessness, and sympathetic overactivity. Dry mouth and sedation are the major side effects of clonidine. It can also cause impotency and constipation. Phentolamine is used for the control of hypertension due to clonidine withdrawal.

Other options:

Option A: Phenoxybenzamine is also a non-selective alpha antagonist but has irreversible action. Side effects are postural hypotension, palpitation, nasal blockage, miosis, and inhibition of ejaculation. It is used primarily in pheochromocytoma, and occasionally in peripheral vascular disease.

Option B: Prazosin is a selective alpha-1 blocker. It is a potent antihyper­tensive but is not used as a first-line drug because fluid retention and tolerance gradually develop with monotherapy. Another major problem with prazosin is marked postural hypotension and syncope following the first dose (first dose effect).

Option D: Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that decreases heart rate, force of contraction, and cardiac output. It reduces blood pressure on prolonged administration. It has mem­brane stabilizing (Na+ channel blocking) properties and is a potent local anesthetic. It also reduces the secretion of aqueous humor.

questions.text: A 2nd-year MBBS student was able to identify the given capsulated bacterium by different techniques during the Microbiology practicals. Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding the following image?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a swollen capsule, which is demonstrated by the Quellung reaction, and India ink stain is not used in the Quellung reaction

Quellung reaction also called as Neufeld reaction is used to identify capsulated organisms such as pneumococci, Neisseria meningitis, Haemophilus influenza, etc.

When a suspension of a capsulated bacterium is mixed with its specific anticapsular serum and examined under the microscope, the capsule becomes very prominent and appears 'swollen' due to an increase in its refractivity. This capsule swelling or Quellung reaction was described by Neufeld.

Note:

India ink preparation is used to detect the presence of capsulated yeast (eg: Cryptococcus neoformans ).

The following image shows Cryptococcus neoformans stained using India ink. A thick capsule is seen around the yeast cell.

questions.text: An individual consumed a balanced meal containing carbohydrates, proteins, and fats. Immediately after the meal, assuming that carbohydrates were mainly metabolized, what will the respiratory quotient be?
questions.solution:
The respiratory quotient (RQ) immediately after a balanced meal in which carbohydrates in the food were mainly metabolized will be 1.0.

The respiratory quotient refers to the ratio of carbon dioxide production to oxygen utilization. It estimates the relative utilization of different foods by the body.

Carbohydrates- When carbohydrates are metabolized, one molecule of carbon dioxide is released when one molecule of oxygen is utilized. Therefore, the RQ of carbohydrates is 1. This occurs immediately after a meal when the majority of carbohydrates are metabolized.

Fats- When fats are oxidized, with every 100 molecules of oxygen utilized, an average of 70 carbon dioxide molecules are released. The RQ of fat is therefore 0.70. This happens because when oxygen reacts with fats, a large amount of it combines with hydrogen from the fats, forming water instead of carbon dioxide. Around 8-10 hours after a meal the carbohydrate stores are depleted and fats are utilized. The RQ becomes 0.70. In severe untreated diabetes, carbohydrates are not utilized as they require insulin. Hence, the RQ remains near that of fat metabolism, i.e., 0.70.

Proteins- When proteins are oxidized, with every 100 molecules of oxygen utilized, an average of 80 carbon dioxide molecules are released. Therefore, the RQ of proteins is 0.8. Protein utilization is better estimated by measuring nitrogen excretion. The average protein contains about 16% nitrogen. During the metabolism of the protein, most of the nitrogen is excreted as urea, uric acid, creatinine, and other nitrogen products in the urine and around 10% is excreted in the feces. The utilization of proteins mainly occurs during starvation, when the carbohydrate and the fat stores have been depleted.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient presents with epigastric pain and anorexia. Urea breath test is positive for the patient. Endoscopy shows thickening of the stomach wall. A biopsy is taken and is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with anorexia and epigastric pain with a positive urea breath test (indicating H. pylori infection) and the slide showing lymphoepithelial lesions suggest a diagnosis of gastric MALToma. 

Extranodal marginal B-cell lymphomas usually arise at the sites of chronic inflammation. Mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) is not present in the normal stomach but can be induced, typically as a result of chronic gastritis. H. pylori infection is the most common inducing factor of MALT and is often found in association with MALTomas. The presenting complaints are similar to adenocarcinoma and include abdominal pain, dyspepsia, and anorexia.

Histologically, MALTomas show dense lymphocytic infiltrate in the lamina propria. The neoplastic lymphocytes infiltrate gastric glands to create lymphoepithelial lesions. MALTomas express B-cell markers like CD19 and CD20, but not CD5 or CD10. 25% of the cases are positive for CD43. Eradication of H. pylori with antibiotics has shown to be an effective therapy for MALToma. Surgical resection has no role in the treatment unless there has been some complication like perforation or uncontrollable bleeding.

Other options:

Option A: Adenocarcinoma is the most common malignancy of the stomach. The intestinal-type of adenocarcinoma forms bulky masses. They are composed of columnar cells which form gland-like structures in a desmoplastic stroma, as shown in the image below.

 

The diffusely infiltrative type of gastric adenocarcinoma can be recognized by the presence of signet ring cells and no gland formation as shown below. Signet ring cells have a large, central vacuole filled with mucin, and the nucleus is seen as a thin crescent rim at the periphery.

 

Option B: Autoimmune gastritis is characterized by damage to oxyntic cells within the body and the fundus of the stomach. The inflammatory infiltrate is predominantly composed of lymphocytes, macrophages, and plasma cells. In contrast to H. pylori-associated gastritis where the inflammation is limited to lamina propria, the inflammation in autoimmune gastritis goes deeper and is centered on the gastric glands. 

Option D: Gastrointestinal tumor (GIST) is a mesenchymal tumor of the abdomen. Most GISTs have a gain of function mutation in KIT. The microscopic appearance of GIST consists of thin elongated cells (spindle cell type) as shown in the image below, or plumper, epithelial-appearing cells (epithelioid type). Most commonly an admixture of the two is seen.

questions.text:
The ionic currents involved in the action potential of the ventricular cardiac muscle are given below. Arrange them in the correct sequence.
  1. Opening of calcium channels and closure of fast potassium channels
  2. Closure of fast sodium channels and opening of fast potassium channels
  3. Opening of slow potassium channels and closure of calcium channels
  4. Opening of fast sodium channels
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of steps in the action potential of the ventricular muscle is as depicted in option A ( 4, 2, 1, 3).

The sequence of different phases of action potential in the ventricle, with the ionic currents involved, is as follows:

  • Phase 0→ Depolarisation
    • Due to the opening of fast voltage-gated sodium channels
  • Phase 1→ Initial repolarization
    • Closure of fast sodium channels and opening of fast potassium channels
  • Phase 2→ Plateau phase
    • Opening of calcium channels and closure of fast potassium channels
  • Phase 3→ Late rapid repolarization 
    • Opening of slow potassium channels and closure of calcium channels

Phase 3 is followed by phase 4, which corresponds to a return to resting membrane potential.

questions.text: The use of barium sulfate as a contrast agent is contraindicated in:
questions.solution:
Tracheoesophageal fistula is a contraindication for the use of barium sulfate as a contrast agent. An isotonic, non-ionic iodinated contrast agent can be used instead.

Barium sulfate is not absorbed as it passes through the gastrointestinal tract. However when the integrity of the gut wall is compromised (perforation) or when there is an abnormal communication between the esophagus and trachea, it can overflow and leak into the lungs, mediastinum, intraperitoneal cavity, and tissue around the rectum and causing widespread granuloma formation and anaphylactic reactions. 

Contraindications to Barium

  1. Esophageal perforation
  2. Perforation peritonitis
  3. Tracheoesophageal fistula

Iohexol is the contrast medium used for the diagnostic workup for a suspected case of esophageal perforation instead of barium contrast to prevent barium-related inflammation of the mediastinum.

Note: Although Gastrograffin (water-soluble) was used previously as an alternative to barium contrast, it has a high chance of causing aspiration pneumonitis and pulmonary edema consequently. Hence, it is not preferred nowadays.

questions.text: Match the gross structure with its histology.
questions.solution:
The given histological image is of transitional epithelium with a star-shaped appearance, which is a feature of the ureter. In the gross image provided, the structure labelled as 1 is the ureter, specifically the left ureter. 

The other structures marked are:

2: Inferior mesenteric artery

3: Descending colon 

4: Femoral cutaneous nerve 

Histology of ureter:

It has 3 layers- the innermost mucous membrane, the middle smooth muscle layer and the outer connective tissue layer.

The innermost mucous membrane is made of transitional epithelium. It is 4-5 cell layers thick with an underlying lamina propria. The mucosa is thrown into longitudinal folds which gives the lumen a star-shaped appearance. These folds vanish when the ureter is distended. 

The middle smooth muscle layer consists of an upper 2/3rd of inner longitudinal and outer circular fibres and a lower 1/3rd- of extra outer longitudinal muscle layer. The muscle coat has 2 layers in the upper 2/3rd and 3 layers in the lower 1/3rd, which may not be distinctly differentiated from each other. 

The outer connective tissue layer, also called the tunica adventitia contains blood vessels, nerves, lymphatics and fat cells. 

Ureters are narrow muscular tubes that begin from the renal pelvis and extend up to the urinary bladder. They are about 25cm long, and 3mm thick with 5 constrictions along their length. They are constricted at the pelvic-ureteric junction, the brim of the lesser pelvis, the crossing of the ureter by ductus deferens or broad ligament of the uterus, during their oblique passage through the bladder wall and at the opening in the lateral angle of the trigone.

questions.text: A patient suffering from pneumonia was put on mechanical ventilation. You plan to do an arterial blood gas analysis of the patient to monitor his status. Which of the following will you use to coat the syringe prior to taking the blood sample?
questions.solution:
For blood collection for an ABG, a syringe coated with heparin should be used. Heparin prevents clotting by inhibiting thrombin in the coagulation cascade.

An arterial puncture is indicated when an arterial blood sample is required. The concentration of various gases in the arterial blood is the same at all the sites of the body. An ABG is indicated when there is an acute dysfunction in the exchange of gases in the lungs. It is also used for monitoring the severity and progression of a documented disease that can affect the gas exchange or acid-base balance. Arterial puncture is contraindicated if the arterial pulse is not palpable. For a planned radial artery puncture, Allen test should be done to ensure that there is adequate collateral circulation from the ulnar artery. If the Allen test is negative (that is, there is no collateral circulation), radial artery puncture should not be attempted. One of the common complications is thrombosis of the punctured artery leading to distal ischemia and gangrene. It is more likely to occur if there is pre-existing atherosclerotic disease in the artery.

Related Pearl: Anticoagulants in Vacutainers and their Uses

questions.text: A patient presented to the casualty with the following finding. The discharge from the affected site was positive for Nagler's reaction. Which of the following is not true regarding the tests used for detecting the causative organisms?

choices.text: Shows stormy fermentation on litmus milk test
Shows target hemolysis on blood agar
Elek’s gel precipitation test is positive

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of gas gangrene caused by Clostridium perfringens. Elek’s gel precipitation test is an immunodiffusion test used to check the toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheriae, not Clostridium perfringens.

Gas gangrene is caused most often by Clostridium perfringens species. Microscopically it is a gram-positive bacteria without spores (sporulates only outside the human body). Naegler's test is a quick test to show the presence of Clostridium. Sample collection and transport are to be done in Robertson's cooked meat medium.

It is an anaerobe and grows well on Blood agar showing target hemolysis (Option B). A narrow zone of complete hemolysis due to θ-toxin and a wider zone of incomplete hemolysis due to α-toxin results in the development of target hemolysis on blood agar by C. perfringens.

In the reverse CAMP test (Option C), C.perfringens is streaked over the center of the plate and Streptococcus agalactiae is streaked at right angles to it. A positive reverse CAMP test shows the presence of an arrow-shaped zone of enhanced hemolysis pointing towards C.perfringens. α-toxin produced by C.perfringens interacts with the CAMP factor and produces synergistic hemolysis. 

In the litmus milk test fermentation of lactose by Clostridium leads to the formation of acid which coagulates the casein in litmus milk. The clotted milk is disrupted due to vigorous gas production and this characteristic finding is obtained that is called stormy fermentation.

Nagler's test is a quick test to show the presence of Clostridium. The α-toxin of C. perfringens has lecithinase activity. When C. perfringens is grown on a media containing egg yolk with the α-antitoxin spread on one half of the plate, colonies on the other half without the antitoxin will be surrounded by a zone of opacity. There will be no opacity around the colonies on the half of the plate with the antitoxin due to the specific neutralization of α-toxin. This is known as Nagler's reaction.

questions.text: A  post-cataract surgery patient who had the surgery 3 months back presents with complaints of blurring of vision for the past 2 weeks. On fundoscopy, there is a honeycomb appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a post-cataract surgery patient presenting with a blurring of vision and a honeycomb appearance on fundoscopy is suggestive of cystoid macular edema (CME).

Common causes of CME include previous cataract surgery, uveitis, central retinal vein occlusions, diabetic retinopathy, retinitis pigmentosa, retinopathy of prematurity, and topical prostaglandins. Cystoid macular edema in post-cataract surgery patients is termed as Irvine-Gass syndrome. 

In CME, optical coherence tomography (OCT) shows loss of foveal depression, intraretinal cystoid spaces, and retinal thickening. CME occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier. Due to retinal vessel leak fluid or exudate comes out and forms cystic space in the central retina. Mostly it gets accumulated in the outer plexiform (Henle's layer) and inner nuclear layers of the retina. 

On fundoscopy, the multiple cystoid oval spaces in CME appear as a  honeycomb appearance. In Fundus fluorescein angiography fluid accumulation in the outer plexiform, layer shows a characteristic flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance) as shown below:

Topical antiprostaglandins and steroids are used in the management of CME. 

Other options:

Option B- Macular hole is the partial or full-thickness hole in the neurosensory retina. An OCT image of a full-thickness macular hole is shown below:

Option C- Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of the neuroretina in the macular region with or without retinal pigment epithelium detachment.

Due to the altered permeability of the choroidal vascular system, there is an increase in the tissue hydrostatic pressure in the choroid. This causes a breach in the outer blood-retinal barrier. Leakage of fluid across this area causes detachment of the neurosensory retina. An OCT of central serous retinopathy showing neurosensory retinal detachment from the retinal pigment epithelium is given below:

Option D- Posterior capsular opacification, otherwise known as after cataract/secondary cataract, is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery. It occurs due to the proliferation of lens epithelial cells that have been left out inside the capsular bag after cataract surgery. 

They can present in different patterns such as:

  • Elschnig's pearls: present as vacuolated (pearl-type) grape-like clusters of swollen cells 
  • Soemmering's ring: present as a white annular proliferation that is formed at the periphery of the capsular bag.
  • Fibrosis type: present as fibroblastic metaplasia of the epithelial cells 

A posterior capsulotomy (creating a hole in the posterior capsule) using an Nd: YAG laser is the mainstay of treatment. It is indicated when the patient is symptomatic. 

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man presented with burning pain in his lower extremities along with staggering gait and sleep disturbances. Which of the following vitamins is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is burning feet syndrome. Vitamin B5-pantothenic acid is responsible for this condition.

Burning foot syndrome presents as burning and lightning pain in the lower extremities, staggering gait due to impaired coordination, and sleep disturbances. It was first seen in prisoners during the second world war. Other features of pantothenic acid deficiency include GI disturbances, paraesthesia, muscle cramps, and ataxia. Burning feet syndrome or nutritional melalgia was first seen in prisoners during the second world war.

Pantothenic acid contains beta-alanine. Beta-alanine is seen in Pantothenic acid (vitamin B5), Coenzyme A, carnosine, anserine, and acyl carrier protein.

Other options:

Option A: Vitamin B6 status can be assessed by assaying erythrocyte transaminase which is activated by pyridoxal phosphate. Deficiency may present with seizures, mental status changes, normocytic anemia, a nonspecific pruritic rash, cheilitis, glossitis, and depression. Excess vitamin B6 causes sensory neuropathy.  It occurs at intakes above 2 g/day

Option B: Deficiency of riboflavin is characterized by cheilosis, desquamation, inflammation of the tongue, seborrheic dermatitis, corneal vascularization, anemia, and personality changes. Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

Option D: The most important function of vitamin E (Tocopherol) is its chain-breaking antioxidant role. In vitamin E deficiency, there is no prevention of lipid peroxidation caused due to free radicals. As a result of this, the erythrocyte membranes are rendered abnormally fragile leading to hemolytic anemia. It can lead to ataxia, difficulty with upward gaze, hyporeflexia, and profuse muscle weakness.

questions.text: A patient with chronic angina was prescribed a new drug, ranolazine. This drug acts by which of the following mechanism?

choices.text: Inhibit funny currents in SA node

questions.solution:
Ranolazine acts by late sodium current inhibition in the heart. It is used in the prophylaxis of angina.

Late sodium current (INa) facilitates the entry of calcium via the sodium-calcium exchanger. Inhibition of INa, therefore, reduces the intracellular calcium concentration which in turn reduces the diastolic tension and cardiac contractility.

At higher doses, it may also modify the fatty acid oxidation (pFOX inhibitor), which improves the efficiency of cardiac oxygen utilisation but whether this actually occurs at therapeutic doses is still being studied. It also has mild beta-blocking activity.

Ranolazine is the second-line FDA-approved drug for heart failure. Side effects of ranolazine include dizziness, headache, and postural hypotension.

Other options:

Option A: Ivabradine selectively blocks the funny current (If) channel involved in the generation of automaticity in the SA node. It reduces heart rate and thereby oxygen demand. It does not have any effect on cardiac contractility. It is an FDA-approved drug for the treatment of heart failure. It is also used for treating stable angina.

Option C: Fasudil acts by inhibiting smooth muscle Rho kinase and reduces coronary vasospasm.

Option D: Nicorandil acts as an agonist at ATP-sensitive potassium (KATP) channels i.e. potassium channel opener. It decreases afterload and preload of the heart by its vasodilatory properties at both arterioles and venules. It is used for the treatment of stable angina.

Note: Trimetazidine is a pFOX inhibitor that partially inhibits fatty acid oxidation in the myocardium. Thereby, it decreases the oxygen requirement. It is also used as an anti-anginal agent.

Related Pearl: Anti-anginal drugs

Anti-anginal drugs can be divided into the following categories:

  • Nitrates - dilates veins > arteries, reduces preload
  • Calcium channel blockers - blocks L-type calcium channels
    • Dihydropyridines - amlodipine, nifedipine
    • Non-dihydropyridines - verapamil, diltiazem
  • Beta-blockers - decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand
  • Other drugs: 
    • Ranolazine - late Na+ channel blocker
    • Ivabradine - inhibit funny currents in SA node
    • Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist
    • Trimetazidine - pFOX inhibitor
    • Fasudil - rho-kinase inhibitor

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with complaints of a runny nose and multiple bouts of sneezing. He has had such symptoms on and off since childhood and his symptoms worsen in the spring and when he goes out of the house. He is given a drug that has the action of leukotriene receptor antagonism for his condition. Which among the following drugs is the drug given to the patient?
questions.solution:
Zafirlukast and montelukast are leukotriene receptor antagonists. 

The leukotrienes are proinflammatory mediators produced from arachidonic acid via the 5-lipoxygenase (5-LO) pathway. These drugs are competitive antagonists of the cys LT1 receptor and hence decrease bronchoconstriction, airway mucus secretion, increased vascular permeability, and recruitment of eosinophil.

This patient with symptoms of runny nose and multiple bouts of sneezing along with worsening of his symptoms in spring and outside environment strongly suggests allergic rhinitis as the diagnosis.

Uses: 

Montelukast and Zafirlukast are indicated for the treatment of allergic rhinitis. Antileukotrienes are useful in preventing exercise-induced asthma. They act mainly by inhibiting bronchoconstriction.

In some patients, anti leukotriene agents are effective as monotherapy in the treatment of mild to moderate persistent asthma, although the mean efficacy of anti leukotriene agents is lower than that of inhaled glucocorticoids (IGCs). Thus, IGCs are preferred first-line controller agents, and anti leukotriene agents are considered alternatives, particularly in patients who have difficulty with adherence or inhaler technique.

Adverse effects:

  • Zileuton, montelukast, and zafirlukast are all associated with rare cases of hepatic dysfunction. Hence, liver function tests should be monitored during the course of their therapy.
  • Churg-Strauss syndrome consisting of vasculitis with eosinophilia is associated with the use of montelukast and zafirlukast. 

Other options:

Option A- Ketotifen is a mast cell stabilizer used for the management of bronchial asthma and allergic disorders such as atopic dermatitis, allergic rhinitis/conjunctivitis, and chronic urticaria. Oral ketotifen possesses both anti-mediator and mast cell-stabilizing properties.

Option B- Cromolyn sodium is a mast cell stabilizer. It inhibits the release of mediators of inflammation, including histamine and leukotrienes, from the mast cells that are induced by reactive antigens that result in allergic symptoms and bronchoconstriction.

Option D- Zileuton is a 5-lipoxygenase inhibitor and helps to reduce inflammation, edema, mucus secretion, and bronchoconstriction in the airways.

questions.text: A surgical resident got his skin cut with a knife while he was operating on a patient diagnosed with hepatitis B infection. His anti-HBs levels were 45 mlU/ml. What will you do next?

choices.text: Give hepatitis B hyperimmune globulin and start hepatitis B vaccination

questions.solution:
In this scenario, since the anti-HBs antibodies titer in the resident is more than 10 mIU/ml, he would not need any further prophylaxis.

  • If the healthcare worker is vaccinated- Measure the anti-HBs antibody titers in him. If the levels are more than 10 mIU/ml, no further prophylaxis is required.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of tuberculosis presents with dyspnea on exertion. On examination, it is noted that the JVP rises during inspiration. A chest radiograph of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a history of tuberculosis now presenting with positive Kussmaul's sign and pericardial calcification seen on the chest radiograph suggests a diagnosis of constrictive pericarditis. 

Constrictive pericarditis is a chronic type of pericarditis that results when there is healing of acute fibrinous pericarditis or absorption of chronic pericardial effusion. While the most common cause in developing countries is tuberculosis, in developed countries, it occurs following viral pericarditis, cardiac surgery, mediastinal irradiation, or as a manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis and SLE. The main abnormality that occurs in constrictive pericarditis is the inability of the ventricles to fill because of the rigid and thickened pericardium. Unlike tamponade, this restriction is not uniform through the diastole. Ventricular filling is normal early in the diastole but stops suddenly when the elastic limit of the pericardium is reached. Y-descent on the JVP curve is prominent in constrictive pericarditis because it represents the rapid early filling of the ventricles. A sudden stop in ventricular filling and subsequent rising pressure is seen as a square root sign in the JVP curve.

The patient presents with exertional dyspnea and orthopnea. There may be a paradoxical rise in venous pressure during inspiration (Kussmaul's sign). Apart from constrictive pericarditis, Kussmaul's sign can be positive in tricuspid stenosis, restrictive cardiomyopathy, right heart failure, and pulmonary embolism. The ECG often shows low-voltage QRS complexes and diffuse flattening of T-waves. A chest radiograph may show pericardial calcification, especially in tuberculous pericarditis.

questions.text: A study shows a weak inverse correlation between vitamin intake and cancer. What is the probable correlation coefficient (r) in this study?
questions.solution:
A weakly inverse or negative correlation means r is negative and closer to 0, hence r= -0.2 is the most appropriate option.

The correlation coefficient (r) helps us find out whether there is a significant association or not between two variables. r tends to lie between - 1.0 and + 1.0.

  • If r is near + 1, it indicates a strong positive association i.e., when one variable increases the other variable also increases. (Option A)
  • A value near - 1 indicates a strong negative association i.e. when one variable increases the other decreases. (Option D)
  • If r = 0, it indicates there is no association between x and y.

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient was diagnosed to have pulmonary arterial hypertension. There was a sustained reduction in mean pulmonary artery pressure with no change in the cardiac output when inhaled NO was administered to the patient. Which of the following drugs is indicated for treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Since this patient has a positive vasoreactivity test using inhaled NO, a calcium channel blocker such as nifedipine is used as the first-line drug for the management of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).

Patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (group 1) should undergo vasoreactivity testing. This is done to find out if the patient belongs to the small subset (10-20%) of patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension who will respond to calcium channel blockers (CCBs). Vasoreacticity testing is not indicated in other forms of PAH like that associated with connective tissue diseases and congenital heart diseases.

Vasoreactivity testing involves the administration of inhaled nitric oxide, IV epoprostenol, IV adenosine, or inhaled iloprost. The test is considered positive if the mean pulmonary arterial pressure (mPAP) decreases by at least 10 mmHg and to a final value ≤ 40 mmHg, without a decrease in cardiac output. In patients who have a positive vasoreactivity test, calcium channel blockers are indicated for first-line treatment. These include sustained-release nifedipine, amlodipine or diltiazem. For patients with negative vasoreactivity test, other classes of drugs are used. These include prostanoids like epoprostenol, endothelin antagonists like bosentan and ambrisentan, phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors such as sildenafil, and soluble guanylyl cyclase stimulators like riociguat.

questions.text: In a patient with pneumonia, which of the following auscultatory findings is most likely to be heard over the affected lobe of the lung?
questions.solution:
In a patient with pneumonia, bronchial breath sounds are most likely to be heard over the affected lobe of the lung. This is because the affected lobe is airless due to consolidation, which transmits the sounds of large airways more effectively.

Normal breath sounds are termed as vesicular breath sounds. They are of rustling or breezy quality. Normal lung tissue makes the breath sounds quieter by selectively filtering out the higher frequencies. The duration of the inspiratory phase is longer than the expiratory phase. There is no pause between inspiration and expiration.

Bronchial breath sounds are rather harsh in quality. They are normally heard anteriorly over the manubrium and posteriorly between the C7 and T3 vertebrae. Bronchial breath sounds contain higher frequency components because the filtering function of the normal lung parenchyma is lost, as occurs in consolidation. The expiratory phase is longer than the inspiratory phase. There is a distinct pause between inspiration and expiration due to the absent alveolar phase.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought with a high fever and noisy breathing, cough, and cold for the past few days. An X-ray was performed and is given below. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: It can develop secondary to infection in adenoids
It presents as a midline bulge
Tracheostomy maybe required in some cases

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of high fever, noisy breathing, cough, cold, soft tissue swelling, and the widening of prevertebral shadow on the lateral view of the neck X-ray in a 2-year-old child suggests a likely diagnosis of acute retropharyngeal abscess. It presents as a bulge on one side of the midline and not as a midline bulge, due to the raphe that divides the retropharyngeal space.

An acute retropharyngeal abscess usually occurs in children below 3 years of age due to the infections of adenoids(Option A) or tonsils causing suppuration in the retropharyngeal lymph nodes which leads to the formation of an abscess. Since the retropharyngeal lymph nodes disappear after this age, an adult retropharyngeal abscess is rare and usually secondary to trauma. 

The clinical features of a retropharyngeal abscess include dysphagia, dyspnea, stridor, croupy cough, torticollis(Option D) (extended stiff neck), and swelling on one side of the midline of the posterior pharyngeal wall. The extent of the abscess can be visualized on a contrast-enhanced CT scan. 

Treatment is usually by incision and drainage of the abscess and antibiotics but tracheostomy(Option C) may be required in cases of large abscess causing obstruction to the airway or leading to laryngeal edema. 

The image below shows a retropharyngeal abscess seen on the lateral view of the neck.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden onset neurological deficits. On examination, he is found to have a loss of pain and temperature sensations over the left side of the face and right side of the body. He also has dysphagia with a deviation of the uvula to the right. Which blood vessel is most likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of this patient are suggestive of lateral medullary syndrome due to the involvement of a left-sided artery. Hence, the blood vessel most likely to be affected in this patient is the left vertebral artery.

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, occurs most commonly due to the occlusion of the ipsilateral vertebral artery. Posterior inferior cerebellar artery occlusion is responsible for the remaining cases.

The structures affected in lateral medullary syndrome include:

  • Tract and nucleus of V cranial nerve: impaired sensation over the ipsilateral half of the face
  • IX and X cranial nerves: ipsilateral paralysis of the palate (dysphagia), vocal cord (hoarseness), diminished gag reflex
  • Nucleus of Tractus Solitarius: ipsilateral loss of taste
  • Vestibular nucleus: nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
  • Spinocerebellar tract: ipsilateral ataxia
  • Descending sympathetic tract: ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome
  • Lateral spinothalamic tract: impaired pain and temperature sensation over the contralateral half of the body

questions.text: A new drug has been introduced into the market which has proven to be able to completely cure a chronic non-communicable disease. Which of the following changes can be seen in the prevalence and incidence of the disease once the drug is effectively used in the population?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the new drug was found to completely cure a chronic non-communicable disease, hence the duration of the disease is decreased thereby decreasing the prevalence. There is no change in the incidence of the disease.

Incidence refers to the number of new cases in a defined population in a specified period of time. Prevalence refers to the number of old and new cases at a given point of time or over a period of time in a given population.

Prevalence depends on two factors, the incidence, and duration of illness. If the population is stable and incidence and duration are unchanging, the relationship between incidence and prevalence can be expressed as:

P = I X D

(I = Incidence and D = Mean duration)

This equation shows longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence. If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of the disease decreases. If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence due to the increased duration of the disease.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presented with multiple swellings on the neck and a few discharging sinuses. The histopathological examination of the swellings was as shown below. Which of the following cells does not play a role in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the slide showing granulomatous inflammation with central caseous necrosis are suggestive of tuberculosis of cervical lymph nodes. Neutrophils are associated with acute inflammation and are not involved in the pathogenesis of tuberculosis.

Once Mycobacterium tuberculosis enters the macrophage, it inhibits the formation of the phagolysosome. This allows it to replicate unchecked. M. tuberculosis recruits a host protein coronin to block the fusion of phagosome and lysosome. Th1 response to M. tuberculosis is mounted about three weeks following the infection. The antigen-presenting cells (APCs) present mycobacterial antigens to the T-cells in the lymph nodes and release IL-12 and IL-18 to cause the differentiation of T-cells into Th1 cells (option B).

Th1 cells produce IFN-γ. IFN-γ is the critical step in the body's defense against M. tuberculosis. It acts by activating macrophages (option C), causing maturation of phagolysosome, and inducing nitric oxide synthase enzyme to form more reactive nitrogen species. It also mobilizes anti-bacterial compounds like defensins and stimulates autophagy.

Th1 response leads to the formation of a granuloma and caseous necrosis. Macrophages that are activated by the action of IFN-γ differentiate into epithelioid histiocytes (option D). These are the cells that actually aggregate to form a granuloma. Some epithelioid cells may also fuse to form a giant cell.

questions.text: While assessing a case of chronic alcoholism, CAGE criteria are used. Which of the following is correct regarding the criteria?

choices.text: It is used as a screening for alcohol problem
It is used to assess the severity of alcohol dependence
Score of 1 or more strongly suggests significant dependence

questions.solution:
The CAGE questionnaire is a 4 question screening for alcohol problems.

  • C - Have you ever felt you ought to cut down on your drinking?
  • A - Have people annoyed you by criticising your drinking?
  • G - Have you ever felt guilty or bad about your drinking?
  • E - Have you ever had a drink first thing in the morning to steady your nerves or get rid of a hangover (eye-opener)?

One 'yes' response raises suspicion of an alcohol use problem, and more than one is a strong indication of abuse or dependence. A score of 1 or more warrants follow-up. A score of 2 or more strongly suggests significant alcohol problems.

Note: The Severity of Alcohol Dependence Questionnaire (SADQ) was developed to assess the severity of alcohol dependence.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presented with a history of lymph node enlargement in his neck and axillae for the past 3 weeks. Investigations revealed mild anemia with leukocytosis of 40,000/mm3. The peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). CLL is a tumor of mature B cells and the most common leukemia in adults.

Patients with CLL present with nonspecific symptoms like easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia. Generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are present in about 50-60% of cases. There is also increased susceptibility to infections due to disruption of immune processes.

The peripheral smear, as shown in the image below, typically shows small round lymphocytes with condensed chromatin and scant cytoplasm (indicated by arrows). Some of these cells get disrupted while preparing the smear; these cells are called smudge cells (indicated by arrowheads).

 

Microscopy of the lymph nodes shows diffuse effacement of the architecture by small lymphocytes. Some larger, activated lymphocytes are also present. They often gather in loose aggregates, referred to as proliferation centers. They contain mitotically active cells. When present, such proliferation centers are pathognomonic for CLL.

Other options:

Option A: Acute lymphoblastic lymphoma (ALL) is a tumor of immature B or T cells and the most common leukemia in children. The peripheral blood smear shows lymphoblasts with condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, and scant agranular cytoplasm.

Option C: Multiple myeloma is a neoplasm of plasma cells. It is also typically associated with punched-out bony lesions, hypercalcemia, and renal failure. Bone marrow aspirate shows plasma cells with multiple nuclei and prominent nucleoli. Serum protein electrophoresis shows a spike of M protein (monoclonal immunoglobulin).

Option D: Waldenström macroglobulinemia is a hyperviscosity syndrome caused due to excess amounts of monoclonal IgM secreted by plasma cells. It is a type of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma, with bone marrow aspirate showing small lymphocytes with variable degrees of plasma differentiation.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with short stature and bilateral genu valgus. Laboratory investigations show reduced serum phosphate and phosphaturia. The detailed pedigree of her family is given below. Which of the following is the inheritance pattern of this disease?
questions.solution:
The given pedigree is suggestive of an X-linked dominant pattern of inheritance. The disorder in question is likely to be X-lined hypophosphatemic rickets.

Points in favor of an X -inked dominant inheritance in the given pedigree include:

  • Females are affected more than males.
  • Affected female transmits the disease to half her sons and daughters.
  • Affected male transmits the disease to all his daughters and none of his sons.

The following flowchart helps in making out the pattern of inheritance from a given pedigree chart.

X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets (XLH) occurs because of a defect in the PHEX gene. Since the PHEX gene is responsible for inactivating FGF-23, there is an increased FGF-23 in XLH. Increased FGF-23 inhibits phosphate reabsorption in the proximal tubule of the kidney and causes phosphaturia. It also inhibits 1-α-hydroxylase, leading to decreased production of activated vitamin D.

Patients with XLH present with clinical features suggestive of rickets such as short stature and genu valgus, genu varum or windswept deformity. The patients have high renal excretion of phosphate, hypophosphatemia, and increased ALP. The treatment in these patients consists of oral phosphorous and calcitriol administration.

questions.text: All of the following are used to monitor systemic perfusion in shock except?
questions.solution:
Base deficit, lactate, and mixed venous oxygen saturation are used to monitor systemic perfusion in patients with shock. Tissue oxygen electrode, as the name implies, is used to monitor organ perfusion in muscles and the brain.

The goal of treatment in shock resuscitation is to restore cellular and organ perfusion and therefore, monitoring of organ perfusion should guide the management of shock. The best clinical measure of organ perfusion and best monitor of the adequacy of shock therapy is urine output. However, this is an hourly measure and does not give a minute ­to­ minute view of the shocked state. The level of consciousness is another clinical marker of cerebral perfusion, but brain perfusion is maintained until the very late stages of shock. It is a poor marker of the adequacy of resuscitation. 

Investigation monitors that can be used for systemic perfusion are base deficit, lactate, and mixed venous oxygen saturation. The degree of lactic acidosis is sensitive for both diagnosis of shock and monitoring the response to therapy. It is measured by serum lactate level and/or the base deficit. A base deficit of more than 6 mmol/L indicates much higher morbidity and mortality likelihood than in those with no metabolic acidosis. 

The percentage saturation of oxygen returning to the heart from the body reflects the oxygen delivery and extraction by the tissues. Samples may be drawn from a long central line placed in the right atrium or lines in the superior vena cava. Mixed venous oxygen saturation levels below 50% indicate inadequate oxygen delivery and increased oxygen extraction by the cells which is consistent with hypovolaemic or cardiogenic shock. High mixed venous saturations (>70%) can be seen in sepsis and other forms of distributive shock.

Specific investigational monitors of organ perfusion are as follows:

  • Muscle and brain: Near-infrared spectroscopy and tissue oxygen electrode
  • Gut: Sublingual capnometry, gut mucosal pH, and laser Doppler flowmetry

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy complains of pain in the left hip and knee. An X-ray of his left hip was obtained and is given below. Which of the following type does this condition belong to as per the Salter-Harris classification?
questions.solution:
The given history of hip pain in a 13-year-old male and X-ray showing Trethowan's sign point to a diagnosis of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE). Slipped capital femoral epiphysis(SCFE) is classified as type 1 according to the Salter-Harris classification.

Type 1 is described as a transverse fracture through the hypertrophic or calcified zone of the plate. Even if the fracture is quite alarmingly displaced, the growing zone of the physis is usually not injured and growth disturbance is uncommon.

The Klein line is a line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck which normally intersects the epiphysis. In SCFE, Klein's line does not intersect the epiphysis and passes superior to it. This is known as Trethowan's sign. Trethowan's sign is seen in this x-ray and thus the diagnosis is slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE). Multiple endocrine disorders are often associated with SCFE, like hypothyroidism, osteodystrophy of chronic renal failure, and excessive growth hormone. 

SCFE occurs during a period of rapid growth, usually during the age of 10-15 years. Risk factors include Obesity, hypothyroidism, growth hormone excess, and chronic renal failure are all-important associations of SCFE.

Clinical features:

  • Pain in the thigh, groin, or knee.
  • On examination, the affected limb is shortened and externally rotated.
  • There is a limitation in abduction, flexion, and internal rotation on the affected side.
  • Flexion of the hip might lead to obligate external rotation and abduction - positive Drehmann’s sign.
  • Patients may have an antalgic or Trendelenburg gait.

Investigations:

  • Trethowan's sign is seen in the X-ray.
  • MRI is the investigation of choice.

Treatment consists of in-situ pinning of the epiphysis to the femoral neck.

Related Pearl: Types of Salter–Harris fractures- Mnemonic

There are nine types of Salter-Harris fractures. Among these, types I to V are more common.

The mnemonic "SALTER" can be used to help remember the first five types.

TYPE  MNEMONIC DESCRIPTION
Type I S = Slip/straight across Transverse fracture through the growth plate
Type II A = Away The fracture lies away from the joint. A fracture through the growth plate and the metaphysis, sparing the epiphysis
Type III L = Lower The fracture is below the physis in the epiphysis.
Type IV TE = Through Everything  A fracture through all three elements of the bone, the growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis
Type V R = Rammed (crushed)  A compression fracture of the growth plate

Rarer types VI to IX have been added subsequently.

  • Type VI - Injury to the perichondral structures
  • Type VII - Isolated injury to the epiphyseal plate
  • Type VIII - Isolated injury to the metaphysis, with a potential injury related to endochondral ossification
  • Type IX - Injury to the periosteum that may interfere with membranous growth

questions.text: Which of the following organism confirms the recent fecal pollution of water?
questions.solution:
The presence of fecal streptococci is confirmatory evidence of recent fecal contamination of water.

Streptococci are highly resistant to drying and may be valuable for routine control testing after laying new mains or repairs in distribution systems or for detecting pollution by surface run-off to ground or surface waters.

Note: Streptococci, E. coli, and clostridium perfringens are biological indicators of fecal pollution of water.

Related Pearl: WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

WHO Guidelines for Drinking Water Quality, 2017

I) Physical parameters:

  Guideline values Comments
Turbidity Ideally, no visible turbidity but permissible standard is < 1.0 NTU (nephelometric turbidity units) for household drinking water. 

It describes the cloudiness of water.

  • >4 NTU – cloudiness visible to naked eye.
  • <4 NTU – measured only by instruments. 
Color Ideally, no visible color but permissible standard is <15 TCU (true color units).  >15 TCU is detectable by the naked eye. 

Taste, odor and temperature

 No health based guideline values It may be indicative of contamination and pollution. High water temperature may enhance growth of microorganisms and influence taste, odor and color.

 

II) Chemical parameters:

  Guideline values
Ammonia

No health based guideline value.

Natural levels in surface and ground water is 0.2 mg/l. Anaerobic groundwater may have up to 3 mg/l.
Aluminium up to 0.9 mg/l
Arsenic

up to 0.01 mg/l

Levels in natural water range from 1 to 2 µg/l.
Chloride

250 mg/l, as above this a detectable taste appears.

Maximum permissible level is 600 mg/l. Sodium thiosulphate can be used to dechlorinate drinking water or tap water.
Copper

up to 2 mg/l.

Excess copper in water can have gastrointestinal effects.
Fluoride

up to 1.5 mg/l. Above this, there is risk of dental and skeletal fluorosis.

Artificial fluoridation range is 0.5 to 1.0 mg/l.
Hydrogen sulphide

Taste and odor threshold is between 0.05 and 0.1 mg/litre.

A rotten egg smell of water indicates hydrogen sulphide.
Nitrates 50 mg/l as nitrate ion, to prevent methaemoglobinaemia and thyroid effects
Nitrites 3 mg/l as nitrite ion, to prevent methemoglobinemia in bottle-fed infants and general population.
pH Acceptable pH is in the range of 6.5 – 8.5.
Lead

up to 0.01 mg/l

The concentration of lead must be kept as low as possible. It is the most undesirable metal in drinking water.
Mercury

0.006 mg/l for inorganic mercury

It is nephrotoxic
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH)

Benzo(a)pyrene up to 0.0007 mg/l

They are to be kept in traces as they are carcinogenic/mutagenic
Sodium Above 200 mg/l may give an unacceptable taste.
Total Dissolved Solids (TDS)

Less than 600 mg/l is generally considered palatable.

TDS consists of inorganic salts and small amounts of organic matter dissolved in water. Water is completely unpalatable above 1200mg/l.

 

III) Biological indicators:

  • Total coliform bacteria:
    • They are the primary bacterial indicators for drinking water.
    • Total coliforms are good indicators of water disinfection because they are abundant in the human intestine and are foreign to potable water.
    • E. coli is considered the best indicator of fecal contamination of water when resources for supplementary microbiological examination are limited.
    • Guidelines state that coliforms must not be detectable in 100ml of sample water. 
    • Multiple tubes method:
      • This is a test of bacteriological surveillance of drinking water for coliforms and thereby fecal contamination.
      • This test is based on the most probable number (MPN) of coliform organisms.
      • Acid and gas production from fermentation due to coliforms are observed for in multiple tubes and a presumptive coliform count is arrived at.
      • Confirmation of E. coli can be done by testing for indole formation at 44-45 degrees Celsius or by another test called Eijkman test.
    • Faecal streptococci: Their presence in water indicates recent contamination with feces and are regarded as specific indicators of human faecal pollution.
    • Clostridium perfringens: They are spore-forming organisms that are resistant to many disinfection methods. They are used as an indicator of protozoa in water and also of remote/intermittent fecal contamination. Their spores are also indicators of the effectiveness of filtration processes.
    • Viruses like enteric viruses can also be used as indicators of the disinfection process.
    • Heterotrophic plate counts measure a wide range of heterotrophic organisms including bacteria and fungi.
    • Coliphages and Bacteroides fragilis phages are evidence of fecal contamination of water. 

IV) Radiological aspects:

  • The proposed guidelines for gross alpha activity is 0.5 Bq/litre and for gross beta activity, it is 1.0 Bq/litre of drinking water.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is brought with complaints of generalized swelling of the body. Urinary examination revealed nephrotic range proteinuria. A biopsy of the kidney was taken which showed normal glomeruli on light microscopy and no deposits on immunofluorescence. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?

GBM: glomerular basement membrane

choices.text: Principal lesion involves the parietal epithelial cells
Lesions are reversible after steroid therapy

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 4-year-old child presenting with nephrotic syndrome with normal renal biopsy on light microscopy and no deposits on immunofluorescence is suggestive of minimal change disease (MCD). Principle lesion in MCD is in the visceral epithelial cells (not parietal epithelial cells), in the form of diffuse effacement of foot processes.

MCD is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. The main pathophysiology of MCD involves damage to visceral epithelial cells (podocytopathy) which leads to loss of glomerular polyanions. This defect in the charge barrier allows negatively charged albumin to be filtered in the glomerulus and lost in the urine.

The glomeruli in MCD on light microscopy appear normal. On electron microscopy, the principal lesion is found to be in the visceral epithelial cells in the form of diffuse effacement of foot processes. The foot processes are reduced to a rim of cytoplasm with loss of intervening slit diaphragms — hence termed as the fusion of foot processes also.

Option A - There's no GBM abnormality in electron microscopy, only the diffuse effacement of foot processes of visceral epithelial cells.
Option C - The proximal tubular cells are filled with lipids and proteins, reflecting the tubular absorption of the lipoproteins which have been filtered by the glomeruli.
Option D - The visceral epithelial changes are reversible after corticosteroid treatment

questions.text:
ABG analysis of a patient reveals the findings given below. Which of the following is the most likely metabolic abnormality in this patient?

Blood pH: 7.50

PaCO2: 36 mmHg

HCO3-: 30 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of metabolic alkalosis and respiratory alkalosis.

Since both the pH and bicarbonate are increased it is a case of metabolic alkalosis. Also, in the case of metabolic alkalosis, respiratory compensation includes a rise in PaCO2. But in this case, it is less than expected, which suggests concomitant respiratory alkalosis.

Finding the primary abnormality

pH = 7.50 Normal = (7.35 – 7.45) Increased
paCO2 = 36 Normal = (35 – 45) Normal
HCO3- = 30 Normal = (22 – 28) Increased

These values clearly suggest metabolic alkalosis.

Calculating the compensation

In metabolic alkalosis, the predicted PaCO2 after compensation should be [HCO3-] + 15.

So PaCO2 level after compensation should be [30] + [15] = 45 mmHg. However, PaCO2 levels are 36 mmHg, which is far lower than the expected value. This indicates that there is a component of respiratory alkalosis in this patient as well.

questions.text: An alcoholic male patient diagnosed with hollow viscus perforation is taken up for laparotomy. A 2cm sized perforation is seen in the stomach. How can this patient be managed?
questions.solution:
This patient can be managed by a Graham patch repair.

Perforations less than 1 cm can be closed primarily (Option A) and buttressed with omentum. Larger perforations and ulcers with fibrotic edges that cannot be approximated can be managed by an omental patch repair. A tongue of omentum is brought up to cover the ulcer defect and secured with a series of interrupted sutures as shown in the image below.

It may be difficult to seal perforations larger than 3 cm. Such defects may be sealed with omentum or jejunal serosa from a Roux-en-Y type limb. 

Other options:

Billroth I and II are gastrectomy-based procedures where the gastric antrum is removed, hence reducing the acid. In Billroth I gastrectomy, the lower half of the stomach is removed, and the cut stomach is anastomosed to the first part of the duodenum. In Billroth II, two-thirds of the stomach is removed, the duodenal stump is closed and the stomach is anastomosed to the jejunum.

questions.text: A middle-aged-man presents with progressive sensorineural hearing loss, imbalance, and tinnitus. Which of the following features rules out Meniere’s disease and is diagnostic of acoustic neuroma?
questions.solution:
Rollover phenomenon is diagnostic of acoustic neuroma. It is a feature of retro-cochlear/neural lesions wherein the speech discrimination steadily increases with intensity but suddenly drops significantly beyond a particular intensity of sound.

Meniere’s disease is an important differential for acoustic neuroma as the patients suffer from similar symptoms. Meniere’s is a cochlear pathology and acoustic neuroma is retrocochlear.

Option A - Stapedial reflex is present in cochlear lesions (Meniere’s) and absent in retrocochlear lesion (acoustic neuroma)

Option B - Recruitment phenomenon is the abnormal growth in loudness in the affected ear, seen in cochlear pathologies. 

Option C - SISI (short increment sensitivity score) is a test of intensity discrimination which is very high in cochlear pathologies but low in retro-cochlear.

Related Pearl: Speech audiometry

Consists of two components:

  • Speech reception threshold: The minimum intensity at which 50% of the words are repeated correctly by the patient.
  • Speech discrimination score: The patient’s ability to understand speech.
    • Percentage of phonetically balanced words delivered 30dB above SRT which are identified correctly.
    • In normal persons and those with conductive hearing loss, a high score of 90–100% can be obtained.
    • It is reduced in cochlear lesions, very poor and out of proportion to hearing loss in retrocochlear hearing loss, and worst in cortical deafness.

Roll-over phenomenon:

  • Feature of retrocochlear hearing loss.
  • When speech intensity is increased above a particular level, SDS falls instead of maintaining a plateau as in cochlear deafness.

Uses:

  • To differentiate organic from non-organic hearing loss.
  • To differentiate cochlear from retrocochlear lesions.
  • To find the intensity at which discrimination score is the best which is useful for fitting a hearing aid.

questions.text: Which of the following composition of alkaline solution (per 280ml of water) is used in atrophic rhinitis to remove the crusts?

choices.text: Soda bicarbonate 2 part, Sodium biborate 1 part, Calcium chloride 2 parts
Soda bicarbonate 1 part, Sodium biborate 1 part, Sodium chloride 2 parts
Calcium bicarbonate 1 part, Sodium biborate 2 part, Sodium chloride 2 parts
Magnesium bicarbonate 1 part, Sodium biborate 2 part, Potassium chloride 2 parts

questions.solution:
The composition of alkaline solution is Soda bicarbonate 1 part, Sodium biborate 1 part, Sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water.

It is used to irrigate the nasal cavities. It loosens the crusts and helps in its removal.

Other treatment options:

  • 25% glucose in glycerine
  • Estradiol spray
  • Submucosal placental extract
  • Local antibiotics
  • Potassium iodide
  • Systemic use of streptomycin

questions.text: A 30-year-old army major is relieved from duty in January and returns home. He lives a normal life until Diwali when the sound of firecrackers startles him and he gets flashbacks of his time at war. Since then, he fears possible attacks on his home. He avoids seeing friends from the Army unit as they remind him of war. He is subsequently brought to the hospital on New Year's Eve by his wife who notices his symptoms worsen. Which of the following conditions is he suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of delayed post-traumatic stress disorder as the onset of symptoms are greater than six months from the event. 

Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a psychiatric disorder characterized by increased stress and anxiety occurring after a stressful or traumatic event, (e.g., witnessing or being involved in violent accidents, crime, war, assault, kidnapping, natural disaster, life-threatening illness, physical or sexual abuse). 

The predisposing factors for this condition include:

  • Presence of childhood trauma
  • Borderline, paranoid, dependent, or antisocial personality disorder traits
  • Inadequate family or peer support system
  • Female gender
  • Genetic susceptibility to psychiatric illness
  • Recent stressful life changes
  • Recent excessive intake of alcohol

Symptoms of PTSD can be divided into four types:

  • Intrusion symptoms
    • Flashbacks- The individual may act and feel as if the traumatic event is reoccurring 
    • Nightmares of the event
  • Hyperarousal 
    • Increased startle response
    • Insomnia
    • Hypervigilance
    • Difficulty concentrating
    • Reckless and self-destructive behavior
    • Irritability and anxiety
  • Avoidance symptoms:  
    • avoiding memories, thoughts, and feelings of the event
    • avoiding external reminders of the traumatic event
  • Negative cognitions and mood associated with the traumatic event
    • Inability to remember an important aspect of the traumatic event
    • Feelings of depersonalization and derealization
    • Anhedonia
    • Negative emotional state- fear, horror, anger, guilt, or shame

The duration of these symptoms should be > 1 month to label it as PTSD. (Symptom onset at Diwali persisting till New Year - which is typically >1 month later)

Based on the duration between the event and the presentation of symptoms, stress disorder is classified as follows.

Duration Condition
3 days to 1 month Acute stress reaction
More than 1 month Post-traumatic stress disorder
Symptoms occur after 6 months Delayed Post-traumatic stress disorder

Psychotherapies found to be effective for PTSD include exposure therapy, trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy, eye movement desensitization, and abreaction. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) may be prescribed as first-line treatment.

Other options:

Option B -  Panic disorder includes episodes of acute intense attacks of anxiety accompanied by feelings of impending doom. Generalized anxiety disorder is often confused with panic disorder and can be differentiated by the absence of spontaneous panic attacks.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a lesion in the periorbital area as shown in the image below. Which of the following investigations is most relevant for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given image shows xanthelasma palbebrarum. The most relevant investigations would be serum lipid profile and liver function tests.

Xanthelasma palbebrarumum is seen in: 

  • Familial hypercholesterolemia
  • Type III hyperlipoproteinemia (broad beta disease)
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis (chronic cholestasis)

Xanthelasmas most commonly affect the upper eyelids and the area around the medial canthus. They are relatively soft on palpation and range from pale yellow to yellow‐orange in color. They can be surgically excised, electrocauterized, or treated by using topical trichloracetic acid, or silver nitrate. Recurrence after treatment is commonly noted.

questions.text: A 10-month-old female baby with an abdominal mass is diagnosed with Wilm's tumor. On examination, the following findings are seen in the baby. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given images  show macroglossia and omphalocele which when considered with the Wilm's tumor points to the diagnosis of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is an example of a disorder of genomic imprinting.The genetic locus that is involved in these patients is in chromosome 11 (band p15.5) called WT2 locus , distal to the WT1 locus. It is characterized by-

  • Neonatal hypoglycemia
  • Macrosomia
  • Macroglossia
  • Hemihyperplasia
  • Omphalocele
  • Visceromegaly
  • Embryonal tumors such as Wilms tumor, hepatoblastoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, and neuroblastoma.

Wilm's tumor is the most common renal neoplasm of childhood. Clinically, the most common finding is an asymptomatic abdominal mass. Other presentations of Wilm's tumor include hematuria, hypertension, fever, weight loss, and tumor rupture causing acute abdomen. The most common site of metastasis of Wilms tumor is the lungs.

On microscopy, the classic triphasic combination of blastemal (small, round blue cells), stromal, and epithelial cell types is observed in most lesions, although the percentage of each component is variable. Nephrogenic rests are precursor lesions of Wilms tumors. 

The below image shows macroglossia seen in a baby diagnosed with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

Other options-

Option A: WAGR is a contiguous gene syndrome that is characterized by Wilms tumor, aniridia, genitourinary anomalies, and mental retardation.

Option B: Sturge-Weber syndrome is also known as encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis. It is a neurocutaneous syndrome characterized by angioma of the face, choroid, and leptomeninges. In the facial territory of the trigeminal nerve capillary, a vascular malformation called port-wine stain or nevus flammeus is usually seen. 

Option C: Denys-Drash syndrome presents with early-onset nephrotic syndrome, progressive renal insufficiency, ambiguous genitalia, and Wilms tumor.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Associations of Wilms Tumor
