Note: Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) protein is a transcriptional activator of genes involved in normal renal and gonadal development. Therefore, genitourinary abnormalities are commonly associated with WT1 gene mutations.

questions.text: An elderly patient on a vegetarian diet presenting with easy fatigability and pallor was investigated. Peripheral smear showed findings of macrocytic anemia. Investigations reveal elevated serum homocysteine levels and normal serum methylmalonic acid levels. What is the probable cause of anemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of megaloblastic anemia in a vegetarian with elevated homocysteine levels and normal serum methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels is due to folic acid deficiency.

Folic acid (vitamin B9) is a water-soluble vitamin, and its active form is tetrahydrofolate (THFA). It acts as a carrier of one-carbon groups. THFA is involved in the formation of many coenzymes in metabolic systems, particularly for purine and pyrimidine synthesis, nucleoprotein synthesis, and maintenance in erythropoiesis.

Folate deficiency results in megaloblastic anemia, homocysteinemia, and neural tube defects (spina bifida, Anencephaly) in the fetus.

Folic acid deficiency is associated with the following clinical and laboratory findings:

  • Raised MCV (normal range: 80–100 fL) - macrocytosis
  • Decrease in hemoglobin and hematocrit levels.
  • Normal MMA level
  • Elevated homocysteine levels.

where MCV is the mean corpuscular volume.

Patients with folate deficiency should be offered supplemental folic acid for the correction of the deficiency. Typically, oral folic acid (1 to 5 mg daily) suffices to treat folate deficiency 

Other options:

Option B: Vitamin B12 or cobalamin deficiency presents as anemia, fatigue, and pallor symptoms. Other presenting complaints may include peripheral neuropathy, glossitis, diarrhea, headaches, neuropsychiatric disturbances like dementia, and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord (SACD) leading to ataxia. A peripheral smear shows macrocytic anemia and hypersegmented neutrophils. Vitamin B12 deficiency is associated with raised serum methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels.

Option C: A patient with thiamine or vitamin B1 deficiency presents either dry Beriberi with predominantly neurological symptoms like neuropathy, muscle weakness, and wasting or wet Beriberi with predominant cardiac symptoms like cardiomegaly, tachycardia, high output congestive cardiac failure.

Option D: A patient with pyridoxine or vitamin B6 deficiency presents with symptoms of seborrhea, glossitis, convulsions, neuropathy, depression, confusion, and normocytic anemia.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man was brought to the casualty after a road traffic accident. He had headaches, nausea, and vertigo after the accident. His CT scan is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given CT image shows a crescent-shaped hyperdense lesion that crosses the suture lines and is indicative of acute subdural hematoma/hemorrhage.

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH) is a collection of blood between the dura and the arachnoid layers of the meninges. Most commonly, it results from the rupture of cortical bridging veins. Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice.

Radiographic features of subdural hemorrhages:

  • Typically unilateral (85%) 
  • Crescent-like distribution (concavo-convex) around the periphery of the brain.
  • They are not limited by sutures and can fill dural reflections.
  • Crescent-shaped hypodense lesion on axial CT: Chronic subdural hemorrhage
  • Hyperdense collections on CT: Acute subdural hemorrhage. 

 

Image 1: CT image of acute subdural hemorrhage

Image 2: CT image of acute on chronic subdural hemorrhage.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain and the USG of his gall bladder appears as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
USG showing comet-tail artefacts in the gallbladder suggests adenomyomatosis of the gallbladder.

Adenomyomatous hyperplasia of the gall bladder is also known as cholecystitis glandularis proliferans. It is characterized by gall bladder wall thickening due to epithelial and smooth muscle hyperplasia along with cystic epithelial invagination into the wall, referred to as Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses. Most common location of these are in the fundus of the gall bladder and the sinuses often contain stones. 

On USG, the characteristic findings are a thickened gallbladder wall showing bright echoes arising from the cystic spaces with ‘comet-tail’ ring-down artefacts as seen in the image below.  

The comet-tail artifact is caused by the cholesterol crystals trapped within the Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses causing reverberation(large number of reflected waves).

Other options:

Option A: An ultrasound scan in acute cholecystitis demonstrates a distended gallbladder with a thickened wall of >3 mm, pericholecystic fluid, the presence of gallstone( when it is due to associated cholelithiasis), and the sonographic Murphy's sign. Gallbladder distension (diameter >5 cm), pericholecystic fluid, gallbladder wall striations, and, occasionally, wall hyperemia on Doppler examination may also be seen in USG. 

Option B: On USG, gallbladder polyps are small echogenic foci adherent to the gallbladder wall and do not cast any acoustic shadow. They are often found in a non-dependent portion and the lack of mobility can be used to distinguish them from gall bladder stones.

Option D: In cholelithiasis gallbladder stones appear as echogenic foci producing posterior acoustic shadows.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with complete obstruction of her right nostril with a woody hard swelling of her nose as shown in the image. She gives a typical history of foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge with crust formation before the swelling appeared. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge with crusting before the development a woody hard swelling in the nose is suggestive of rhinoscleroma. 

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus).

It has 3 stages

Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul-smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis.

Granulomatous stage– Painless, non-ulcerative granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of a woody nose. (image given below)

 

Cicatricial stage – Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx, larynx. 

Histology shows infiltration of submucosa with plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells, and Russell bodies. Image below shows

  • Mikulicz cells - large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing the causative bacilli
  • Russell bodies - homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies in plasma cells. (noted by arrows in the image)

 

The slide given below shows Russell bodies.

 

Treatment of rhinoscleroma:

  1. Streptomycin (1g/day) and tetracycline (2g/day) for a period of 4 to 6 weeks.
  2. Steroids to reduce fibrosis.
  3. Surgical intervention to restore the airway and correction of the nasal deformity.
  4. Treatment is stopped only when two consecutive cultures from the biopsy material are negative. 

Other options

Option A: Rhinophyma or potato tumor is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous gland and presents as pinkish, lobulated swelling over the tip of the nose. It is associated with acne rosacea.

 

 

Option B: Atrophic rhinitis or ozaena causes atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. It presents with foul smelling nasal discharge with greenish or greyish black dry crusts but doesn’t cause woody nose.

 

Option C: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by the fungus Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis, and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

The image below shows a polypoidal mass of rhinosporidiosis.

 

Image below - Histopathology of rhinosporidiosis showing several sporangia, oval, or round in shape with a chitinous wall and filled with spores which may be seen bursting through its wall.

Related Pearl: Etiology of atrophic rhinitis

Etiology of primary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Hereditary- Involves more than one member of a family
  • Endocrinal- More common in females, starts at puberty and regresses after menopause
  • Racial- More common in mongoloid and caucasian races
  • Nutritional deficiency- Vitamin A, D, iron deficiencies
  • Autoimmune- Antigens of the nasal mucosa
  • Organism- Klebsiella ozaenae

Etiology of secondary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy and, rhinoscleroma
  • Long-standing purulent sinusitis
  • Radiotherapy to nose
  • Excessive surgical removal of turbinates
  • Diphtheroids, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, staphylococci and streptococci

Related Pearl: Rhinosporidiosis

  • It is a chronic granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi which is recently reclassified as a member of the protistan Mesomycetozoa
  • It is more common in the southern states of India
  • It affects immunocompetent individuals
  • Most commonly a waterborne disease
  • Clinical features: Blood tinged nasal discharge, frank epistaxis, nasal stuffiness
  • Findings: 
    • Leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple in color and attached to the nasal septum or lateral wall
    • Sometimes, it extends into the nasopharynx and may hang behind the soft palate
    • The mass is very vascular and bleeds easily on touch
    • Its surface is studded with white dots representing the sporangia
  • Diagnosis: Biopsy which shows sporangia

Histologic section showing sporangium (arrow) which is fully packed with immature sporoblasts at the periphery and mature ones at the center

Treatment: Complete excision of the mass with diathermy knife and cauterization of its base. Recurrence may occur after surgical excision. Dapsone is also used.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

Atrophic rhinitis is more common in females and usually starts at puberty. It is a bilateral condition.

  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia).
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who has a known history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension was diagnosed with Wallenberg syndrome.  He developed dysphagia, dysarthria, and hoarseness of voice. Which cranial nerve nucleus in the brainstem is involved that leads to the symptoms mentioned above?

choices.text: Nucleus ambiguus from general visceral efferent column
Nucleus ambiguus from special visceral afferent column
Nucleus ambiguus from special visceral efferent column
Nucleus ambiguus from general visceral afferent column

questions.solution:
Dysphagia, dysarthria, and hoarseness of voice seen in Wallenberg syndrome is due to the involvement of the nucleus ambiguus from the special visceral efferent column.

Nucleus ambiguus is a common motor nucleus containing the efferent fibers of the glossopharyngeal (CN IX) and the vagus (CN X) nerves. These supply the pharyngeal constrictors, intrinsic laryngeal muscles, and striated muscles of the palate and upper esophagus. This nucleus is also involved in the gag reflex and the cardiac parasympathetic activity. Lesions this nucleus in leads to dysphagia, dysarthria, and hoarseness of voice seen in Wallenberg syndrome. Nucleus ambiguus arises from the special visceral efferent column present in the medulla.

Wallenberg syndrome occurs due to thrombosis in the vertebral artery or posterior inferior cerebellar artery (the most tortuous artery in the body) causing infarction of the inferior cerebellar peduncle, nucleus ambiguus, vestibular nucleus, spinal lemniscus, the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, and the sympathetic chain. 

This results in ipsilateral ataxia, loss of pain and temperature, drooping of the eyelid, miosis, anhidrosis, loss of ciliospinal reflex, apparent enophthalmos, dysphagia, dysarthria, nasal regurgitation, hoarseness of voice, contralateral loss of pain and temperature, vertigo, nystagmus, and vomiting.

questions.text: An infant was brought with complaints of excessive crying and seizures. Examination revealed developmental delay. His urine had a mousy odor and the blood report came back positive for Guthrie test. Which enzyme is likely to have been deficient in this baby?
questions.solution:
This child is having phenylketonuria and the enzyme deficient in this condition is phenylalanine hydroxylase.

Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an inborn error of metabolism seen due to a defect in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (classic phenylketonuria). Less commonly, it can also occur due to a defect in the enzymes producing tetrahydrobiopterin. These defects result in the impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. The patient develops clinical features due to elevated levels of phenylalanine metabolites and decreased levels of tyrosine. The excess phenylalanine in the blood is metabolized to phenyl ketones (phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate) which are excreted in the urine and are termed phenylketonuria. Infants appear normal at birth. They gradually develop the following features as they grow up - 

  • Hyperactivity
  • Agitation
  • Low IQ
  • Seizures
  • Hyperreflexia, spasticity
  • Tremors
  • Hypopigmentation (due to tyrosine deficiency)
  • Phenylacetate gives rise to the characteristic mousy odor in the body's sweat and urine

Investigations to detect PKU - 

  • Guthrie test - It is a rapid screening test. It is detected by the absence of growth of certain strains of Bacillus subtilis as they require phenylalanine in the medium.
  • Tandem mass spectroscopy - It is the most reliable test and investigation of choice.
  • Ferric chloride test - urine shows a transient blue-green colour by adding a drop of ferric chloride to it.

Treatment - A diet low in phenylalanine (eg: food made from tapioca) is the mainstay of treatment. The goal is to reduce phenylalanine levels in the plasma and brain.

Other options - 

Option A: Tyrosinemia type I or hepatorenal tyrosinemia is caused by FAH deficiency. It is an autosomal recessive disease. This results in the accumulation of fumarylacetoacetate and succinylacetone which are metabolites of tyrosine degradation. The tissues most affected are hepatic, renal, and nervous tissues. The manifestations of these can be seen in the form of an acute hepatic crisis, peripheral neuropathy, and a Fanconi-like syndrome. The diagnosis can be established by the demonstration of elevated levels of succinylacetone in urine (boiled cabbage urine odour) or blood. 

Option B: Tyrosine aminotransferase is deficient in Tyrosinemia type II caused by a defective TAT gene. It is also an autosomal recessive disease that results in hyperkeratosis, herpetiform corneal ulcers, and intellectual disability. The laboratory finding here is marked hypertyrosinemia and elevated 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid. 

Option D: Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder, caused by a deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate oxidase. Homogentisic acid oxidase is an enzyme that converts homogentisic acid to maleylacetoacetic acid in the tyrosine degradation pathway. The three major features of alkaptonuria are long-standing urine turning into a dark colour, bluish-black pigmentation in connective tissue (ochronosis) and arthritis (usually occurs in the third decade).

questions.solution:
Eluxadoline is an opioid drug approved for the treatment of diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome(IBS)

Eluxadoline is an opioid agonist that acts on μ-receptors. On oral administration, it acts on gut opioid receptors and causes slow colonic movement and increased fecal fluid absorption. FDA has approved eluxadoline in patients with diarrhea-predominant IBS.

The adverse effects include constipation, sphincter of Oddi spasm leading to abdominal pain, pancreatitis, and elevated pancreatic enzymes or liver enzymes. Therefore eluxadoline should not be used in patients with a history of pancreatitis, alcoholism, or sphincter of Oddi disease.

Other drugs used in the treatment of diarrhea-predominant IBS are:

  • Alosetron
  • Rifaximin
  • Loperamide

Other options:

Option C- Alvimopan is a peripherally restricted mu-opioid receptor (MOR) antagonist. It decreases intestinal transit time and improves defecation. It has been approved to shorten the time of postoperative ileus. 

Option D- Naloxegol and Methylnaltrexone are peripheral MOR antagonists approved in the treatment of opioid-induced constipation. 

 

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida is in the second stage of labor. She complains of severe abdominal pain. On examination, the mother is exhausted and dehydrated. On P/A examination the upper uterine segment is tender, and contracted and depression is present between the upper uterine segment and the lower uterine segment. Obstructed labor is suspected. What is the management of this condition?

choices.text: Wait and Watch for labor to progress

questions.solution:
Ideal management in obstructed labor is urgent cesarean section.

Clinical features seen in patients with obstructed labor include maternal exhaustion, dehydration, tachycardia, and tachypnea. On P/A examination the upper uterine segment is tender and tonically contracted. The Lower uterine segment is thin and stretched. A groove/depression is felt between the upper uterine segment and the lower uterine segment. This is called a Bandls ring

Management of obstructed labor involves administering intravenous fluids for dehydration, providing antibiotics to prevent infection, and promptly performing a cesarean section to relieve the obstruction. If the fetus is alive, an immediate cesarean section is typically performed. Management of obstructed labor never involves a wait-and-watch approach or augmenting with oxytocin.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presented with abdominal pain and vomiting. X-ray abdomen reveals characteristic sign as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows rows of several air-filled spaces between the valvulae conniventes of fluid-filled, dilated small bowel loops, giving a ‘string of pearls’ or ‘string of beads’ appearance, characteristic of small bowel obstruction.

Radiological features of small bowel obstruction:

X-ray:

  • On erect X-ray, there may be presence of more than 2 fluid levels within the dilated small bowel loops.
  • Supine X-ray shows a row of gas bubbles trapped between the valvulae conniventes, within fluid-filled dilated small bowels, resembling a string of beads.

Ultrasound:

It can detect fluid-filled loops of the small intestine.

CT:

  • The presence of angulated and tethering of the bowel loops on CT may indicate adhesions, most likely due to a neoplasm.
  • Small bowel ‘feces sign’ may be seen due to the presence of faeces-like material in the small bowel loops proximal to the obstruction. It can occur due to prolonged stasis, and water reabsorption.
  • In simple obstruction, a definite point of obstruction, called ‘transition point’ may be seen, with dilated small bowel loops proximally, and collapsed loops distally.
  • In closed-loop obstruction, a U- or V-shaped configuration of the dilated loops may be seen with a fixed radial distribution.
  • A strangulated bowel represents the incarceration of the proximal and distal limbs of mechanical small bowel obstruction, with subsequent ischemia.

questions.text: Which of the following cutaneous lesions are associated with celiac disease?
questions.solution:
Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic, intensely pruritic, skin condition associated with celiac disease.

These lesions include intensely pruritic inflammatory papules and vesicles on the forearms, knees, scalp, or buttocks. Patients with Dermatitis herpetiformis (DH) also have an associated gluten-sensitive enteropathy (celiac disease).

The single best screening test for celiac disease is tissue transglutaminase Ab (tTG-IgA) which has a sensitivity of about 98% & specificity of about 95%.

A gluten‐free diet is the cornerstone of long‐term dermatitis herpetiformis management. This also treats the associated gluten-sensitive enteropathy (GSE) and may decrease the long‐term risk of lymphoma. Dapsone and related sulphonamide drugs have proven highly effective, suppressing pruritus within days of treatment.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man complains of jet lag whenever he flies long distances. He was prescribed Ramelteon. Where are the receptors for this drug situated?
questions.solution:
Ramelteon is a synthetic analogue of melatonin. Melatonin G-protein coupled receptors (MT1 and MT2) are found on neurons in the suprachiasmatic nucleus. 

There are two melatonin receptors, MT1 and MT2, in the suprachiasmatic nucleus where MT1 receptors promote the sleep onset and MT2 receptors change the timing of the circadian system. The suprachiasmatic nucleus functions as the principal pacemaker, or time clock, for circadian rhythms.

The pacemaker receives input from the eyes and many other parts of the nervous system, and these inputs mediate the effects exerted by the external environment (retinohypothalamic tract). One output of the pacemaker goes to the pineal gland, a gland within the brain that secretes the hormone melatonin. These neural signals cause the pineal gland to secrete melatonin during darkness but not during daylight.

Diurnal variation of ACTH also depends on the suprachiasmatic nucleus. The secretory rates of ACTH and cortisol are high in the early morning but low in the late evening. This effect results from a 24-hour cyclical alteration in the signals from the suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus that cause cortisol secretion. When a person changes daily sleeping habits, the cycle changes correspondingly.

Other options -

Option A - Ventromedial hypothalamic nucleus, also known as the satiety center gives a sense of satisfaction or fullness and inhibits the feeding center. 

Option B - Anterior hypothalamic nuclei are responsible for regulating the body temperature. 

Option C - The lateral nuclei of the hypothalamus serve as a feeding center and operates by exciting the motor drives to search for food.

questions.text: A 38-year-old businessman came with a complaint of difficulty in falling asleep for a few weeks.  He recently closed his business due to large unexpected debt in the company. He says even though he is exhausted at night, it takes him hours to fall asleep. Which of the following drug can be prescribed to him which has the least effect on REM sleep?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of sleep-onset insomnia. Among the given drugs, the one which can be prescribed for sleep-onset insomnia with the least effect on REM sleep is zolpidem. 

Zolpidem is a nonbenzodiazepine hypnotic. It acts as a selective agonist in benzodiazepine receptors and produces hypnotic-amnesic action. It shortens the sleep latency and prolongs sleep duration in insomniacs. It doesn't prolong total sleep time or alter NREM-REM sleep cycles. The effect on the sleep stages and REM sleep is less than that of benzodiazepines. 

Zolpidem doesn't show a rebound phenomenon on discontinuation and it has low abuse potential. Other non-benzodiazepine hypnotics are:

  • Zopiclone
  • Eszopiclone
  • Zaleplon

Other options:

Option A- Phenobarbitone can be used as a sedative and hypnotic. But they reduce REM and stage 3,4 sleep and disrupt the NREM-REM sleep cycle. 

Options B and D- Both diazepam and alprazolam are benzodiazepines that can be used for sleep-onset difficulty. They are selective CNS depressants that produce sedation, relieve anxiety, facilitate sleep, suppress seizures, and reduce muscle tone. But they also affect the REM sleep pattern more than nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics.

Note:

Ramelteon is a hypnotic given for sleep-onset insomnia that acts as a melatonin receptor agonist. It hastens the sleep onset and increases the sleep duration.

questions.text: The hemoglobin level is 7 gm/dL in a patient posted for a minor surgical procedure. Which of the following is true regarding the need for blood transfusion in this patient?

choices.text: Transfusion unlikely to be of benefit

questions.solution:
According to perioperative red blood cell transfusion criteria, a patient with a hemoglobin level of 7 gm/dL (6-8 g/dL) is unlikely to benefit from blood transfusions in the absence of bleeding or impending surgery.

The indications for blood transfusion are as follows:

  • Acute blood loss: To replace circulating volume and maintain oxygen delivery.
  • Perioperative anemia: To ensure adequate oxygen delivery during the perioperative phase.
  • Symptomatic chronic anemia: without hemorrhage or impending surgery.
Hemoglobin level (g/dL) Indications
<6 Probably will benefit from transfusion
6–8 Transfusion unlikely to be of benefit in the absence of bleeding or impending surgery
>8 No indication for transfusion in the absence of other risk factors

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child with Down's syndrome presents with a 14mm horizontal diameter of the cornea. The cornea is clear and vision is normal. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A horizontal corneal diameter of 14 mm in a 4-year-old child is suggestive of a megalocornea.

Megalocornea is diagnosed when the horizontal corneal diameter is 12 mm or more (up to 2 years of age) or 13 mm or more (if age >2 years). There is typically high myopia and astigmatism, but normal corrected visual acuity. Usually X-linked recessive; 90% of affected individuals are male.

Option A: Keratoglobus is a familial disorder, marked by thinning and hemispherical protrusion of the entire cornea. It can be congenital or acquired. A globular protrusion is seen here, in contrast to the conical ectasia seen in keratoconus. Intrastromal ring segments and cross-linking can be used for management.

Option B: Buphthalmos is a large eye that results from stretching due to raised IOP. The thin sclera appears blue due to underlying uveal tissue. Primary congenital glaucoma presents with buphthalmos. Lack of other concomitant features helps rule out buphthalmos.

Option D: Micro-cornea - Horizontal corneal diameter is less than 10 mm.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy presented with progressive muscular weakness. On examination, it is noted that he uses his hands to walk up the body from a squatting position. His lower limb appears as depicted in the image shown below. Lab testing shows increased CK levels and diagnosis is made based on genetic analysis that shows dystrophin deletion. Which of the following tests must be done periodically as a part of regular surveillance in this patient?
  1. ECG
  2. Echocardiography
  3. Vital capacity
  4. ABG
questions.solution:
The given picture shows pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles, also the child is unable to get up from a squatting position. This is characteristically seen in Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Surveillance testing should include

  • ECG, to monitor for arrhythmia
  • Echocardiography to screen for dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Vital capacity in sitting position - From 5-6 years of age  Monitored on a yearly basis during the ambulatory stage 

 

Salient features of Duchenne muscular dystrophy:

  • Most common hereditary neuromuscular disease.
  • X-linked recessive deletion of dystrophin gene on chromosome Xp21.

Clinical features

  • Progressive weakness, developmental delay, and intellectual impairment
  • In toddlers: delayed walking, falling, toe walking, and trouble running or walking upstairs
  • Common sites of muscular hypertrophy: calf > tongue > forearm
  • Gower's sign: Patient has to use their hands and arms to walk up their own body from squatting position due to the lack of hip and thigh muscle strength due to the weakness of proximal muscles, especially of the lower limbs.
  • Trendelenburg gait/hip waddle
  • Complications: Contractures, scoliosis, cardiomyopathy, malignant hyperthermia after anesthesia.
  • The patient is unable to walk by the age of 12 years and death occurs by 18–20 years of age, due to respiratory failure.

Diagnosis

  • Elevated serum creatine kinase levels
  • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis for the dystrophin gene
  • If PCR is normal, but clinical suspicion is high, muscle biopsy with dystrophin immunocytochemistry is done.

Surveillance:

  • Electrocardiogram, echocardiography, or cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) to detect cardiomyopathy.
  • Vital capacity starting at five to six years of age. Once the patient is nonambulatory - seated vital capacity, maximum inspiratory pressure, maximum expiratory pressure, peak cough flow, blood oxygen saturation by pulse oximetry (SpO2), end-tidal or transcutaneous partial pressure of carbon dioxide in the blood (pCO2)

Image: Gower's sign

questions.text:
Which of these sites have tanycytes and lack blood-brain barrier?
  1. Area postrema
  2. The suprafornical organ
  3. The supracommissural organ
  4. Organum vasculosum
  5. The anterior pituitary
questions.solution:
Area postrema and Organum vasculosum are circumventricular organs that have tanycytes and lack blood-brain barrier.

Tanycytes are specialized ependymal cells present in circumventricular organs. The functions of these ependymas and tanycytes include secretion of substances into the CSF, chemoreception, transport of neurochemicals from adjacent neurons, glial cells, or vessels to the CSF, and transport of neurochemicals from the CSF to the same adjacent structures.

The anterior pituitary has a normal blood-brain barrier. It is the posterior pituitary that lacks the blood-brain barrier.

Circumventricular organs (CVOs) are midline structures in the ventricular wall and are characterized by their extensive vasculature and lack of a normal blood-brain barrier (BBB). They are:

  • Area postrema
  • The subfornical organ
  • The subcommissural organ
  • Vascular organ of lamina terminalis (organum vasculosum)
  • The posterior pituitary (neurohypophysis)
  • The pineal gland
  • The median eminence

questions.text: A baby is brought to the OPD with a deformity in the hip and lower limbs. On examination, there is an asymmetry of the groin crease and a click sound is heard on moving the left hip.  The following test is done and found to be positive. Which of the following is not a risk factor for developing this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and a positive Galeazzi's test as shown in the above image are suggestive of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). The female sex of the baby is a risk factor for developing this condition.

Galeazzi's test is done between 3 to 8-month-aged children in unilateral cases of developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). To perform this test, the child is in the supine position with the hip and knee in flexion. The level of both knee joints is noted with respect to a horizontal line. Normally both knees should be at the same level. In DDH, the affected knee is seen at a lower level indicating femoral shortening.

Developmental dysplasia of the hip or congenital dysplasia of the hip is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth. Risk factors for DDH include:

  • Sex of the baby- females are more susceptible to DDH due to the action of maternal relaxin on the fetal joints in-utero predisposing it to dislocation. It is 3-5 times more common in females.
  • Intrauterine positioning- breech position is associated with a higher incidence of DDH
  • Genetic predisposition- DDH is more common in children of parents who had DDH themselves.
  • First born child

Examination of the developmental dysplasia of the hip:

1) Newborn to 3 months of age. Tests to check instability of the hip:

  • Asymmetrical skin creases in the inguinal, gluteal, and thigh regions.
  • Ortolani test: To perform this test, the infant is supine, with the hip and knee flexed. With the thumb placed over the medial thigh and the index finger on the greater trochanter, the hip is gently abducted. This reduces the femoral head into the acetabulum producing a palpable "clunk". 
  • Barlow test: This test is done within 2–3 days of birth. To perform this test, the infant is supine with the knees fully flexed and the hip at 90° of flexion. Gentle adduction results in a posterior subluxation or dislocation of an easily dislocatable femoral head, producing a palpable "clunk".

2) At 3-6 months of age:

  • Galeazzi's test 
  • Marked asymmetry of the inguinal, gluteal, thigh, or popliteal folds.
  • Decreased abduction on the affected side.

3) In children of walking age:

  • Trendelenburg gait
  • Positive tredelenburg sign
  • Limb-length discrepancy

Treatment of DDH includes early closed reduction with splinting or casts. If closed reduction cannot be achieved in long-standing dislocations, an open reduction may become necessary.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old woman came with fever, headache, and vomiting for 3 days. On examination, her temperature is 101 F, pulse rate is 108 bpm, and BP is 80/60 mm of Hg. A maculopapular rash is seen over the trunk and extremities. She has neck stiffness and flexion of the neck causes flexion of the hips and knees. Which of the following media is used as transport media for the causative organism?

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) examination:

  • Reduced glucose
  • Increased protein
  • Increased leukocytes with the predominance of neutrophils.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with fever, maculopapular rash, and signs of meningeal irritation (nuchal rigidity, Brudzinski's sign) with CSF showing reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes levels is a typical presentation of bacterial meningitis. Among the given options Stuart's medium is recommended for the preservation and transportation of Neisseria species and other fastidious organisms from the clinic to the laboratory.

A nasopharyngeal swab from the patient is held in a Stuart transport medium till it is plated.

Composition of Stuart Medium:

  • Sodium glycerophosphate
  • Sodium thioglycollate
  • Calcium chloride
  • Methylene blue
  • Agar

Characteristics of Stuart medium:

  • This medium is a chemically defined, semisolid, non-nutrient medium that prevents microbial proliferation.
  • Because of this composition, the medium ensures that microorganisms present are able to survive for a sufficiently long period of time.
  • Sodium thioglycollate produces a reduced environment so as to improve the recovery of anaerobes.
  • Methylene blue acts as an oxidation-reduction indicator.
  • Calcium chloride maintains the permeability of bacterial cells and sodium glycerophosphate maintains the pH of the medium.
  • The medium appears colorless in the reduced state and blue in the oxidized state.

Meningococcal meningitis commonly presents with non-specific symptoms like fever, vomiting, headache, and irritability. Other features of bacterial meningitis include neck stiffness, photophobia, decreased consciousness, seizures, and focal neurologic signs. A non-blanching rash (petechial or purpuric) develops in >80% of cases.

Fulminant meningococcemia is the severe form, where the patient presents with high-grade fever and hemorrhagic rash. There is thrombosis of several small blood vessels in various organs with perivascular infiltration and petechial hemorrhages. 

Some patients with fulminant meningococcemia may also develop disseminated intravascular coagulation, and circulatory collapse, a condition known as Waterhouse–Friderichsen syndrome.

  Guidelines for prophylaxis:

  • All patients admitted to the hospital with meningitis should be placed on standard precautions.
  • Droplet precautions are recommended for patients with Neisseria meningitidis and Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) meningitis until they have received 24 hours of effective therapy. 
  • Chemoprophylaxis is indicated for the household and close contacts. The preferred antibiotics are rifampin, ciprofloxacin, and ceftriaxone.
  • Monovalent, polyvalent, and conjugate vaccines are availbale.

Other options:

Options A, B, D- Cary Blair medium, Venkatraman Ramakrishnan medium, and autoclaved seawater are used as the transport mediums for Vibrio cholerae

questions.text: Pheochromocytomas are associated with the following syndromes except?
questions.solution:
Pheochromocytoma is associated with MEN-2, Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome, and Neurofibromatosis type 1. Cowden syndrome is caused by PTEN mutations and can be associated with multiple hamartomas of skin, breast, and mucous membranes, breast cancer, and neuroendocrine tumors.

Pheochromocytomas may occur in isolation or be associated with hereditary tumor syndromes. The latter include the following tumor syndromes which are characterized by unique germline mutations of genes. 

  • Neurofibromatosis type 1 is characterized by NF1 germline mutations.
  • Familial paraganglioma syndrome - Germline mutations within succinate dehydrogenase complex subunit B (SDHB), SDHD, SDHC genes.
  • MEN2 - Activating germline mutations of RET proto-oncogene.

questions.text: A patient presented with tenderness in the region shown in the image below. Which of the given structures cannot be palpated in this region?
questions.solution:
The marked region is the anatomical snuffbox and lunate cannot be palpated in this region.

Three bones can be palpated distally to the radial styloid process along the floor of the anatomical snuffbox. They are

  • The proximal articular surface of scaphoid (Option D)
  • The radial aspect of the trapezium
  • The base of the 1st metacarpal.

An anatomical snuffbox is a triangular depression on the posterolateral side of the wrist. It is best observed when the thumb is extended. Its boundaries are:

  • Laterally: Tendons of Abductor pollicis longus (APL), Extensor Pollicis Brevis (EPB)
  • Medially: Tendon Extensor Pollicis Longus (EPL)

On palpation along the extensor pollicis brevis tendon, the superficial radial nerve can be felt (Option A), which can be rolled from side to side on the tendon. It forms the roof of the snuffbox along with the cephalic vein, which is also visible and palpable. The only content of the snuffbox is the radial artery (Option B), and its pulsations can be palpated deeply on its floor.

questions.text: An obstetrician performs a procedure for labor induction on a patient which is depicted in the image below. Which among the following is false about it?

choices.text: It is based on Ferguson reflex
It is associated with raised blood levels of prostaglandin F2α metabolites
It is a simple and safe method of induction of labor
It is done after artificial rupture of membranes

questions.solution:
The method of labor induction being depicted in the image is the stripping of membranes. This is done prior to the artificial rupture of membranes (ARM).

Stripping/Sweeping: Digital separation of chorio-amniotic membranes from the wall of the cervix & lower uterine segment. This helps in labor induction by eliciting the Ferguson reflex.

Ferguson reflex/Fetal ejection reflex is a phenomenon in which mechanical stretching of the internal cervix enhances uterine activity. It is associated with an increase in blood levels of prostaglandin F2α metabolite (PGFM). The release of oxytocin from the maternal pituitary has also been suggested as a possible mechanism.

questions.text: In a village of 2000 people, you diagnosed a 10-year-old boy having diarrhea with cholera. 19 more similar cases occurred in the same village, out of which 5 succumbed to death. Which of the following parameters can be used to assess the killing power of the causative agent in the given outbreak?
questions.solution:
The case fatality rate represents the killing power of the disease.

Case fatality rate = Total number of deaths due to a particular disease X 100 / Total number of cases due to the same disease

The case-fatality rate is thus the proportion of people with a particular disease who die from that disease. It is a measure of the severity of the disease, and the deadliness of an outbreak, and may be used to evaluate any public health measures implemented. It is closely related to the virulence of the agent.

Due to changes in the agent, host, and environmental factors in different epidemics, the case fatality rate for the same disease may vary in different epidemics. It is typically used in acute infectious diseases. Eg: Food poisoning, measles, cholera, etc. 

Other options:

Option B: Proportional mortality rate is used to know the proportion of total death due to any particular cause. It does not indicate the risk of contracting or dying from the disease.

 

Option C: Crude death rate measures the rate at which the death is occurring from different causes in a given population, during a specified period. 

Crude death rate = number of deaths during the year X 1000/ Mid-year population

Option D: Specific death rate is used to identify particular groups or groups "at-risk" for preventive action. They help in comparison between different causes of death within the same population. 

Specific death rate due to cancer = Number of death from cancer during a calendar year X 1000/ Mid-year population

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: A pediatrician is testing the hearing of a baby. When a sound is made with a toy, the baby directly looks at the toy diagonally. At what age is this milestone achieved?
questions.solution:
Diagonal localization of sound occurs by the age of 10 months.

Newborn babies respond to sounds by startling, blinking, crying, or changing the ongoing activity. A baby can turn its head towards the source of sound by 3 to 4 months. If a sound is made below the level of the baby's ears, it turns the head to one side and then downwards at 5 to 6 months. A month later from this, it will localize the sounds above the level of its ears. By the age of 10 months, the child directly looks at the source of sound diagonally.

questions.text: A mother brings her 6-month-old baby to your PHC with complaints of a lump in the axillary region. The child is immunized and up-to-date. Examination revealed a tender lymph node of 2cm in the axilla of the infant. Adverse reaction to which of the following could be the likely cause of the baby's symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lymphadenitis which is an adverse reaction to BCG vaccination.

At least one enlarged lymph node of size > 1.5 cm can be detected (mostly axillary), which can then develop a draining sinus over a lymph node leading to suppurative lymphadenitis. It occurs within 2 to 6 months after receipt of the BCG vaccine, on the same side as inoculation.

It usually heals spontaneously and is best left untreated, unless the lesion is. adherent to skin. In such cases, surgical drainage and local instillation of anti-tuberculous drug can be done.
Systemic treatment with anti-tuberculous drugs would be ineffective. 

Other adverse reactions following BCG vaccination include BCG osteitis/ osteomyelitis, ulceration, and disseminated BCG infection.

questions.text: A primigravida delivered a baby at her house. How many visits should an ASHA worker make post-delivery to evaluate the condition of the newborn and the mother?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, where the woman has had a home delivery, an ASHA worker would make 7 visits post-delivery to evaluate the condition of the newborn and the mother.

  • 7 visits after home delivery on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 42
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28, and 42
  • 5 visits after cesarean section delivery, first visit on day 7, and thereafter 4 visits till day 42

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS

    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: You notice the following skin finding in a child presenting to the dermatology OPD. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts phrynoderma which can be managed by Vitamin A supplementation.

Phrynoderma (toad skin) is common in children in the 5 - 15 year age group. Earlier thought to be purely due to Vitamin A deficiency, now has been associated with other nutritional deficiencies including B complex, ribofla­vin, vitamin C, vitamin E, essential fatty acids, and malnutrition

It is a non-specific finding that can be associated with: 

• Liver cirrhosis.
• Malabsorption syndromes.
• Anorexia nervosa.
• Alcohol abuse.
• Nutritional deficiency following bariatric surgery.

It manifests as groups of papules, each one around 3–4 mm in diameter, with a central keratotic plug. The papules have a follicular distribution and give the skin a rough texture. The elbows and knees are the most commonly affected areas but the buttocks and extensor surfaces of the limbs may also be affected.

All patients with phrynoderma should have their Vitamin A levels measured. Treatment involves the correction of poor diet and administration of multivitamin preparations containing Vitamin A.

questions.text: A pregnant mother was prescribed doxylamine for morning sickness. Which of the following categories of teratogenic risk does this drug belong to?
questions.solution:
The drug doxylamine belongs to category A.

Doxylamine is a sedative H1 antihistaminic with prominent anticholinergic activity. It is used in combination with pyridoxine for morning sickness. It is classified under category A as there is no evidence of risk to fetus.

The united states food and drug administration (FDA) system for teratogenic potential attempts to quantify the teratogenic risk of drugs from category A (safe) to category X (definite human teratogenic risk).

Category A: The possibility of fetal harm is remote and studies on women have failed to demonstrate any evidence of risk to the fetus. Examples: doxylamine, folic acid, levothyroxine.

Category B: Either animal-reproduction studies have not demonstrated a fetal risk, but there are no controlled studies in pregnant women or animal-reproduction studies have shown an adverse effect that was not confirmed in controlled studies in pregnant women. Examples: Amoxicillin, loratadine, and ondansetron.

Category C: Either studies in animals have revealed adverse effects on the fetus, that is, teratogenic or embryocidal, but there are no controlled studies in women, or studies in women and animals are not available. These drugs should be given only if the potential benefit justifies the potential risk to the fetus. Examples: fluconazole, metoprolol, and sertraline.

Category D: Though there is evidence of human fetal risk, the benefits from use in pregnant women may be acceptable despite the risk, for example, if the drug is needed in a life-threatening situation or for a disease for which safer drugs cannot be used or are ineffective. Examples: Lisinopril, lithium, phenytoin.

Category X: There is evidence of fetal risk based on human or animal experience and the risk of the use of the drug in pregnant women clearly outweighs any possible benefit. The drug is contraindicated in women who are or may become pregnant. Examples: Methotrexate, simvastatin, and warfarin.

questions.text: Identify the fracture given in the below image.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a fracture of the styloid process of radius which is called a Chauffer's fracture.

Chauffer's fracture
It is caused by forced radial deviation of the wrist and may occur after a fall, or when a starting handle kicks back, the so-called chauffeur’s fracture. The fracture line is transverse or oblique, extending laterally from the articular surface of the radius; the fragment is often undisplaced. The injury is commonly associated with a carpal ligament injury, fracture of the scaphoid, and rupture of the scapholunate ligament.

In case of displacement, it is reduced and the wrist is held in ulnar deviation by a plaster slab, extending from below the elbow to the metacarpal necks. Imperfect reduction may lead to osteoarthritis; therefore, if closed, the fragment should be perfectly reduced and held with a K-wire or buried cannulated screw.

Other options
Option A: Pilon fracture is the comminuted intraarticular fracture of the distal end of the tibia.

Option C: Rolando fracture is an intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

Option D: Barton's fracture is an intra-articular rim fracture of the distal radius.

*Note: The arrow marked in the image is a distractor. Although it points to the ulnar styloid, none of the options are relevant to it. Additionally, the image shows a radial styloid fracture which corresponds to option B. Remember to always analyze a radiograph in toto, in the context of the options.

questions.text: A multiparous woman has a previous history of birth trauma with injury to the uterosacral and cardinal ligaments. Which of the following is likely to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
Uterosacral and cardinal ligaments form the level 1 support of the genital organs. Level 1 damage can lead to enterocele, uterine descent, vault descent.

DeLancey introduced three-level systems of genital tract supports,

  • Level I includes uterosacral and cardinal ligaments and its damage leads to uterine descent, enterocoele, and vault prolapse.
  • Level II includes pelvic fascia, paracolpos, arcus tendinous, pubocervical and rectovaginal fascia, and its damage leads to cystocele and rectocele.
  • Level III includes levator ani muscle and its damage leads to urethrocele, gaping introitus, and deficient perineum.

questions.text: Marshall's triad in a bomb explosion is seen due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Marshall's triad in a bomb explosion is seen due to secondary blast injuries.

Marshall described the characteristic injuries associated with bomb explosions. It includes:

  • Abrasions
  • Bruises/ contusions
  • Puncture lacerations
Blast injuries are classified as:
  • Primary injuries- effect of transmitted blast waves on gas-containing structures. External injuries are absent and are characterized by internal injuries. The middle ear, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract are the most susceptible to this.
  • Secondary injuries- injuries caused by shrapnel and other airborne debris propelled by the explosion. These injuries may affect any part of the body and sometimes result in penetrating trauma. Most casualties are caused by secondary injuries.
  • Tertiary injuries- are caused by blast wind that can throw victims against solid objects.
  • Quaternary injuries- all other injuries caused by explosions are not included in the above three categories. eg, flash burns, crush injuries, respiratory effects due to toxic dust, gas, etc.

Burns, histotoxicanoxia, and crush injuries
  • The specific pulmonary injury of air blast is known as blast lung.
  • When the explosion is in the water the pressure changes are called underwater blast. Intestinal damage is very common in underwater blast injuries.
  • Solid blast refers to the wave of energy that spreads through the rigid structure when an explosive is detonated near it and people in contact with its structure can be injured.
  • Caecum is most sensitive to intestinal blast injury.

questions.text: An unimmunized 2-year-old child presented with coryza, conjunctivitis, and bluish-white spots in his buccal mucosa near the lower molar teeth. A day later, he developed a maculopapular rash on the face and neck. All of the following viruses belong to the same family as the causative agent, except?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of infection with measles virus which belongs to the family Paramyxoviridae. All the given viruses belong to Paramyxoviridae except Molluscum contagiosum, which belongs to Poxviruses.

Paramyxoviridae is a family of single-stranded RNA viruses which include the measles virus, mumps virus, parainfluenza virus, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), Newcastle disease virus, Nipah virus, and Hendra virus.

The measles virus has an incubation period of 7-18 days, after which the prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots (Bluish-white spots in his buccal mucosa near the lower molar teeth). This is followed by the appearance of maculopapular rash after 4th day of fever, which begins at the face and spreads to the torso and extremities. Lymphadenopathy may be present.

questions.solution:
The kind of bullet identified by the radiologist as explained in the given scenario is known as souvenir bullet.

Souvenir bullet is the one which has been lodged in the body for a long time with no fresh bleeding around it and surrounded by a dense fibrous tissue capsule. They can be visualized on X-rays. They are usually a result of bullet lodging in an inaccessible space which may result in more damage on attempted retrieval. e.g. Bullet in the spine.

Other options:

Tandem bullet (Piggyback bullet): This is where two bullets come out with a single shot. Seen with unused or locally made weapons. It may cause confusion with the number of entry and exit wounds.

Incendiary bullets: Type of army bullet used to cause fire in the target.

questions.text:
A patient presents with increased urine output. The urine osmolarity is 220 mOsm/L. On water deprivation test, the urine osmolality is unchanged. Plasma AVP is found to be elevated. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?

AVP - Arginine vasopressin
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a patient with increased urine output, low urine osmolarity and increased plasma AVP levels, a diagnosis of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is most likely.

In a patient with increased urinary frequency and polyuria, 24-hour urine should be collected with unrestricted fluid intake. If the urine osmolarity is <300 mosm/L and urine volume is >50 mL/kg/day, the patient has diabetes insipidus (DI). The next step is to do a fluid deprivation test. If this results in concentration of the urine (increase in the urine osmolarity), it indicates that the patient has primary polydipsia. If, however, the urine osmolarity remains unchanged on fluid restriction, diabetes insipidus is confirmed.

To differentiate between pituitary and nephrogenic DI, desmopressin can be injected and the response noted. If there is concentration of the urine, a diagnosis of central DI is made; if there is no increase in the osmolarity of the urine, a diagnosis of nephrogenic DI is made. Another approach to differentiate between the two is to measure plasma arginine vasopressin (AVP) levels. The workup of polyuria has been shown in the algorithm below. 

Syndrome of inappropriate ADH release (SiADH) (option B) will not present with polyuria. Instead, the patient will present with features of hyponatremia, such as lethargy, altered sensorium and seizures. The urine osmolarity will be high and plasma osmolarity will be low in these patients because of increased water absorption from the distal tubule and resulting dilutional hyponatremia.

Central diabetes insipidus (option A) will present with lower levels of circulating AVP and loss of normal bright spot in the posterior pituitary on the MRI of the brain. 

Primary polydipsia (option D) will show increased osmolarity of the urine on water deprivation and low levels of circulating AVP.

Related Pearl: Water Deprivation test in Diabetes Insipidus

Procedure: Start the test at 4 am by checking the baseline urine osmolality. Deprive the patient of water till 12 pm (8 hours), and then re-check urine osmolality. 

  Urine osmolality before water deprivation Urine osmolality after water deprivation Urine osmolality after desmopressin administration
Normal  Normal  Increases No change
Central DI Low No change >50% increase from baseline
Nephrogenic DI Low No change <10% increase from baseline
Primary polydipsia Low Increases No change


Note: Normal urine osmolality- 500-850 mOsm/L

Related Pearl: Causes of Central Diabetes insipidus

  • Neoplasms: 
    • Pituitary adenomas (most common)
    • Meningioma
    • Metastasis from lung and breast cancers
  • Infiltrative: 
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Langerhans cell histiocytosis
  • Genetic: 
    • Wolfram syndrome
    • Hand-Schuller-Christian disease 
  • Infections: 
    • Chronic meningitis
    • Viral encephalitis
    • Toxoplasmosis
  •  Inflammatory:
    • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
    • Lupus erythematosus
    • Scleroderma
  •  Vascular:
    • Sheehan’s syndrome
    • Aneurysm (internal carotid)
  • Head injury (closed and penetrating) including pituitary surgery
  • Snakebite
  • Lymphocytic hypophysitis

questions.text: Mr. A is furious after his fiancee broke off their engagement, and gets inebriated. He then attacks her with a heavy rod and injures her right eye. He will be deemed liable for his actions even though they were committed in a state of inebriation under which section of the IPC?
questions.solution:
In the given case scenario, Mr. A will be charged under Section 86 of the IPC (BNS Sce 24) as he was under voluntary intoxication while he committing the act and he is liable for his actions.

McNaughten's rule falls under section 84 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) (BNS Sec 22). Mc Naughten's rule (The right or wrong test / The legal test) states that "A person of unsound mind is not liable for an act."

Defect: In Mc Naughthen’s rule, only intellectual factors are considered but emotions, delusion, and control of impulses are ignored.

Related Pearl: BNS section 22, M'Naghten's rule

M'Naghten's rule, BNS 22 (Previously - Section 84 IPC):  Criminal responsibility of the insane.

Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.
