questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the incubation period?

choices.text: Quarantine is usually advised for a period equal to the maximum incubation period of disease
Diseases like measles are not communicable during the incubation period
Immunization of exposed patient during incubation period is useful in preventing clinical illness
In cases of point source epidemic all the cases occur within one incubation period of the disease

questions.solution:
Diseases like measles are communicable during the incubation period.

Generally, infectious diseases are not communicable during the incubation period, but there are a few exceptions like measles, chickenpox, whooping cough, and hepatitis A which are communicable during the later part of the incubation period.

The incubation period is the time interval between the invasion of the infectious agent and the appearance of the first symptom or signs in the body. It is termed as the latent period in non-infectious diseases.

The incubation period is helpful for :

  • Tracing the source of infection and contacts.
  • Determining the period of surveillance or quarantine, which is usually equal to the maximum incubation period of the disease (Option A)
  • Planning immunization. Prophylactically, knowledge of the incubation period is helpful in preventing clinical illness (Option C) by using immunoglobulins and antisera. 
  • Identification of point source or propagated epidemics. In cases of point source epidemic, all the cases occur within one incubation period of the disease; in a propagated epidemic, cases occur later than the known length of the incubation period. (Option D)
  • Determining the prognosis.

questions.text: While assisting with a laparoscopic appendectomy, you observe the resident use the Fold of ________ (marked in the image below) as a guide while coagulating vessels in the mesoappendix. Choose the correct option about this named anatomical landmark.
questions.solution:
The Fold of Treves is an antimesenteric ileocecal fold of peritoneum used as a guide while coagulating vessels in the mesoappendix

A clinical aid useful for detecting the location of the appendix through small abdominal incisions is the identification of the fold of Treves. It is an antimesenteric ileocecal fold of the peritoneum that marks the junction of the ileum and cecum. As it does not contain any vessels, it is referred to as the bloodless fold of Treves. It is also used as a guide to determine the extent of coagulation during an appendectomy. This prevents thermal injury to adjacent structures.

Other options:

Option A: The ligament of Treitz is part of the duodenojejunal junction and forms the line of demarcation for gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding. Upper GI bleeding refers to bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz, and lower GI bleeding refers to bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz. 

Option B: Jackson Membrane is an adhesion from the right abdominal wall to the anterior tenia of the ascending colon.

Option C: Gerlach valves are mucosal folds covering the appendiceal orifice.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with a rash on sun-exposed areas of the body and a history of ataxia and diarrhea. His urine shows the presence of only neutral amino acids. Which of the following tests is positive in this condition?
questions.solution:
A patient with manifestations of pellagra (rash in sun-exposed areas, ataxia, and psychiatric manifestations) along with the presence of neutral amino-aciduria points to the diagnosis of Hartnup disorder. The Obermeyer test is positive in this condition.

The Obermeyer test detects the urinary excretion of indole compounds. Indole derivates such as indican are found in large amounts in patients due to bacterial breakdown of unabsorbed tryptophan in the intestines. 

Hartnup disorder is an autosomal recessive disorder due to a defect in the transporter for neutral amino acids like tryptophan. Decreased intestinal absorption of tryptophan in conjunction with its increased renal loss leads to its reduced bioavailability. This hampers niacin synthesis, and Hartnup disorder can thus present with manifestations of niacin deficiency (pellagra) like diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia.

The major clinical manifestation is cutaneous photosensitivity. The skin becomes erythematous after sun exposure and might develop a pellagra-like rash and eczema over time. Some patients might have intermittent ataxia manifested as unsteady, wide-based gait. Cognitive development is usually normal, but there may be episodic psychiatric manifestations such as irritability, emotional instability, and depression. 

The diagnosis of Hartnup disorder is established by typical clinical history and the presence of neutral amino acids in the urine. Urinary excretion of other amino acids remains normal, which differentiates it from causes of generalized aminoaciduria like Fanconi syndrome. Treatment with nicotinamide and a high-protein diet gives a good response in symptomatic patients.

Other options:

Option B: Benedict's test detects the excretion of reducing substances in the urine. About 0.5 ml of urine is boiled with 5 ml of Benedict's reagent for 2 minutes. The formation of a precipitate is observed on cooling. The test is semi-quantitative and the color of the precipitate roughly parallels the concentration of reducing sugar.

Option C: Guthrie bacterial inhibition test is a screening test for phenylketonuria. This test uses a phenylalanine requiring strain of Bacillus subtilis.

Option D: Seliwanoff's test will distinguish glucose and fructose. The reagent is resorcinol in HCl. 3 ml of the reagent and 0.5 ml of urine are heated for 30 seconds up to a boiling point. A red color indicates the presence of fructose.

Related Pearl: Conditions Associated with Pellagra-like Symptoms

Condition/Disease

Reason for niacin deficiency

Hartnup disease

Intestinal & renal malabsorption of tryptophan

Carcinoid syndrome

Overproduction of serotonin that causes diversion of  tryptophan from NAD+ Pathway

Vitamin B6 deficiency

Defective kynureninase pathway

Maize rich diet

Niacin is in unavailable niacytin form

Jowar diet (Sorghum)

Increase leucine content inhibit QPRTase enzyme

questions.text: A 58-year-old man was treated with a diuretic for heart failure. He now presents with complaints of hearing impairment and dizziness. Which diuretic is likely to be associated with these side effects?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of drug-induced hearing loss, and furosemide is likely to be associated with these side effects, causing ototoxicity.

Loop diuretics have the potential to cause damage to the ears, resulting in symptoms such as ringing in the ears (tinnitus), hearing impairment, dizziness, and a feeling of fullness in the ears. The risk of ototoxicity is highest when loop diuretics are administered rapidly through an intravenous route and lowest when taken orally. To prevent ototoxicity, it is important to avoid infusing furosemide at a rate of more than 4 mg/min.

Furosemide is a loop diuretic. It acts by inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, resulting in increased excretion of sodium, potassium, and chloride. It is used in cases of acute pulmonary oedema, cerebral oedema, hypertension, and hypercalcemia of malignancy.

Hypokalemia, hyperuricemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia are the important side effects.

Other options:

Option B: Thiazides act on the DCT. They inhibit Na+-Cl− symporter present in the distal convoluted tubule. It is used for the treatment of hypertension and chronic oedema. Their adverse effects are as follows:

  • Hypotension
  • Hyponatremia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypochloremia
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Decrease glucose tolerance
  • May increase the lipid levels

Option C: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors like acetazolamide inhibit the reabsorption of bicarbonate ions in the proximal convoluted tubule. Used to treat glaucoma and mountain sickness and to alkalinize urine. Side effects are acidosis, hypokalaemia, fever, rashes, and paresthesia. Bone marrow depression is rare but a serious side effect. It is contraindicated in liver disease.

Option D: Tolvaptan is an orally active nonpeptide selective V2 receptor antagonist. Its main mechanism of action is to enhance the excretion of free water by the kidneys, which helps restore normal sodium levels in the blood. It is a new addition to the treatment options for hyponatremia caused by congestive heart failure, liver cirrhosis, or syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH). The most common side effects of this medication include increased thirst and a dry sensation in the mouth. Other possible side effects are fever, gastrointestinal disturbances, and elevated blood sugar levels.

questions.text: A study was conducted in a village to evaluate the effects of water fluoridation on dental health. Which of the following categories of studies does this study belong to?
questions.solution:
A study to evaluate the effect of water fluoridation on dental health is categorized as a community intervention study.

To evaluate the effect of interventions on health outcomes within a group that may be defined geographically like a city or village or socially like a workplace or school, we use community interventions studies. Community intervention studies come under experimental studies.

All the other options mentioned above are analytical studies.

Classification of epidemiological studies:

Observational studies:

  1. Descriptive studies
  2. Analytical studies:
    • Ecological studies or correlational studies
    • Cross-sectional or prevalence studies
    • Case-control or case-reference studies
    • Cohort or follow-up studies

Experimental studies or intervention studies:

  1. Randomized controlled trials or clinical trials
  2. Field trials
  3. Community trials or community intervention studies

Related Pearl: Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

The flow chart below gives a glance into the types of epidemiological study designs and where they are generally used.

Note: Descripitve study is used to formulate aetiological hypothesis of a disease. Whereas analytical study is used to test the hypothesis (i.e to accept or reject the hypothesis).

questions.text: A diabetic male patient was admitted with complaints of breathing difficulty. Blood investigations show positive reports for 1,3 beta D Glucan assay and raised galactomannan antigen levels. A CT scan shows a pulmonary consolidation and a CT-guided biopsy is done. Which of the following findings can be seen in the histopathology of the sample?

choices.text: Fungal hyphae are septate and branch at acute angles
Ribbon-like aseptate hyphal elements that branch at right angles

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of pulmonary consolidation and positive 1,3 beta D Glucan assay and raised galactomannan antigen points towards a diagnosis of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis. Fungal hyphae of Aspergillus species are narrow, septate, and have branching at acute angles.

Invasive aspergillosis is an opportunistic infection seen in the immunosuppressed hosts. Aspergillus has a tendency to invade blood vessels. Thus, widespread hematogenous dissemination with the involvement of the heart valves and brain is common.

Galactomannan is a component of the cell wall of Aspergillus. It can be detected in serum or bronchoalveolar lavage by ELISA for the diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis in adults and children.

Other diagnostic features of invasive aspergillosis are:

  • A positive culture from the affected organ
  • Aspergillus antigen detection of galactomannan
  • Narrow, septate hyphae with branching at 45o and conidiophores
  • Halo sign on CT scan

β 1-3 glucan assay is mainly used for invasive aspergillosis, candidiasis, and Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia. It detects the presence of (1-3)-β-d-glucan (BDG) which is an abundant cell wall polysaccharide found in most fungi, except those which lack the glucan entirely or produce it at a minimal level like: 

  • Cryptococcus neoformans
  • Zygomycetes like mucor species
  • Blastomyces dermatitidis

Image below shows fungal hyphae of Aspergillus species which are narrow, septate, and have branching at acute angles.

Other options:

Option B: Pseudohyphae are seen in candidiasis. Though 1,3 Beta D Glucan assay is used for invasive candidiasis, it doesn't show galactomannan antigen positivity.

Option C: Ribbon-like aseptate hyphal elements that branch at right angles is seen in Mucormycosis. 1,3 beta-D-glucan assay, cannot be used for the diagnosis of mucormycosis.

Option C: Encapsulated yeast forms are seen in cryptococcosis. 1,3 beta-D-glucan assay, cannot be used for the diagnosis of cryptococcosis.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: Identify the deformity in the x-ray of the tibia given below. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The given image shows hypertrophic non-union of tibia. The most appropriate treatment would be stabilization alone.

Based on increasing biologic potential for fracture healing, non-union can be of the following types:

  • Hypertrophic nonunion: 
    • These fractures have adequate healing response and good vascularity. There is a lack of adequate stability for the union to occur.
    • It can occur after initial nonoperative management or in some cases after initial operative management where there was inadequate stabilization.
    • On radiography, there is usually abundant callus formation with an intervening dark area of fibrocartilage-lacking mineral.
  • Oligotrophic nonunion:
    • There is minimal callus formation
    • It is due to inadequate approximation of fracture surfaces.
    • On radiography, there is minimal bone healing reaction.
  • Atrophic nonunion: 
    • Poor healing response with no callus formation due to little or no active bone-forming cells at the fracture site.
    • The blood supply is typically poor.
    • On radiography, there is an absence of bone reaction.

Management of non-union

  • Hypertrophic non-union
    • Stabilisation alone is sufficient
      • Conservative - functional bracing
      • Operative - Add or change to a stronger internal fixation
  • Oligotrophic or atrophic non-union
    • Stabilisation with bone grafting and/or bone curettage

questions.text: The illustration below shows the insertion of which of the following airway devices?
questions.solution:
The illustration shown above is the technique of insertion of the oropharyngeal(Guedel) airway.

The oropharyngeal airway or Guedel airway is inserted in the patient’s mouth with concavity towards the hard palate. As the airway is inserted it is rotated 180 degrees (concavity towards the tongue) until the flange comes to rest on the patient’s lips. 

The landmarks used for measuring the appropriate size of this device are the corner of the mouth and the angle of the mandible or tragus. This  airway should not be used in conscious patients as the airway may come into contact with the epiglottis and base of the tongue. This can cause coughing, retching, or laryngospasm if the pharyngeal and laryngeal reflexes are not blunted with a local anesthetic. 

Option A: Laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is a supraglottic airway device that is positioned in the hypopharynx.

The technique of insertion:

  • The deflated cuff of LMA is lubricated and inserted blindly into the hypopharynx so that, once inflated, the cuff forms a low-pressure seal around the entrance to the larynx.
  • Correct placement of the tube is confirmed by giving gentle positive pressure ventilation while checking for chest rise and ETCO2 using capnography.

 

Option B: Nasopharyngeal airway: inserted through the nostril (after lubrication) along the natural curvature of the floor of the nasal cavity with the bevel pointing towards the septum. Once the device is inserted the flange should rest on the nostril opening.

Option D: Endotracheal tube: inserted infraglottically after visualising the vocal cords with direct laryngoscopy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is posted for inguinal hernia surgery. In order to perform a fast-track surgical procedure, the anesthetic technique of choice is:
questions.solution:
Infiltration anesthesia is ideal to perform inguinal hernia repair as a fast-track procedure.

It has a lesser incidence of complications than regional or general anesthesia. Other anesthetic techniques for hernia repair include intercostal block and ilioinguinal nerve block.

Ambulatory/Outpatient anesthesia employs the use of fast - Track surgical techniques to provide adequate surgical anesthesia and minimize post-operative complications in order to reduce the duration of hospital stay.

Disadvantage of infiltration anesthesia - Short duration of anesthesia even when long-acting local anesthetics like bupivacaine are used. Extended- duration local anesthesia can be produced by encapsulating bupivacaine into a biodegradable carrier.

Regional anesthesia is contraindicated in patients with bleeding disorders, those on anticoagulants and with local infections.

Spinal anesthesia has the disadvantage over epidural anesthesia of delayed recovery due to profound motor blockade. Spinal opioids like fentanyl or sufentanil are added to prolong postoperative analgesia and minimize motor block without delaying recovery. But the adverse effects of spinal opioids like nausea, pruritus and postoperative urinary retention are additive.

questions.text: A neonate with a central diaphragmatic hernia is suspected to have a defect in the development of the septum transversum. All of the following are derivatives of the defective structure, except?
questions.solution:
The gastrosplenic ligament is not a derivative of the septum transversum, but a derivative of the dorsal mesogastrium.

The septum transversum gives rise to:

  • Central tendon of the diaphragm
  • Connective tissue of the liver
  • Ventral mesentery of the foregut. It has the following parts
    • Lesser omentum (ventral mesogastrium)
    • Ligaments of the liver (falciform ligament, triangular ligaments, and coronary ligaments)

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with type II diabetes mellitus has LDL cholesterol 100 mg/dL. There is no history of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. Which of the following is the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: No intervention required at this stage

questions.solution:
In a diabetic patient with LDL cholesterol 100 mg/dL, the next step would be to start the patient on statin, irrespective of the presence or absence of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD).

The indications for starting statins as given by 2018 AHA/ACC guidelines are as follows:

  • Presence of clinical atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD)
  • LDL cholesterol ≥ 190 mg/dL
  • Diabetic patient with LDL ≥ 70 mg/dL in the age group of 40-75 years
  • Estimated 10-year ASCVD risk ≥ 7.5% in a non-diabetic patient with LDL 70-189 mg/dL in the age group of 40-75 years

Evolocumab (option B) is a PCSK9 inhibitor that is approved for use in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or in patients with ASCVD who require further LDL lowering despite being on other drugs. Current guidelines recommend the addition of PCSK9 inhibitors to statins at maximally tolerated doses in patients at very high risk for ASCVD but whose LDL cholesterol remains above 70 mg/dL. This group of patients includes those who suffered acute coronary syndrome in the last 12 months, multiple prior MIs or strokes, and poly-vascular disease (CAD plus cerebrovascular or peripheral vascular disease).

Low-dose aspirin (option D) is effective in reducing cardiovascular morbidity and mortality in patients who have a history of MI and stroke. However, for primary prevention (that is, without a history of any ASCVD), the benefits of aspirin have to be weighed against the potential risk of major bleeding events, especially GI bleeding. Thus, the use of aspirin for primary prevention is restricted and should only be considered in diabetic patients who have documented high cardiovascular risk, and it is generally contraindicated in patients older than 70 years of age.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with irregular periods was evaluated for infertility and underwent an endometrial biopsy. The histology image is given below. Which phase is seen here?
questions.solution:
The image depicts the secretory phase of the endometrium.

During menstruation, the endometrium goes through three phases, namely proliferative, secretory, and menstrual phases. Their histological features are given below:

 Features in secretory phase/ luteal phase:

  • The secretory phase of the endometrium begins on the 15th day of the menstrual cycle and persists until the onset of menstruation.
  • The epithelium shows subnuclear vacuolation (presumptive evidence of progesterone activity).
  • Characteristic corkscrew-shaped glands and edematous stroma.

The image below shows secretory endometrium

 

 Features in proliferative phase/ follicular phase:

  • It begins when the regeneration of menstruating endometrium is complete and lasts until the 14th day of the menstrual cycle.
  • The glands of the functional layer are simple tubules with regular epithelium.
  • The basal layer of the endometrium and functional layer become more defined.
  • Arteries become more coiled and spiraled and extend through the endometrium.

The image below shows proliferative endometrium

 

Menstrual phase: Glands shrink with prominent vessels and haemorrhagic spots.

questions.text: The probable diagnosis based on the below clinical image of the breast is?
questions.solution:
The image shows a thrombosed subcutaneous cord attached to the skin of the breast which is the pathognomic feature of Mondor's Disease.

Mondor’s disease is the thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall. It may also occur in the arm or penis. On raising the arm, the skin over the chest gets stretched and a narrow, shallow groove alongside the cord is seen. It is treated by restricting arm movements and usually subsides within a few months without recurrence, complications, or deformity.

The differential diagnosis to be considered is lymphatic permeation from an occult carcinoma of the breast.

Other options:

Option A: Paget’s disease is a type of ductal carcinoma in situ arising from the nipple and commonly presents as nipple erosion.

Option B: Zuska’s disease, also called recurrent periductal mastitis, is a condition of recurrent retroareolar infections and abscesses. Smoking has been implicated as a risk factor for this condition. Managed symptomatically by antibiotics coupled with incision and drainage as necessary.

Option D: Tietze’s syndrome refers to the benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages.

questions.text: Identify the finding marked in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image shows hemorrhagic spots with pale white centers indicative of Roth spots. The pale centers are composed of coagulated fibrin, platelets, necrotic cells, inflammatory infiltrates, infectious organisms, and neoplastic cells.

These spots are seen in:

  1. Leukemia
  2. Diabetes
  3. Subacute bacterial endocarditis/ Bacteremia
  4. Hypertensive retinopathy
  5. HIV retinopathy
  6. Systemic lupus erythematosus

Other options:

Option A: Bull’s eye maculopathy is seen in congenital cone dystrophy and in chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine toxicity.

Option B: Sunburst spots are foci of clumped retinal pigment epithelium that develop in response to retinal haemorrhage. This finding is seen in sickle cell retinopathy.

Option D: Forster Fuchs spot is a raised circular pigmented scar at the macula seen after resorption of subretinal haemorrhage. It is seen in pathological myopia.

questions.text: A microbiologist is studying the effect of pepsin when it acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin. Which of the following end products will be obtained through this enzymatic digestion of the antibody?

choices.text: 1 F(ab’)2 fragment and many smaller fragments

questions.solution:
When pepsin acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, the end products are 1 F(ab’)2 fragment and many smaller fragments

Enzymatic digestion of antibody with:

  • Papain- 2 Fab fragments and one Fc fragment
  • Pepsin- One F(ab’)2 fragment and many smaller fragments
  • Mercaptoethanol- 2 H and 2 L chains

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient presents with complaints of fatigue and recurrent lower respiratory tract infections over the last 6 months. Serum protein electrophoresis shows increased monoclonal IgM. Which of the following is a possible complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with fatigue and recurrent infections and the serum electrophoresis showing monoclonal IgM is suggestive of Waldenström's macroglobulinemia. Hemiparesis is a possible complication that can occur in this condition. 

The plasma cells in Waldenström's macroglobulinemia secrete monoclonal IgM. Because of its large size, at high concentrations, IgM increases the viscosity of the blood, giving rise to hyperviscosity syndrome. This can present in the form of visual disturbances and neurological manifestations such as peripheral neuropathy, dizziness, and hemiparesis. Even bleeding can occur due to the formation of complexes between macroglobulins and clotting factors. This can manifest in the form of epistaxis. However, Waldenström's macroglobulinemia does not cause bone lesions or hypercalcemia (option C). Because of the size of the IgM paraprotein, there is minimal renal excretion. Therefore renal complications such as renal failure and amyloidosis are rare (option A and B). 

Waldenström's macroglobulinemia is a B-cell neoplasm that usually presents in the age group of 60-70 years. It is associated with acquired mutations in the MYD88 gene. The usual patient presentation is like multiple myeloma, that is fatigue and repeated infections. Additionally, symptoms of hyperviscosity are seen as described above. Acute hyperviscosity symptoms can be treated with plasmapheresis because most of the IgM protein is intravascular.

questions.text: An elderly woman presents to you with multiple joint pains. On examination, you notice the following deformity over the ring and little finger. This deformity is called:
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis. The is showing hyperextension of distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints and flexion at proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints suggestive of Boutonniere deformity.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease of symmetric polyarthritis, mainly affecting the small joints of the hands and feet. The wrists and metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints are most frequently involved. Clinically, patients present with early morning joint pain and stiffness lasting >1 hour that relieves with activity.

A Boutonniere deformity occurs due to the rupture of the central slip of the extensor tendon. Normally, the central slip of the extensor tendon inserts into the base of the middle phalanx. Following rupture of the central slip, the lateral slips also separate creating a gap. The head of the proximal phalanx goes through the gap, resembling a button going through a buttonhole.

The image below shows the two most common deformities in RA.

Being a systemic disease, RA causes various extra-articular manifestations, like subcutaneous nodules, lung involvement, pericarditis, peripheral neuropathy, vasculitis, and anemia of chronic disease.

Patients may have elevated ESR (erythrocyte sedimentation rate), and CRP (C reactive protein). Rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP (cyclic citrullinated peptide) antibodies are helpful in prognosis. Progression of joint damage is assessed by plain X-ray.

Management includes non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), glucocorticoids, and DMARDs (disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs) like methotrexate, hydroxychloroquine, sulfasalazine, leflunomide. Biological agents such as TNF-α inhibitors, abatacept, anakinra, rituximab, and interleukin -6 inhibitors are also helpful in RA.

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: The following image shows a deformity as a result of a fracture. Which of the following is false regarding the fracture under discussion?

choices.text: The three-point bony relationship of the elbow is maintained
More commonly leads to cubitus valgus
Inability to do OK sign with fingers maybe seen

questions.solution:
The above image shows gunstock deformity which is commonly due to malunion following the supracondylar fracture.  Supracondylar fracture more commonly leads to cubitus varus ( not cubitus valgus.).

Other options:

Option A: The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks. The three bony points are the tip of the medial epicondyle, the tip of the lateral epicondyle and the olecranon.

Option C: Posterior displacement is more common in supracondylar fracture of the humerus.

Option D:   The patient is asked to perform an OK sign by touching the tips of the index finger and the thumb. Normally, the patient can flex the distal phalanges and a nice O-shape is produced (right side). Supracondylar fracture of the humerus commonly leads to anterior interosseous nerve injury (left side), where the flexor digitorum profundus and flexor pollicis longus are weak. The patient is unable to perform the OK sign. The fingers get pinched, and instead of the tips, the volar surfaces of the thumb and index finger make contact.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman presents to the hospital with complaints of vaginal bleeding and mild abdominal pain. Her last menstrual period was 8 weeks ago. Pelvic examination reveals a 10-12 week, non-tender uterus. Urine hCG is positive. A pelvic ultrasonogram is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

LMP-last menstrual period 

hCG- Human chorionic gonadotropin
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the ultrasonogram showing characteristic snow storm appearance are suggestive of a complete hydatiform mole. Suction curettage will be the appropriate management for this patient.

The snowstorm appearance is due to an echogenic uterine mass that has numerous anechoic cystic spaces but without a fetus and amnionic sac. Combined with a raised hCG and a uterus larger than the date of pregnancy, the diagnosis of a complete hydatidiform mole is made.

Management of a complete mole is by suction curettage, which effectively removes the molar tissue from the patient.

Preoperative cervical dilatation with an osmotic agent is recommended if the cervix is minimally dilated. With large moles, adequate anesthesia, sufficient intravenous access, and blood-banking support are important. Intraoperative sonography is recommended to help ensure that the uterine cavity has been emptied.

Other options:

Option A: Expectant management is not appropriate in the case of the complete mole as patients may develop complications.

Option B: Methotrexate therapy can be used to treat a persistent or metastatic complete mole.

Option D: Indication for hysterectomy in molar pregnancy:

  • Preferred for women who have completed their families.
  • In women >40 years, who are at high risk for GTN

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

questions.text: A patient with hepatomegaly and polyarthritis involving the joints of the hands underwent a liver biopsy. The results are shown below. Which of the following tests will be the most appropriate for screening other family members?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the slide stained with prussian blue stain point to a diagnosis of hemochromatosis. The most appropriate test for screening the patient's family members would be transferrin saturation.

Asymptomatic and symptomatic family members of the patients should be screened with serum ferritin and percentage transferrin saturation. In the early phase of hemochromatosis, these values will be found to be elevated even before the iron stores are significantly increased in the liver. If serum ferritin and/or transferrin saturation are found to be elevated, the next step is to test the individual for HFE genotype to decide the further management.

In patients with acute inflammatory conditions and hepatocellular necrosis, serum ferritin will be elevated — since ferritin is a positive acute phase reactant. These conditions will not affect transferrin saturation, so it can be considered a more accurate screening method.

Hereditary hemochromatosis is caused by a mutation in the HFE gene, present on chromosome 6p. This mutation causes a decreased synthesis of hepcidin. This in turn causes unchecked iron absorption from the intestinal mucosa, leading to iron overload. The liver is the organ that is affected first and most severely.

Patients present with hepatomegaly and characteristic bronze skin pigmentation due to excess melanin and iron deposition in the skin. Diabetes mellitus and arthropathy involving the joints of the hand, especially the metacarpal joints, are also seen.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents with sudden onset breathing difficulty. There is no history of any prior respiratory diseases. The chest radiograph of the patient shows pneumothorax. Which of the following types of emphysema is likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
A young adult with spontaneous pneumothorax is most likely to have paraseptal (distal acinar) emphysema. 

The distal part of the acinus is involved in the paraseptal type of emphysema. It is the most prominent just adjacent to the pleura and the margins of the pulmonary lobules. It occurs more frequently in the upper parts of the lungs and accompanies areas of fibrosis or atelectasis. Enlarged airspaces, sometimes forming cyst-like structures, are the characteristic finding. Rupture of the apical cystic spaces that lie within or immediately under the viscera pleura causes pneumothorax. The initial recommended treatment in primary spontaneous pneumothorax is simple aspiration of the air. In recurrent cases, thoracoscopy with stapling of blebs and pleural abrasion is indicated.

questions.text: A 59-year-old patient presents with right-sided nasal obstruction and occasional blood-stained nasal discharge. His CT and endoscopy findings are shown in the image below. What is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
On the basis of the given images and the presenting history, inverted papilloma is the most likely diagnosis. The treatment of choice for inverted papilloma is medial maxillectomy.

Inverted papilloma (Ringertz tumor or transitional cell papilloma or Schneiderian papilloma) is a benign neoplasm of the non-olfactory mucosa of the nose (also called the Schneiderian membrane) and paranasal sinuses.

The lateral wall of the nose in the middle meatus is the most common site of origin. The hyperplastic papillomatous tissue grows into the stroma.
It is common in the 4th to 7th decades of life with a male preponderance. It is almost always unilateral and presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis. It can invade sinuses or the orbit, the latter of which causes proptosis, diplopia, and lacrimation.
 
On examination of nose or endoscopy, it presents as a polypoidal mass resembling simple nasal polyps, as depicted by arrows in the endoscopic image above. A computed tomography(CT) scan and/or magnetic resonance imaging(MRI) show the location and extent of the lesion. MRI provides additional help to differentiate associated secretions in the sinus from the actual tumor mass. A biopsy is essential for diagnosis.
 
Medial maxillectomy is the treatment of choice, done preferably via endoscopy. Recurrence is common and malignancy has been observed in up to 15% of the cases. Radiotherapy may induce malignancy and hence is not advised.

questions.text: The test below depicts the presence of which of the following defects of the left eye?
questions.solution:
The test shown is the cover - uncover test. There is abduction of the eye with suspected deviation (left eye) on covering the fixing eye (right eye) which suggests left esotropia.

This test consists of two parts:

  • Cover test
  • Uncover test

Cover Test: This is used to detect heterotropia (manifest squint). Light is first shone and corneal reflections are observed. This is done to assess fixation in the deviating eye. The procedure for testing using an accommodative target and for distance is as follows.

  • The patient is asked to fixate on a target straight ahead.
  • The eye in which deviation is not suspected is covered first. For example, if a right eye deviation is suspected, the left eye is covered.
  • Any movement of the right eye to take up fixation is noted.
  • The following are the possible results:
Movement of the eye Suspected defect
No movements Orthotropia/Heterotropia of the covered eye
Adduction Exotropia
Abduction Esotropia
Downward movement Hypertropia
Upward movement Hypotropia

The test is then repeated for the opposite eye.

Uncover test: This is used to detect heterophoria (latent squint). The test is performed for both near and distant as follows.

  • The patient fixates a distant target straight ahead.
  • The examiner covers an eye for 2-3 seconds and the cover is then removed.
  • If the covered eye had deviated, a re-fixation movement is observed on being uncovered.
  • The following are the possible results based on the re-fixation movements of the eye.
Movement of the eye Suspected defect
No movements Orthophoria
Adduction (Nasal recovery) Exophoria
Abduction Esophoria
Downward/Upward movement Vertical phoria
  • The speed and smoothness of the recovery is noted as well as evidence of the strength of motor fusion.
  • The test is then repeated for the opposite eye.

Related Pearl: Cover tests in ophthalmology

Cover–uncover test:

  • To detect the presence of heterophoria: Latent squint
  • One eye is covered with the occluder, and the other eye is made to fix an object.
  • In the presence of heterophoria, the eye under the cover will deviate.
  • When the cover is removed, the eye under the cover will return back to its normal.
  • This movement is observed.
  • The direction of movement determines the type of heterophoria.

Direct Cover test:

  • Confirms the presence of manifest squint.
  • Differentiates apparent squint from a manifest squint.
  • The patient is asked to fixate on the point light.
  • The normal-looking eye is covered.
  • In manifest squint, the uncovered eye will move in the opposite direction to take fixation.
  • In apparent squint, there will be no movement of the uncovered eye.

Alternate cover test:

  • In the below image, the patient has right exotropia with left eye fixating.
  • Both eyes move each time the cover alternates from one eye to the other.
  • It reveals if the squint is unilateral or alternate.
  • It differentiates between concomitant and paralytic squint.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of ischemic heart disease presents with palpitations for the last 3 days. A transesophageal echo shows a thrombus in the left atrium. His ECG is shown below. Which of the following should be done to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with ECG showing  irregular RR intervals with absent P waves is suggestive of atrial fibrillation. His CHA2DS2-VASc score is 2 (history of ischemic heart disease and age of 70), he is symptomatic for > 48 hours, and there is presence of a left atrial thrombus thus requiring initiation of anticoagulation.  

The major source of thromboembolism and stroke in AF is the formation of thrombus in the left atrial appendage due to stagnant flow. Hence thromboembolism must be prevented by giving anticoagulants, along with an appropriate rate/rhythm control strategy with the help of electrical or pharmacologic cardioversion. 

The treatment of atrial fibrillation depends on three things: the duration of symptoms, the severity of symptoms, and the risk of stroke. The patients who present within 48 hours of the onset of symptoms have a lower risk of an existing atrial thrombus and can be safely cardioverted. Those who present with unknown or known onset of more than 48 hours should ideally be anticoagulated before cardioversion. This can be done in 2 ways as shown below:

The severity of atrial fibrillation refers to the presence of symptoms such as hypotension, pulmonary edema, or angina that are reflective of the cardiac health prior to the onset of fibrillation, and requires emergency cardioversion.

For long-term treatment of patients, the risk of stroke is calculated using the CHA2DS2-VASc score, and anticoagulation is given to those with a score of 1 or more.

Note: Electrical cardioversion is contraindicated in this patient due to the presence of a left atrial thrombus and therefore high risk of stroke.

questions.text: You are an intern performing clinical rounds in the casualty. The casualty receives a call asking for arrangements to receive the patients of a road traffic accident that occurred nearby. The trauma PG wants you to assess the severity of the patients, taking the mechanism of injury into account. Which of the following scoring systems will you use?
questions.solution:
The Trauma and Injury Severity Score takes into consideration the "injury mechanism" to calculate the severity of the patient.

The components of TRISS include:

  • Injury Severity Score (ISS)
  • Revised Trauma Score (RTS)
  • Age
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)

Other options :

Injury Severity Score (ISS):

The Injury Severity Score (ISS) is calculated by summing the squares of the Abbreviated Injury Scale (AIS) severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions. The ISS ranges from 1 to 75, with severity groupings being defined as minor injury (ISS less than 9), moderate injury (ISS between 9 and 16), serious injury (ISS between 16 and 25), and severe injury (ISS more than 25). 

Revised Trauma Score (RTS):

The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a well-studied physiologic scoring system that characterizes the injured patient’s condition by incorporating the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate. These scores have been of value for research purposes and have been successfully used to make triage decisions.

Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS):

The Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) is the most widely validated classification system. It takes into consideration the following,

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

A score of 7 or higher consistently predicted the need for amputation, whereas all limbs with initial scores of 6 or less remained viable in the long term.

questions.text:
What is the effect of the mechanism of enzyme inhibition shown in the image below?

Km: Michaelis constant
questions.solution:
The given mechanism shows non-competitive enzyme inhibition. In this type of inhibition, Km remains the same.

In enzyme kinetics, Vmax is the rate of the reaction when the enzyme is saturated with the substrate. Km (Michaelis constant) is the substrate concentration at which the enzyme achieves ½ Vmax.

Km indicates the affinity of the enzyme to the substrate. When the enzyme has a high affinity for the substrate, ½ Vmax is achieved at a lower substrate concentration/ lower Km.

In non-competitive inhibition, an inhibitor binds to the allosteric site of the enzyme. This leads to a conformational change in the substrate-binding site which prevents the binding of the substrate to the enzyme. The free enzyme molecules have the same amount of affinity to the substrate because of which Km remains the same.

Since the inhibitor and the substrate bind to different sites, increasing the substrate concentration will not have any effect on reversing the inhibition. Therefore, non-competitive inhibition is considered irreversible inhibition. As some of the enzyme molecules become irreversibly inactive, Vmax is reduced in non-competitive inhibition.

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of delamanid?
questions.solution:
Delamanid acts by inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis.

Pretomanid and delamanid are bicyclic nitroimidazoles that act by inhibiting mycolic acid (a component of the mycobacterial cell wall) and protein synthesis in the mycobacteria.

Pretomanid in combination with bedaquiline and linezolid was approved by FDA in 2019 for the treatment of adult patients with extensively drug-resistant (XDR) TB and for patients who are treatment-intolerant or nonresponsive to multidrug-resistant pulmonary (MDR) TB treatment.

In India, delamanid is only approved for the management of MDR-TB.

Isoniazid also acts by inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis.

Other options:

Option A: Bedaquiline acts by inhibition of ATP synthase. It is a diarylquinoline that targets the subunit c of the ATP synthase of M. tuberculosis. This leads to inhibition of the proton pump activity of the ATP synthase and causes a failure in the bacillary energy metabolism.

Option C: Fluoroquinolones act by inhibition of DNA gyrase. They are used as second-line agents in the treatment of tuberculosis.

Option D: Cycloserine is a D-alanine analogue used as a second-line drug for MDR-TB that acts by inhibition of alanine racemase. Alanine racemase converts L-alanine to D-alanine which is needed for the mycobacterial cell wall.

questions.text: A tandem mass spectroscopy is done in a newborn to rule out metabolic disorders like phenylketonuria. Which type of screening is done in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The type of screening done in a newborn to rule out metabolic disorders like phenylketonuria is prescriptive screening. 

Prescriptive screening is done for case detection. People are examined for their own benefit. Screening is initiated by medical and public health personnel and is not requested by a patient. It may lead to an early diagnosis of an unrecognized disease. Hence, appropriate treatment can be initiated immediately to arrest disease progression.

Examples of prescriptive screening:

  • Screening of hemolytic disease in newborns
  • Screening of infants for phenylketonuria
  • Screening of bacteriuria in pregnancy
  • Screening for deafness in school children

Other options:

Option A: Prospective screening is done for disease control. People are examined for the benefit of others. It may lead to an early diagnosis and permit more effective treatment. It also reduces the spread of infectious diseases in the community, thereby reducing the mortality associated with the disease.

Examples of prospective screening:

  • Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and syphilis to protect the home population
  • Screening for streptococcal infection to prevent rheumatic fever

Option B: Multiphasic screening is the combined application of two or more screening tests to a large number of people at one time. It is not cost-effective and has shown no benefit in reducing the morbidity and mortality of the population.

Option D: Selective screening is done in high-risk groups. It is one of the most productive screening tests. Examples include MRI screening of the breast done annually in a 25-year-old woman with a first-degree relative having BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation.

questions.text: A patient presented with corneal opacities and renal failure. On investigation, the enzyme lecithin cholesterol acyltransferase was found to be completely deficient. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and the investigation showing complete deficiency of the enzyme lecithin cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT) points to the diagnosis of Norum's disease.

Familial lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase deficiency (FLD), also called Norum disease occurs when the deficiency of LCAT is complete. It is a rare genetic disorder inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. Here, the reverse cholesterol transport is affected leading to decreased circulating HDL cholesterol. Clinical features are dense corneal opacity and renal failure.

Fish-eye disease (FED) is due to a partial deficiency in LCAT activity.

Other options:

Option B: Tangier’s disease is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a mutation of the ABCA1 gene. Enlarged yellow-orange tonsils are pathognomonic. Low HDL levels are seen. Clinical features of Tangier disease include hyperplastic yellow-orange tonsils, hepatosplenomegaly, and peripheral neuropathy, which may be either relapsing-remitting or chronic progressive in nature

Option C: Abetalipoproteinemia is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a defect in the MTTP gene causing defective microsomal triglyceride protein. Here, loading apolipoprotein B with lipids is defective. Hence, few very low-density-lipoproteins (VLDLs) or chylomicrons are formed, leading to the accumulation of triacylglycerols in the liver and intestine.

Option D: Acid lipase enzyme deficiency can lead to Wolman's disease which is a lysosomal storage disease. The pathognomic feature of this condition is adrenal calcification. Infants generally present with failure to thrive, abdominal distention, vomiting, steatorrhea, and hepatosplenomegaly.

questions.text: A patient presented with the following finding after accidentally spilling hydrofluoric acid over his hand. What is the preferred initial treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
The initial treatment of hydrofluoric acid skin burns is with the application of calcium carbonate gel.

Immediate first aid to help prevent severe injuries from a chemical burn include:

  • Carefully remove the chemical and any contaminated clothing
    • Remove the chemical and contaminated clothing from contact with the skin and eyes
    • Do not wipe the skin as this may spread contamination
    • If the chemical is dry, brush it off the skin
    • Use gloves or other protective materials to cover hands and, if possible, carefully cut away clothing such as T-shirts, rather than pulling them off over the head
  • Rinse the affected area using as much clean water as possible
    • Rinse the affected area continuously with clean water as soon as possible
    • Try to make sure the water can run off the affected area without pooling on the skin
    • Only use water– do not rub or wipe the area

In very few cases initial management by lavage with water is not useful. Ex: Phosphorous used in some military devices and elemental sodium seen in laboratory explosions.

In hydrofluoric acid burns, initially, calcium gluconate gel is applied topically. Severe burns or burns to large areas of the hand can be subsequently treated with Bier’s blocks containing calcium gluconate 10 % gel. If the burn is with a concentration of greater than 50 %, then acute early excision is indicated due to the chance of hypocalcemia and arrhythmias. Split skin graft application to a hydrofluoric acid wound should be delayed and must not be done initially. 

Note - Although topical calcium gluconate is usually preferred, topical calcium carbonate gels may also be used for treating burns as they are also effective in providing calcium ions to complex the  free fluoride ions to prevent further toxicity.

questions.text: A patient presented with bull neck edema and a pseudomembrane on the tonsils. All of the following stains can be used to demonstrate the volutin granules of this organism, except?
questions.solution:
Presence of bull neck edema and pseudomembrane on tonsils points towards Diptheriae. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheria. All of the given stains can be used to demonstrate the volutin granules of this organism, except Fontana’s stain. Fontana’s silver impregnation method is used for staining treponeme and leptospira.

Albert’s stain is one of the commonly used stains to demonstrate the volutin granules (metachromatic/ Babes-Ernst granules) of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. The two other stains used for this purpose are Neisser’s stain and Ponder’s stain. The bacilli are usually arranged in pairs or palisades or small groups, at various angles to each other, resembling the letters V or L. This has been called the Chinese letter or cuneiform arrangement.

questions.text: Maximum penetration is seen with:
questions.solution:
Gamma rays show maximum penetration.

When a nucleus disintegrates, it will emit radiation either as photons (X or gamma rays) or as high-velocity particles. Gamma rays are a form of electromagnetic radiation (EMR) similar to X-rays, however, distinguished from the latter by the fact that they are emitted from an excited nucleus. Gamma radiation is highly penetrating and interacts with matter through ionization via two processes, the photoelectric effect, and Compton scattering.

Related Pearl: Ionising and penetrating ability of radiation

  • Penetration power: Gamma rays > X-rays > Beta particle > Alpha particle (helium ion)
  • Ionising or tissue damaging ability: Alpha particle (helium ion) > Beta particle > X-ray > Gamma ray
  • Alpha waves have the highest molecular mass

Related Pearl: Radioprotectors and Radiosensitizers

Radioprotectors:

Radioprotectors are substances that protect normal tissues from the effect of radiation. These include:

  • Zinc oxide
  • Pentoxifylline
  • Estramustine
  • Amifostine
  • Chlorhexidine (radiation-induced stomatitis)
  • Potassium iodide (for thyroid against radioactive iodine)
  • Melatonin
  • Antioxidants

Radiosensitizers:

Radiosensitizers make the tumor more susceptible to the action of radiotherapy. These include:

  • Oxygen
  • Cisplatin
  • 5 FU
  • Gemcitabine
  • Nitroimidazoles

Radiation potentiators:

The following drugs potentiate the action of radiation when used in conjunction: 

  • Doxorubicin
  • Dactinomycin

questions.text: If a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a Court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same question based on the same set of facts. This is known as:
questions.solution:
If a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a Court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same question based on the same set of facts and this is known as Res Judicata.

Defences Against Negligence

  • No duty is owed to the plaintiff
  • Duty discharged according to prevailing standards
  • Error of judgment
  • Contributory negligence - the absence of ordinary care on the part of the patient or his personal attendant
  • Res judicata (Section 337, BNSS) -If a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a Court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same question based on the same set of facts.

Other options:

Option A: 'Res Ipsa Loquitor' means 'the thing or fact speaks for itself'. It is obvious evidence of the negligent act committed. For example, swabs left in the abdominal cavity post laparotomy.

Option C & D: Limitation (Res indicata)- A suit for damages for negligence should be filed against the doctor within two years from the date of alleged negligence. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed. But, where a breach of duty to provide care as per a particular contract between a patient and a doctor is committed, legal action can be initiated up to three years from the date of alleged negligence.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was brought to the hospital with hypoglycemia and muscle weakness. On examination, he had hepatomegaly and growth restriction. Investigations revealed the accumulation of characteristic branched polysaccharides on enzyme assay and distention of hepatocytes with glycogen in the liver. Which enzyme is likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of growth restriction, hypoglycemia and muscle weakness with the accumulation of branched polysaccharides(limit dextrin) and glycogen deposition in the liver suggests a diagnosis of Cori disease, which occurs due to the deficiency of a debranching enzyme. Hypoglycemia and muscle weakness indicate debranching enzyme deficiency in both the liver and muscles.

Glycogen debrancher deficiency (Glycogen Storage Disease III) is also known as Cori disease, Forbes disease, and limit dextrinosis. When the debranching enzyme is defective, there is incomplete glycogen breakdown with an accumulation of abnormal glycogen with short outer branch chains, resembling limit dextrin.

It is inherited as an autosomal recessive disease. When both the liver and muscle are involved, it is termed type IIIa GSD, while if only the liver is involved (15% of cases), it is classified as type IIIb.

The disease presents in infancy and childhood with hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, short stature, variable skeletal myopathy, and variable cardiomyopathy. Hepatic symptoms in type III GSD usually improve with age, however, progressive liver cirrhosis and failure can occur. Hepatocellular carcinoma may develop. Hypoglycemia is associated with other features:

  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Fasting ketosis
  • Elevated liver transaminases
  • Normal blood lactate and uric acid levels 

It may be clinically indistinguishable from von Gierke’s disease (Type I GSD). However, the accumulation of limit dextrins (branched polysaccharides) is unique to Cori's disease. Definitive diagnosis is through liver, muscle, or both enzyme assays.

Treatment is mainly by preventing hypoglycemia. Frequent high-carbohydrate meals with cornstarch supplements or nocturnal gastric drip feedings are effective. A high-protein diet during the day plus overnight protein enteral infusion is also effective. A hepatic transplant may be done for patients with progressive cirrhosis or hepatocellular carcinoma.

Other options:

Option B. Glucose 6-phosphatase deficiency of this leads to Type 1 GSD or Von Gierke's disease. It presents with growth retardation, glycogen accumulation in liver and renal tubule cells, hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, ketosis, hyperlipemia, and elevated uric acid levels.

Option C. Glycogen phosphorylase deficiency leads to Type V GSD or Mc Ardle disease. It presents with poor exercise tolerance,  myoglobinuria on strenuous exercise, and increased levels of creatinine kinase.

Option D. Lysosomal acid α-glucosidase deficiency leads to Type II GSD or Pompe's disease. In infants, it presents as hypotonia, muscle weakness, cardiac enlargement, and failure, fatal early. Late-onset presentation is with progressive muscle weakness and atrophy.

questions.text: A 40 -year-old patient came with deformities, swellings, and pain in multiple areas of the limbs, her X-rays of the hands are given below. On examination, her skin doesn't have any hemangiomas. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above radiograph shows multiple tumors affecting the bones of the hand with soft tissue swellings and calcification which is suggestive of multiple enchondromatosis. Multiple enchondromas when present without hemangiomas is called Ollier disease. 

Enchondromas are benign bone tumors of hyaline cartilage which arise from the medullary canal.

Ollier disease is a rare condition in which many cartilaginous tumors appear in the large and small tubular bones and in the flat bones. It is caused by the failure of normal endochondral ossification.

Note: Enchondromatosis with hemangioma of the overlying soft tissue constitutes Maffucci’s syndrome.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient with a BMI of 34 kg/m2 complains of headache and diplopia. On examination, papilledema is present. CT scan of the head is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In an obese female patient with complaints of headache, diplopia, and papilledema on examination, a diagnosis of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (or pseudotumor cerebri) is most likely. 

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension refers to a rise in intracranial pressure in the absence of a structural lesion or hydrocephalus. There is an association with obesity, female gender, pregnancy, and drugs such as tetracycline, vitamin A, and retinoid derivatives. Patients with idiopathic intracranial hypertension typically present with a generalized headache that is present on waking up in the morning and improves as the day goes by. Transient visual obscurations are frequent during severe headache episodes. Elevated intracranial pressure can also cause VI cranial nerve palsy, causing diplopia. On examination, papilledema is seen. If accompanied by appropriate history, papilledema is considered the diagnostic sign of idiopathic intracranial hypertension. 

The initial evaluation of patients suspected of elevated CSF pressure is done with an MRI, including an MR angiogram. Measurement of CSF pressure using lumbar puncture can also be done. High opening pressure and improvement in the headache following CSF removal are considered diagnostic if papilledema is absent. CT of the head is often normal, but may show empty sella in some patients. Initial treatment is with diet and lifestyle modifications targeted at achieving the ideal BMI. The first-line pharmacotherapy is with Acetazolamide. If ineffective, Topiramate is the next drug of choice. Patients in whom chronic papilledema is threatening vision, optic nerve sheath fenestration, or lumbo-peritoneal shunt may be considered.

Other options:

Option A: Cluster headaches present with a unilateral, stabbing, and deep-seated type of pain. They are accompanied by congestion and watering of the ipsilateral eye and nasal congestion. Papilledema is absent.

Option B: Normal pressure hydrocephalus presents with a characteristic clinical triad of ataxia in the form of wide-based gait (magnetic gait), urinary incontinence, and dementia. Since intracranial pressure is normal, there will be no papilledema in patients with normal pressure hydrocephalus.

Option D: Migraine presents as a unilateral throbbing headache, usually accompanied by features like nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. It may be preceded by an aura, which is usually some form of visual disturbance. On examination, the patient is usually normal. There may be some neurological deficits, but they are transient. Papilledema is absent. 

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination with no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text: A  male patient presented with a 6-month history of soft tissue swelling on the right jaw. On examination, a discharging sinus was found as seen below.  On microscopic examination of the pus, sulfur granules appearance was seen.  Which of the following is not true regarding the implicated pathogen?

choices.text: Stains positive by Kinyoun's modified acid fast staining
It is an anaerobic or microaerophilic bacteria
It is a gram-positive filamentous bacteria
Culture of the organism shows a molar tooth appearance of the colonies

questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation, this is a case of cervicofacial actinomycosis caused by Actinomyces  species. Actinomyces are gram-positive, anaerobic, and filamentous bacteria that are non-acid-fast in contrast to Nocardia.

Actinomycosis typically presents as a painless nodule that indurates, with purulent discharge that contains sulfur granules. Sulfur granules are composed of a matrix of bacteria, calcium phosphate, and host tissue. It is an indolent, slowly progressive, suppurative, and granulomatous infection that produces pyogenic lesions, with interconnecting sinus tracts that contain sulfur granules. It presents as any of the following clinical types:

  • Cervicofacial actinomycosis- (most common site) fluctuant mass in the jaw area producing draining fistulas. (lumpy jaw)
  • Thoracic actinomycosis- pulmonary infection with fever, cough, and purulent sputum. 
  • Abdominal actinomycosis- following ruptured appendix or ulcer. It may involve multiple organs.
  • Pelvic actinomycosis- due to the colonization of intrauterine contraceptive devices.
  • Actinomycosis can spread to bones and surrounding tissue, and produce multiple discharging sinuses.

Diagnosis:

  • Gram staining of sulfur granules shows a dense network of thin gram-positive filaments, surrounded by club-shaped structures (Sunray appearance).
  • Culture shows a molar tooth appearance of the colonies.

The image below shows the molar tooth appearance of Actinomyces colonies.

 

Image below shows gram-positive filaments of Actinomyces. 

 

The given image shows a patient with multiple cutaneous lesions caused by actinomycosis:

Penicillin G is the drug of choice and requires prolonged administration where the duration of therapy is between 6-12 months. The other drugs that can be used include amoxicillin, erythromycin, tetracycline, doxycycline, clindamycin, and minocycline. Surgical excision and drainage may be required.

questions.text: A 33-year-old patient with flaccid bullae over his face and erosions over his oral mucosa. An immunofluorescence study of his lesions revealed the following picture. Which of the following is false regarding the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The immunofluorescence pattern shown above the characteristic f fish-net appearance, suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris. Nikolsky’s sign is positive, not negative, in these patients. 

This fish-net appearance of pemphigus vulgaris is due to anti-desmoglein IgG antibodies deposited on the desmosomes (Dsg3 more than Dsg1), which are present inter-cellularly. Direct immunofluorescence of skin sample with anti-IgG shows intercellular IgG deposits in the epidermis, in a  characteristic fishnet/chickenwire appearance.

Pemphigus is a group of chronic immunobullous disorders, that are characterized by the presence of antibodies against desmosomal proteins expressed in the skin and mucous tissue.

Desmosomal proteins like desmogleins 1 and 3 help in cell-cell adhesion and form the structure of the desmosome. In the epithelium, desmoglein 1 is mostly seen in all layers, while desmoglein 3 is more in the lower layers. In the oral mucosa, desmoglein 3 is seen in all layers and desmoglein 1 is present at low levels. The target antigens and the antibodies involved in the common variants of pemphigus are:

  • Cutaneous lesions:

  • Phenotypic and immunological conversion from pemphigus vulgaris to foliaceous or vice versa may occur, occasionally.

The image given below shows the lesions seen in pemphigus foliaceous.

The image below shows the lesions seen in pemphigus vegetans.

Acantholysis and cell apoptosis are the key pathological processes in pemphigus. Histological changes include:

  • Intercellular oedema with loss of intercellular attachments in the basal layer is the earliest change
  • Suprabasal epidermal cells separate from the basal cells to form clefts and blisters.
  • Basal cells remain attached to the basement membrane, in a ‘row of tombstones’ on the floor of the blister.
  • Blister cavities contain rounded‐up acantholytic cells, also seen in Tzank smears.

The image given below shows the row of tombstone appearance seen in pemphigus.

The image given below shows the round acantholytic cells seen in pemphigus, on a Tzanch smear.

Nikolsky's sign is elicited by applying firm tangential sliding pressure with a finger on lesional or perilesional skin. This leads to the separation of the normal‐looking epidermis from the dermis, producing an erosion, seen in acantholytic diseases like pemphigus.

Systemic corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment for controlling the disease, improving the quality of life and reducing disease activity. Other steroid-sparing drugs that are used to reduce the dose of steroids include:

  • Azathioprine
  • Mycophenolate mofetil
  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Rituximab
