questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought with complaints of abdominal distension for the last 1 month. On examination, an irregular mass is palpated, which is crossing the midline. The patient's blood pressure is normal. Urine examination shows the presence of vanillylmandelic acid and homovanillic acid. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a child presenting with a large abdominal mass with normal blood pressure and vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and homovanillic acid (HVA) present in the urine, a diagnosis of neuroblastoma is most likely.

Neuroblastoma is the most frequently diagnosed malignancy in infancy. It most commonly arises from the adrenal glands, followed by sites along the sympathetic chain, such as the paravertebral region of the abdomen and posterior mediastinum. Neuroblastoma is derived from primordial neural crest cells which populate these sites. In young children, they present as large abdominal masses with fever and weight loss. They can also metastasize widely and present with symptoms related to other systems. 

90% of neuroblastoma produce catecholamines. Urinary levels of VMA and HVA act as important tumor markers and help in making the diagnosis of the disease. Despite the elaboration of catecholamines, hypertension is less frequent in these tumors compared to pheochromocytoma. Histologically, neuroblastoma show small, primitive-appearing cells with dark nuclei — and thus may be difficult to differentiate from other small round blue cell tumors. The background shows faintly eosinophilic fibrillary material (neuropil) which represents the neuritic processes of the primitive neuroblasts. Around the neuropil, the tumor cells are arranged concentrically. This is referred to as Homer-Wright pseudorosettes.

Other options:

Option A: The dominant clinical feature in pheochromocytoma is hypertension. Most patients have paroxysmal episodes, which are abrupt elevations in blood pressure. They are accompanied by tachycardia, palpitations, headache, and sweating. Lab diagnosis of pheochromocytoma is based on the demonstration of increased urinary excretion of free catecholamines and their metabolites such as VMA.

Option B: Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma) usually presents as a unilateral abdominal mass, abdominal pain, hypertension, and gross hematuria. Wilms tumor thrombus can extend into the inferior vena cava and the right atrium. Laboratory findings that can be seen include polycythemia and thrombocytosis.

Option D: Hepatoblastoma presents as an asymptomatic mass in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. It mostly arises from the right lobe of the liver. Patients have non-specific symptoms such as fever, fatigue, weight loss, and anorexia. A biopsy of the liver mass is necessary to make the diagnosis. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is a useful tumor marker that is used in diagnosis and monitoring.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with repeated episodes of red-eye, eye pain, and blurred vision. The image of his eye is given below. What is the finding seen in the image?
questions.solution:
In this patient with repeated episodes of red-eye, eye pain, and blurred vision, there is a nodule on the pupillary edge of the iris prompting suspicion of uveitis and making it likely that it is a Koeppe nodule.

Anterior uveitis is the inflammation of the anterior portion of the uveal tract consisting of the iris and anterior ciliary body. It is most often associated with HLA-B27 positive conditions such as Behcet disease and sarcoidosis. Patients usually present with ocular pain, circumcorneal congestion, photophobia, etc.

Anterior uveitis is characterized by: 

  • Koeppe nodules - lymphocytic infiltrates at the pupillary margin
  • Busacca nodules - lymphocytic infiltrates at collarette 
  • Keratic precipitates (KP) - proteinaceous deposits on the corneal endothelium. These are pathognomonic for anterior uveitis. Types of KP's include - 
    • Mutton fat type - seen in granulomatous uveitis
    • Granular type - seen in non-granulomatous uveitis
  • Aqueous flare - diffuse inflammation with exudates in the anterior chamber. It is the earliest sign of non-granulomatous uveitis

The exudates can also pour out into the posterior chamber causing the iris to adhere posteriorly to the lens. When the adhesions organize to become fibrous, it becomes firm and is known as posterior synechiae.  A dilating/mydriatic agent causes the remaining pupillary portions, that have not become attached, to dilate irregularly giving the classic appearance mentioned above. 

Cycloplegics such as atropine and homatropine and steroids are the mainstay of treatment. Complications such as complicated cataracts, secondary glaucoma, and phthisis bulbi (soft and atrophic eye) can be seen. 

Other options:

Option A: Brushfield spots refer to small white speckles on the peripheral iris that are arranged in a concentric ring. They are seen in Down’s syndrome and may sometimes be a normal finding in blue eyes. The image below shows Brushfield spots.

Option C: Lisch nodules are small well-defined nodules that are seen in neurofibromatosis. They are present bilaterally and appear as clear, yellow, or brown elevations above the iris surface.

Option D: Busacca nodules are present on the iris stroma. They are seen in granulomatous uveitis.

questions.text: Which of the given eggs belong to the parasites that can cause autoinfection?
questions.solution:
Among the given options eggs of Strongyloides stercoralis (Image 2) and Enterobius vermicularis (Image 3) belong to parasites that can cause autoinfection.

questions.text: A child with a history of egg allergy is advised not to take the live attenuated vaccine for influenza by their family doctor as the vaccine was developed by growing the influenza virus in an embryonated egg. Which of the following sites of an embryonated egg is used for the influenza virus vaccine production?
questions.solution:
Allantoic cavity inoculation is used for the growth of the influenza virus for vaccine production.

Embryonated eggs of a duck or a hen are used for the cultivation of several viruses at different sites. These sites are:

  • Chorioallantoic membrane (CAM) (option A) inoculation results in the formation of lesions called pocks. These vary in morphology from one virus to another and each virus particle forms one pock under suitable conditions. Pock counting is employed in the assay of variola or vaccinia.
  • The allantoic cavity can be used to inoculate influenza and some paramyxoviruses. 
  • Inoculation of the amniotic sac (option B) is used for the isolation of the influenza virus.
  • The yolk sac (option C) is inoculated for the cultivation of viruses, chlamydiae, and rickettsiae.

For the production of the influenza vaccine, each strain of virus is grown in the allantoic cavity of the embryonated eggs. The allantoic or amniotic fluids may be harvested to prepare a single harvest after incubation.

Other chick embryo vaccines include those for yellow fever (17D strain) and the non-neural rabies vaccine. (Flury strain)

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient is brought to the ER after he complained of chest tightness and then collapsed after running a half marathon. His father and grandfather also have a history of similar episodes. On echocardiography, mitral regurgitation and systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve leaflet are seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a young patient with a history of chest tightness and sudden collapse following strenuous physical activity, with a similar history in first-degree relatives and echocardiography showing mitral regurgitation with systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve leaflet, a diagnosis of hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HCM) is likely. 

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is characterized by the thickening of the septal myocardium below the aortic valve. This leads to obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract and the most common presenting symptoms. Systolic obstruction is initiated by drag forces, which push an anterior displaced anterior mitral valve leaflet into contact with the hypertrophied septum. This causes mitral regurgitation, and decreased cardiac output due to the obstruction. Stroke volume is maintained by increasing the pressure generated by the ventricles, and can thus lead to myocardial ischemia. Conditions of low preload such as dehydration and low afterload such as arterial vasodilation can cause hypotension and syncope. 

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with variable penetrance. The most frequent symptoms are dyspnea and chest pain. Syncope can occur following exertion as diastolic filling diminished due to fluid loss and tachycardia increases LV outflow tract obstruction. Ventricular arrhythmias can cause sudden cardiac death. On examination, pulsus bisferiens, triple apical impulse and loud S4 may be heard. Auscultation may reveal a systolic murmur that increases with upright posture or Valsalva maneuver and decreases with squatting.

Echocardiography is diagnostic, showing left ventricular hypertrophy with asymmetrical hypertrophy of the interventricular septum, systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve and mitral regurgitation. Beta-blockers are the initial medication in symptomatic individuals. Calcium channel blockers, specially Verapamil have also been shown to be effective in symptomatic patients. Preventive intra-cardiac defibrillator is indicated for patients with HCM and documented cardiac arrest or sustained ventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man was referred to cardiology OPD for the management of hypertension. His BP was not controlled with spironolactone and laboratory investigations revealed hypokalemia & metabolic alkalosis. His BP comes down when spironolactone is replaced with amiloride. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a young patient with hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis, responding to amiloride but not spironolactone, a diagnosis of Liddle syndrome (also known as pseudohyperaldosteronism) is most likely.

Liddle syndrome is due to the autosomal dominant gain of function mutation in epithelium sodium channel, ENaC, in collecting tubules. It classically causes hypertension in young patients, along with hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. The disease responds to amiloride but is resistant to spironolactone. Although its presentation is similar to primary hyperaldosteronism, aldosterone is nearly undetectable in the serum due to negative feedback. Hence it is also known as pseudohyperaldosteronism.

Other options:

Option A: Syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess (SAME) occurs due to the activation of mineralocorticoid receptors by cortisol, like in 11-β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency. It also presents with hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis, but mineralocorticoid receptor blockade with spironolactone is successful in treating SAME. Spironolactone does not work in Liddle syndrome because the defect is downstream to where spironolactone acts.

Option C: Addison's disease refers to adrenal insufficiency and decreased levels of aldosterone. It presents with hyponatremic volume contraction (which may lead to hypotension), hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis.

Option D: Bartter syndrome is an autosomal recessive renal tubular reabsorption defect in Na+/K+/2Cl- channel. It causes hypokalemia, hypercalciuria, and metabolic alkalosis. But BP is usually low to normal. It mimics chronic loop diuretic use.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text:
Pyruvate formed from glycolysis is converted into acetyl CoA. Which of the following co-factors are required for this reaction?
  1. Thiamine pyrophosphate
  2. Oleic acid 
  3. Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide
  4. Lipoic acid
  5. ATP
questions.solution:
Pyruvate is converted to acetyl CoA by the enzyme pyruvate dehydrogenase. The co-factors required for this reaction are thiamine pyrophosphate, nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide, and lipoic acid.

The given pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex is a multienzyme complex that is associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane. It catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA which enters the citric acid/Kreb’s cycle. It has 5 cofactors

Dihydrolipoyl transacetylase (E2)

Lipoic acid

Coenzyme A

Flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD)

The other multienzyme complexes that catalyze oxidative decarboxylation reactions are 

  • α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase in the citric acid cycle.
  • Branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase is involved in the metabolism of leucine, isoleucine, and valine.

This can explain why a deficiency of thiamine causes reduced energy production.

questions.text: Run amok and amotivational syndrome are clinical presentations that are associated with the abuse of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Run Amok and Amotivational syndrome are associated with the abuse of Cannabis sativa.

Amotivational syndrome is characterized by lethargy and a lack of interest in day-to-day activities.

Run amok is a psychic disturbance resulting from continued use or sudden consumption of cannabis and is characterized by a peculiar homicidal mania. The person is not held responsible for his acts since ‘run amok’ is considered a disorder of mind and not intoxication.

questions.text: In a patient with interstitial lung disease, which of the following parameters of pulmonary function test would be normal?
questions.solution:
Interstitial lung disease is a restrictive lung disease. Therefore, the FEV1/FVC ratio would be normal on the pulmonary function test.

Interstitial lung disease increases the recoil tendency of the lung. This lowers the total lung capacity (TLC), functional residual capacity (FRC) as well as forced vital capacity (FVC). Maximal expiratory flows such as FEV1 are also decreased. Moreover, the destruction of the pulmonary capillaries by the fibrotic processes results in a marked reduction in the diffusion capacity. Oxygenation is severely reduced because of persistent perfusion of alveolar units which are underventilated due to pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old sexually active woman presents with profuse, frothy vaginal discharge associated with itching. On examination, there are multiple punctate spots on the cervix. The most likely causative organism is a _______

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient who presented with abdominal pain, bloody stools, and hypertension was diagnosed with polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). Which of the following will not be seen in the histopathological examination of a vessel biopsy in this condition?

choices.text: Lesions of the same age throughout the artery

questions.solution:
In polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), all stages of the disease co-exist at the same time in different or even in the same vessels. This suggests ongoing injury and the body's attempts at healing. While a fresh lesion may show transmural necrosis, older lesions will show fibrous thickening of the blood vessels. Hence, the vascular lesions are of different ages.

The microscopic examination of PAN shows segmental, transmural necrotizing inflammation. PAN primarily affects the small- and medium-sized arteries (option A). The kidney, heart and GIT vessels are the most commonly involved ones. Lesions usually involve only part of the vessel circumference, and have a predilection for branch points. Because of these lesions, there can be impaired perfusion to the distal organs, resulting in infarcts and ischemic atrophy. 

During the acute phase, there is transmural inflammation of the arterial wall and fibrinoid necrosis as shown in the image below. The phase of acute inflammation can also be complicated by thrombosis. Older lesions show fibrous thickening of the vessel wall extending into the adventitia. All the stages of the disease activity (acute to chronic) are often present in the same vessel. 

Patients typically present with hypertension (due to renal artery involvement) and abdominal pain and bloody stools (due to involvement of the GIT blood vessels). One-third of the patients with PAN have chronic hepatitis B.
